(Code 1983, § 4-121; Ord. No. 443-07-04, 7-15-2004)
 
Sec. 6-24. Dogs not to run at large; impounding.
(a)	It is unlawful and an offense for any person to permit a dog, possessed, kept or harbored by him to run at large on the streets, alleys, or public places, or on private premises not under the control of the owner, within the city whether licensed or not. All dogs will be kept in an enclosed area or on a leash. 
(b)	It is the duty of the dog catcher to take up any dog found running at large and confine it to the city pound for 48 hours. The owner may redeem the dog within 48 hours upon the payment of the sum of the pound fee, and all other costs provided by the city. The chief of police or other officer will be allowed to enter upon private property to restrain dogs violating this division. In the event the chief of police or other officer is unable to capture the dog, he shall issue a complaint against the owner of this animal. 
(c)	All fees shall be delivered to the city treasurer and credited to the general fund of the city, provided that a dog may not be redeemed or released unless there is adequate evidence that the dog has been vaccinated and licensed as required by this Code. 
(d)	In the event that the owner of any dog impounded by the city fails to pay the amount set out above and redeem the dog within 48 hours, it is the duty of the police chief or other officer to destroy any dog not reclaimed. However, if, in the judgment and discretion of the other officer the unreclaimed animal should not be destroyed, then the chief of police, after the time for reclaiming such dog has expired, shall sell and dispose of the dog for sums equal to the total poundage plus any liens or registration fees then due. Before selling of any dog in this manner, all dogs must be vaccinated for rabies. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.25; Code 1983, § 4-129)
 
Secs. 6-25—6-49. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. PROHIBITED ANIMALS
 
Sec. 6-50. Animals, keeping prohibited.
(a)	It is unlawful to keep, harbor, own or in any way possess within the corporate limits of the city: 
(1)	Certain wild and exotic animals. Any warm-blooded, carnivorous or omnivorous, wild or exotic animal excluding fowl, ferrets and small rodents of varieties used for laboratory purposes and excluding exhibitions of animals maintained by a zoological park. Any person having a current state commercial wildlife license dated prior to October 10, 1996, will be allowed to keep and replace animals approved by his current license, provided that: 
a.	The state commercial wildlife license remains continuously current; 
b.	No violation of the license occurs that requires the license to be revoked; 
c.	The city sanitation requirements are met at all times; 
d.	Animals remain in the location approved by the license; 
e.	Animals are not sold to a person who resides within the city limits unless that person has a current state commercial wildlife license issued prior to October 10, 1996, or that person will be keeping the animals outside the city limits; 
f.	The number of wild animals kept on property within the city limits is in accordance with this chapter and any other relevant provisions of this Code ; and 
g.	The animal control officer is permitted to make periodic inspections of the wild animal facilities within the city. 
(2)	Any animal having a poisonous bite. 
(3)	Any pit bull dog, defined, for purposes of this subsection, as the bull terrier breed, the Staffordshire bull terrier breed, the American pit bull terrier breed, and the American Staffordshire terrier breed and any mixed breed of dog which contains as an element of its breeding any of the breeds described. 
(b)	Any person violating or permitting the violation of any provision of this section shall upon conviction in municipal court be fined as provided in the city fine schedule. In addition to the fine imposed, the court may sentence the defendant to imprisonment for a period not to exceed 30 days. In the event the violation shall involve an animal prohibited by this section, the court shall order the animal removed from the city. Should the animal owner refuse to remove the animal from the city, the municipal court judge shall find the defendant owner in contempt and order the immediate confiscation and impoundment of the animal. If the owner shall continue to refuse to remove the animal from the city, the municipal court judge shall issue any other orders necessary to carry out the intent of this section. Each day that a violation of this division continues shall be deemed a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing penalties, any person who violates this section shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, handling, veterinary care and testimony necessitated by the enforcement. 
(Code 1983, § 4-200; Ord. No. 357-9-96, 11-14-1996)
 
Secs. 6-51—6-73. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. VICIOUS ANIMALS
 
Sec. 6-74. Vicious animals prohibited.
It is unlawful for any person, owner or possessor to keep a vicious animal as defined by section 6-1. 
(Code 1983, § 4-211; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-75. Attacks prohibited.
(a)	It shall be unlawful for any person, owner or possessor to permit such animal to attack or bite any person or animal upon the premises of the person, owner or possessor. It shall be an affirmative defense to this subsection when such premises are previously posted at each entrance to the same with prominent and conspicuous signs warning all persons in lettering not less than two inches in height of such animal. It is also an affirmative defense to this subsection that the use of such animal to attack or bite any person was necessary to prevent or apprehend a person engaged in committing an act of violence, robbery or theft upon the property. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any person, owner or possessor to permit such animal to attack or bite any person or animal not upon the premises of such person, owner or possessor. 
(c)	For the purposes of this section, the term "attack" shall mean violent or aggressive physical contact. 
(d)	The provisions of this section shall not apply to any law enforcement officer who uses or employs an animal while engaged in law enforcement activities, nor to any owner, possessor or keeper whose animal attacks or bites a person engaged in physically attacking or striking the owner, possessor or keeper. 
(Code 1983, § 4-212; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-76. Complaint of violation.
(a)	Any person who witnesses or has personal knowledge that an act made unlawful by this division has been committed may file a complaint in the municipal court against the alleged violator. 
(b)	Any police officer, animal control officer or code enforcement officer who is employed by the city is authorized to issue a summons and complaint when the officer personally observes a violation of this division. 
(c)	The complainant shall provide a sworn complaint to the officer receiving the complaint containing the following information: 
(1)	Name, address and telephone number of the complainant and other witnesses to the incident; 
(2)	Date, time and location of the incident; 
(3)	Description of the animal; 
(4)	Name, address and telephone number (if known) of the animal owner; 
(5)	A statement that the animal attacked the complainant or some other person or animal as witnessed by the complainant; and 
(6)	Other facts and circumstances of the incident. 
(Code 1983, § 4-213; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-77. Impoundment.
It shall be the duty of the city manager or his designated representative, upon receipt of a verified complaint under this division to cause the animal involved to be impounded pending a determination as required by this division. Any and all expenses associated with the impounding including shelter, food, handling and veterinary care shall be borne by the owner of such animal during the period of impoundment. 
(Code 1983, § 4-214; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-78. Hearing.
The municipal judge, in addition to any hearings which may be required on criminal charges, shall hold a hearing within ten days of the date of impoundment to determine if the animal is vicious as defined by this division. The hearing may be held in conjunction with any criminal proceedings if so ordered by the judge but in no event shall this delay the hearing on determination of viciousness. 
(Code 1983, § 4-215; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-79. Determination.
The municipal judge shall be empowered to make one of the following determinations as a result of the hearing: 
(1)	The animal is in fact not vicious, in which event, the city manager shall cause it to be surrendered to the owner of the animal, upon payment by the owner of expenses as required by this division; 
(2)	The animal is in fact vicious and should be destroyed; 
(3)	The animal is vicious but, that for good cause shown, the animal should not be destroyed in which event the judge shall order one of the following: 
a.	That the animal be immediately removed from the corporate limits of the city and not to ever be again allowed within the corporate limits of the city and that the owner give a good and sufficient bond in the amount of $250.00 and pay all fees required by this division; 
b.	That the owner be allowed to maintain the vicious animal within the corporate limits of the city under the following conditions: 
1.	Fees. Payment of all fees required by this division. 
2.	Leash and muzzle. No person shall permit an animal covered by this section to go outside its kennel or pen unless such animal is securely leashed with a leash no longer than four feet in length. No person shall permit the animal to be kept on a chain, rope or other type of leash outside its kennel or pen unless a person is in physical control of the leash. Such animal may not be leashed to inanimate objects such as trees, posts, buildings, etc. In addition, all animals on a leash outside the animal's kennel must be muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent such animal from biting persons or other animals; 
3.	General confinement. All animals covered by this section shall be securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen or kennel, except when leashed and muzzled as above provided. Such pen, kennel or structure must have secure sides and a secure top attached to the sides. All structures used to confine the animals must be locked with a key or combination lock when such animals are within the structure. Such structure must have a secure bottom or floor attached to the sides of the pen or the sides of the pen must be embedded in the ground no less than two feet. All structures erected to house the animals must comply with all zoning and building regulations of the city. All such structures must be adequately lighted and ventilated and kept in a clean and sanitary condition; 
4.	Confinement indoors. No animal covered by this section may be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the animal to exit such building on its own volition. In addition, no such animal may be kept in a house or structure when the windows are open or when screen windows or screen doors are the only obstacle preventing the animal from exiting the structure; 
5.	Signs. All owners, keepers or harborers of animals covered by this section within the city shall display in a prominent place on their premises a sign easily readable by the public using the words "Beware of Vicious Animal." in addition, a similar sign is required to be posted on the kennel or pen of such animal; and 
6.	Insurance. All owners, keepers or harborers of animals covered by this section must provide proof to the animal control officer of public liability insurance in a single incident amount of $50,000.00 for bodily injury to or death of any person or persons or for damage to property owned by any persons which may result from the ownership, keeping or maintenance of such animal. Such insurance policy shall provide that no cancellation of the policy will be made unless ten days' written notice is first given to the animal control officer. 
(4)	All owners, whose animal is adjudged to be vicious at the hearing, and sentence imposed by the municipal judge pursuant to this section, upon written demand, may appeal the judge's decision with ten days to the district court of the county where a trial in the district court shall be accorded them de novo. All such appeals shall comply with the procedures of section 12-131. 
(Code 1983, § 4-216; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-80. Violation and penalties.
Any person violating or permitting the violation of any provision of this article shall upon conviction be fined as provided in the city fine schedule. In addition to the fine imposed, the court may sentence the defendant to imprisonment in the municipal jail for a period not to exceed 30 days. Each day that a violation of this division continues shall be a separate offense. 
(Code 1983, § 4-217; Ord. No. 358-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Secs. 6-81—6-103. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. CATS
 
Sec. 6-104. Authority to seize, impound cats.
It is the duty of the city manager or his authorized representatives to seize and impound for the times and under the conditions hereinafter stated every abandoned cat, every vicious cat, every rabies suspected cat, every cat which is a nuisance as hereinafter provided, and every cat, either licensed or unlicensed, which is found running at large upon the streets, alleys or public places or upon private premises not under the control of the owner of such cat, and every cat the keeping or harboring of which is declared to be an offense. 
(Code 1983, § 4-185; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-105. Failure to surrender violating cats.
It shall be unlawful to fail or refuse to deliver to the city manager or his designated representative, upon demand, any licensed cat, any vicious cat, any cat which is a nuisance, any rabies suspected cat, or any cat the keeping or harboring of which is declared to be an offense. 
(Code 1983, § 4-186; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-106. When cat constitutes a nuisance.
A cat within the city limits is deemed a nuisance if it: 
(1)	Molests passersby or passing vehicles; 
(2)	Attacks other animals; 
(3)	Trespasses on school grounds; 
(4)	Is repeatedly at large; 
(5)	Damages private or public property; 
(6)	Meows, whines, or howls in an excessive, continuous, or untimely fashion, or otherwise endangering or offending the well-being of the public without cause; or 
(7)	Overturns any garbage can or other vessel for waste products or scatters the contents of same, is a public nuisance. 
(Code 1983, § 4-187; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-107. Nuisance cats prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person to harbor, keep or have possession of any cat which is a nuisance as herein defined. 
(Code 1983, § 4-188; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-108. Procedure for nuisance cats.
(a)	It is the duty of the city manager or persons designated by him, upon being notified that any person claiming that a cat is a nuisance within the meaning of this division has filed a verified complaint alleging that such cat is a nuisance as herein defined, to seize and impound the cat therein described. If the court finds that no nuisance exists, it shall order the cat to be surrendered to the owner thereof. 
(b)	If the court finds that the nuisance exists without cause, it shall order the cat destroyed as in the case of a vicious cat; however, if the owner of such cat gives a good and sufficient bond in the sum of $200.00 with a surety to be approved by the judge of the municipal court conditioned that such owner shall abate and prevent such nuisance, the court shall order the return of such cat to the owner thereof upon payment of the impounding fees herein specified. 
(c)	Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit any cat to run or be at large except as permitted under the city ordinances. No such cat shall be returned to the owner if the same is a vicious cat or in any event unless the same is vaccinated, registered and licensed as required by this division. 
(Code 1983, § 4-189; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-109. Reclaiming cats.
(a)	No person shall be entitled to reclaim any cat found to be a nuisance except as herein provided, nor shall any person be entitled to reclaim any cat found to be rabid or vicious; but the owner may reclaim any other cat seized under the terms of this division within the times and under the conditions stated herein. 
(b)	After the expiration of the ten-day term as to every cat held under observation and not showing symptoms of rabies, and as to every other cat within 48 hours from the time of seizure, the owner may reclaim the cat seized hereunder by submitting proof, satisfactory to the city manager or his designated representative, of his ownership of such cat and by paying any license fees then due for the current year in addition to any applicable impounding fee for any cat plus the costs of providing care and maintenance of the cat for each day since the seizure thereof. 
(c)	In the event the reclaimed cat has not been vaccinated for rabies in accordance with the terms of this division, the person reclaiming it must have the cat properly vaccinated and submit proof of such vaccination to the city manager or his designated representative. Failure to submit such proof within three days will constitute a violation of this division. 
(d)	No cat shall be released without satisfactory proof of ownership and without payment of the charges herein prescribed, nor shall the payment thereof constitute any defense in any prosecution that may be instituted for violation of the terms of this division. 
(e)	No poundage shall be charged for any licensed cat surrendered to the owner on acquittal or dismissal of the charges of harboring such cat as a nuisance or as a vicious cat. 
(Code 1983, § 4-190; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-110. Unreclaimed cats.
At the expiration of the time within which the owner may reclaim any cat seized under the provisions of this division, it is the duty of the humane society, city manager or person designated by him, to destroy any cat not then reclaimed, and cause the body thereof to be disposed of, however, if in the judgment and discretion of the humane society, city manager or person designated by him, the unreclaimed animal should not be destroyed, then the humane society or city manager may, after the time for reclaiming such cat as expired, sell and dispose of the cat for a sum equal to the total poundage plus any license or registration fees then due. Before selling or disposing of any cat in this manner, all cats must be vaccinated for rabies. 
(Code 1983, § 4-191; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-111. Cat waste.
The owner of every cat shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his cat on public walks, recreation areas, or private property. 
(Code 1983, § 4-192; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-112. Vaccination and licensing.
All persons possessing a cat within the city limits shall comply with the provisions of section 6-206. 
(Code 1983, § 4-193; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-113. Isolation.
The city manager or his designated representative may require or cause any cat which he has reason to believe may be infected with rabies to be confined in accordance with state law. 
(Code 1983, § 4-194; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Sec. 6-114. Release from pound.
Whenever a cat is impounded because the same is not licensed or because it is suspected of rabies, the cat shall not be released to the owner or person making claim thereto until the city manager or his designated representative holding the cat shall be furnished with a certificate of vaccination from a veterinarian or other person legally authorized to immunize cats showing that the cat has been immunized against rabies during the calendar year, and that any applicable impounding fee for any cat plus the cost for providing care and maintenance of the cat for each day since the seizure thereof has been paid. 
(Code 1983, § 4-195; Ord. No. 359-9-96, 10-10-1996)
 
Secs. 6-115—6-141. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 5. POULTRY AND FOWL
 
Sec. 6-142. Restrictions.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to keep poultry in any residential zoning except as provided in this division. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.40; Code 1983, § 4-150)
 
Sec. 6-143. Enclosure area.
No more than 12 poultry may be kept in an area of enclosure having a minimum of 100 square feet. For each four additional poultry, 50 square feet of area must be provided. In no event will more than 16 poultry be allowed on one acre. An additional acre must be provided for each 12 poultry in excess of 16. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.41; Code 1983, § 4-151)
 
Sec. 6-144. Housing facilities; building permits.
The owner, keeper or possessor of any poultry is required to provide an enclosure which shall contain the poultry therein. The erection of any shelter within the enclosure to provide shelter for the poultry shall be neatly built so as to conform to the buildings on the surrounding premises in neatness and appearance and in such a manner as to prevent unsanitary conditions. A building permit shall be secured before the commencement of construction. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.42; Code 1983, § 4-152)
 
Sec. 6-145. Fence.
Any keeper of poultry as provided in this division shall fence the area enclosure in such a manner as to prevent the poultry from escaping or running at large. No poultry shall be allowed to run at large or be tethered outside an area of enclosure within the limits of the city. The fence shall be neat in appearance and conform to the surrounding area. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.43; Code 1983, § 4-153)
 
Sec. 6-146. Determination of area.
In determining the number of square feet in the area of enclosure, only that ground which will be actually encompassed in the area of enclosure shall be used in arriving at the number of square feet in the area of enclosure. No area of enclosure will be closer than 40 feet to any dwelling designed to be used as living quarters for one or more families, and not less than 100 feet from the nearest water well used for human consumption. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.44; Code 1983, § 4-154)
 
Sec. 6-147. Sanitation.
It is the duty of the keeper where the poultry are kept, to maintain and operate the shelter and premises in such a manner as to not create a health nuisance. No keeper of poultry shall allow manure to accumulate in the enclosure and/or shelter. The enclosure and shelter shall be kept in a neat and clean manner. Each shelter or enclosure shall be sprayed with a suitable residual spray as often as is necessary to control flies and other insects. It is unlawful to dump or place any manure or other waste, feathers, or dead poultry in the garbage cans serviced by the sanitation department of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.45; Code 1983, § 4-155)
 
Secs. 6-148—6-177. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 6. LARGE FARM AND LIVESTOCK ANIMALS
 
Sec. 6-178. Requirements for keeping/raising large animals.
Large animals (horse, pony, mule, ass, calf, sheep, goat, cow, steer, bull) may not be kept in areas zoned for residential, commercial or industrial use. In no case may swine (pig or hog) be raised within the city limits of Spencer, Oklahoma. Commercial feed pens for livestock are prohibited within the city limits of Spencer, Oklahoma. 
(a)	Exceptions.
(1)	Large animals may be kept in unplatted areas zoned A-1, suburban agricultural district, provided said property contains a minimum of two and one-half acres and an occupied single family dwelling is part of this two and one-half acre tract. 
(2)	Large animals may be kept in unplatted areas zoned R-1, single-family dwelling district, provided said property contains a minimum of two and one-half acres and an occupied single-family dwelling is part of this two and one-half acre tract. 
(3)	Large animals may be kept in unplatted areas zoned R-5, single family manufactured home district, provided said property contains a minimum of five acres and an occupied conventional single-family dwelling or a single-family manufactured home (mobile home) is part of this five acre tract. 
(b)	Additional requirements concerning the keeping of large animals.
(1)	No large animal may be kept within 40 feet of the dwelling on the same property or within 100 feet of a dwelling adjacent to this property. 
(2)	No large animal will be kept within 100 feet of a private water well on this property or within 100 feet of a private water well adjacent to this property. 
(3)	Adequate fencing to prevent large animals from running at large shall be provided. 
(4)	Adequate water, food supply (pasture, grain or hay), and appropriate shelter shall be provided for large animals. 
(5)	Poor drainage combined with the accumulation of animal manure causing unsanitary conditions, flies, mosquitoes and foul odors may be declared a public nuisance by the City of Spencer with corrective action required by the property owner. 
(6)	Equine registration required. Effective June 30, 2021, any horse, pony, mule or ass kept within the city limits of Spencer must be registered with the City of Spencer on an equine registration form provided by the city. An annual registration fee of $25.00 shall be required for each registered equine animal. All equine registration forms expire on June 30th of each year and must be renewed with the registration fee paid for each animal. 
(7)	The rule for the number of large animals being kept within the City of Spencer, Oklahoma: 
a.	Two cows per acre, excluding one-half acre reserved for the dwelling (excluding other large animals). 
b.	Two horses per acre, excluding one-half acre reserved for the dwelling (excluding other large animals). 
c.	Four sheep or goats per acre, excluding one-half acre reserved for the dwelling (excluding other large animals). 
(c)	Current keeping of large animals not in compliance with this section.
(1)	Properties within the city limits of Spencer, Oklahoma where large animals are being kept that do not comply with this section on the effective date of the ordinance from which it is derived shall be considered a nonconforming use. 
(2)	Large animals being kept on nonconforming properties shall be subject to subsection (b)(1)—(6) above. 
(3)	The removal of large animals from nonconforming properties for a period of three months or more shall terminate the large animal nonconforming use of said property meaning no other large animals will be permitted to be kept or raised on this property. 
(4)	Repeated violations of any of the additional requirements for the keeping of large animals (subsection (b)(1)—(6)) within any three-month period shall result in the termination of the large animal nonconforming use status and the future use of said property for keeping or raising large animals. 
(Ord. No. 539-05-11, § 1(4-102), 5-19-2011; Ord. No. 2020-12-17 , § 1, 12-17-2020)
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 2020-12-17 , § 1, adopted Dec. 17, 2020, changed the title of § 6-178 from requirements for housing to requirements for keeping/raising large animals. 
 
Sec. 6-179. Reserved.
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 2020-12-17 , § 2, adopted Dec. 17, 2020, repealed § 6-179, which pertained to special permits allowed for keeping [large animals] on properties with less than five acres, and derived from Ord. No. 539-05-11, § 1(4-103), adopted May 19, 2011. 
 
Sec. 6-180. Breeding in public prohibited.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person who is owner or possessor of any male or female large animal or the owner or possessor or occupier of the premises to permit or authorize the breeding of such animals at any place in the city limits that is in view of any private residence, public road or way, playground, school, or other place where private citizens may congregate or be. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.12; Code 1983, § 4-112)
 
Sec. 6-181. Certain farm animals and livestock not to run at large or be present on public property.
Unless specifically authorized by the city, no person shall permit any horse, pony, mule, ass, calf, sheep, goat, swine, cow, steer, bull, or other animal owned by or under his control to run at large or be picketed, staked or herded, or to be driven in or on the streets, alleys, and public grounds within the city limits. All stock must be led by halter or rope in being taken to and from pasture. However, nothing in this division shall prevent dealers or other persons from driving their stock to market. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.13; Code 1983, § 4-113)
 
Sec. 6-182. Chief of police to impound animals at large.
All police officers of the city and such other persons as the chief of police may in writing designate and appoint are authorized and directed to take up all animals found running at large within the city, contrary to this division. Animals picked up shall be confined in a pound, pen, building, or other place as may be designated by the chief by and with the approval of the city manager. The chief shall provide at the cost of the city suitable and necessary sustenance for all animals so taken up and impounded. The cost of providing such sustenance, together with all other costs and charges growing out of the taking up, care and keeping of such animals, shall be paid by the owner or person redeeming the animal before the animal shall be released. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.14; Code 1983, § 4-114)
 
Sec. 6-183. Owners of animals responsible for damages.
Any person driving horses, cattle or other stock along the streets or alleys of the city shall be held liable for all damages done by such stock to lawn, trees, or shrubbery. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.18; Code 1983, § 4-118)
 
Secs. 6-184—6-205. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 7. LICENSING AND RABIES VACCINATION
 
Sec. 6-206. License required; reduced rates offered.
It is unlawful for any person to keep, own, possess, harbor or to allow to remain upon the premises under his control, within the city any dog or cat without having obtained a license. The license fee is as provided in the city fee schedule for each dog and cat. All licenses shall expire on June 30 of each year. License fees shall be reduced by 50 percent with proof that the animal is spayed or neutered. A certificate from a licensed veterinarian shall serve as proof and must be submitted at the time of purchase. 
(Code 1983, § 4-122; Ord. No. 443-07-04, 7-15-2004)
 
Sec. 6-207. Cats and dogs to be vaccinated.
The owner or keeper of any dog or cat of three months of age or older within the city limits shall have the dog or cat vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian every calendar year. Owners shall affix, or have affixed, to the collar or harness of each vaccinated dog or cat a metal disc with sufficient information thereon that the vaccination certificate covering the animal may be readily traced. 
(Code 1983, § 4-123)
 
Sec. 6-208. Vaccination required for license.
No license shall be issued for any dog or cat unless the dog or cat shall have first been vaccinated against rabies by a veterinarian within 60 days prior to the issuance of such license for the dog or cat. There shall be delivered to the city clerk-treasurer prior to the issuance of such license, a certificate signed by a veterinarian, duly licensed to practice within the state, that the dog or cat has been duly vaccinated, giving the date of the vaccination thereof. Thereafter and upon payment of the fee as provided by law, the city clerk-treasurer shall issue a license for the dog or cat. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.21; Code 1983, § 4-124; Ord. No. 443-07-04, 7-15-2004)
 
Sec. 6-209. Payments of license fee, issuance of license and metal tag.
The license fee required in this division shall be paid annually and in advance and upon the payment of the fee. In addition to issuing the license, the city clerk-treasurer shall issue a properly numbered metal tag to be affixed to the collar of the dog. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.22; Code 1983, § 4-125)
 
Sec. 6-210. City clerk-treasurer to keep a record.
The city clerk-treasurer shall keep a register of all licenses issued in which shall be entered the name and address of the applicant, the description of the dog or cat, the number of the license and check issued, the amount paid, and the date of issuance and expiration. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.23; Code 1983, § 4-126; Ord. No. 443-07-04, 7-15-2004)
 
Sec. 6-211. Tag to be attached to collar; lost tag.
The metal tag shall be securely fastened to the collar to be worn by the dog. If any such tag is lost, the city clerk-treasurer may, on satisfactory proof thereof, and on payment of the sum as provided in the city fee schedule, issue another, and shall note such fact and number of such tag on the register, together with a memorandum of the amount paid therefor. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.24; Code 1983, § 4-127)
 
Sec. 6-212. Unlawful to remove tag.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to remove any tag from the collar of any dog without the owner's consent. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.24; Code 1983, § 4-128)
 
Sec. 6-213. Report of persons bitten by animal.
Any person owning or having under his control any animal who bites any person or any person who has been bitten by any animal shall forthwith notify the police department of the city giving the location and license number of the animal and the name and address of the owner thereof and the name and address of the person bitten, and failure to make such report is an offense. 
(Prior Code, §§ 6-1.26, 6-1.36; Code 1983, § 4-130
 
Sec. 6-214. Owner to confine dog which bites.
The owner of any animal who has bitten a person shall immediately fasten up the animal and the animal shall be impounded at the city pound or in a veterinary hospital which has been approved by the city for a period of 14 days. The expense of such impoundment shall be paid by the owner of the animal. If the owner cannot be located or found, or refuses to pay for the upkeep of the animal, the animal shall be destroyed at the end of the 14 days as otherwise provided in this division. 
(Prior Code, §§ 6-1.27, 6-1.28; Code 1983, § 4-131)
 
Sec. 6-215. Enforcement.
It is the duty and responsibility of the police department of the city to enforce the provisions of this division. However, the city manager may appoint a qualified person to act as dog catcher, who shall have police authority. He shall perform such other duties as may be directed by the city manager. 
(Prior Code, § 6-131; Code 1983, § 4-133)
 
Secs. 6-216—6-238. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 8. CITY POUND AND IMPOUNDMENT
 
Sec. 6-239. City pound.
A city pound shall be provided and maintained at the expense of the city in which all animals found at large in the city contrary to this Code shall be impounded. Such pound shall be constructed in such manner as to provide shelter for all animals impounded therein, with sufficient stalls to separate one breed of animal from that of another, and to separate a ferocious animal from that of another of the same breed in separate stalls; and shall be constructed out of strong material to ensure the safe keeping of all animals. Animals held for observation shall be maintained in separate stalls. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.32; Code 1983, § 4-140)
 
Sec. 6-240. Pound keeper.
A qualified person shall be approved to serve during the pleasure of the city manager as pound keeper whose duty it is to take up and impound all animals and livestock running at large contrary to the ordinances of the city, and to safely keep and dispose of all animals coming into his possession as provided by this Code. He shall provide adequate food, water, shelter and care to such animals while the same are in the city pound, and shall take precaution for the safe care of animals while impounded; the pound keeper shall have full police power to pick up, impound, sell, release on redemption all live stock and animals as provided by the ordinances of the city and to destroy and bury all unredeemed dogs impounded therein, as provided by such ordinances, and shall perform such duties as directed. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.33; Code 1983, § 4-141)
 
Sec. 6-241. Disposal of animals.
It is the responsibility of the pound keeper to notify the owner of any impounded animals, if such owner can be determined, of the fact of the impoundment of the animal and any dog not redeemed by the owner shall be killed and buried, as provided by law. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.34; Code 1983, § 4-142)
 
Sec. 6-242. Monthly report.
The pound keeper shall make a written report within the first five days of the month to the city manager, a duplicate of which shall be filed with the city clerk, which report shall include the following: 
(1)	By class the total number of animals received at the city pound the previous month; 
(2)	A description of each animal; 
(3)	The name of the owner if known; 
(4)	The date received or taken up; 
(5)	The date of redemption; 
(6)	Animals sold and the time of sale and the price received; and 
(7)	Animals destroyed. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.35; Code 1983, § 4-143)
 
Sec. 6-243. Sale of impounded animals.
Any animal taken up and impounded may be sold at public auction by the chief of police or otherwise disposed of at any time after the expiration of three days from the time of impounding the same. The chief of police or other officer shall give at least five days' notice of the time and place of such sale, by causing notices thereof to be posted in the police office of the city hall and the city pound. The notice shall be substantially in the form approved by the city from time to time. 
(Code 1983, § 4-115)
 
Sec. 6-244. Redemption of animals impounded; excess over expenses to be paid owner.
(a)	If the owner of any animal shall pay the costs, which shall include a pick-up fee plus feeding costs per animal, all as set by the city council by motion or resolution, and other charges and expenses incurred under this chapter at any time before the sale or disposition of such animal, the chief of police or other officer shall release such animal. 
(b)	If the owner of any animal shall apply to the city after such animal has been sold and prove the ownership thereof to the satisfaction of the chief of police, before payment to the city treasurer, the chief shall pay the balance from the sale of such animal to the applicant, taking his receipt in duplicate, one of which he will file with the city clerk. 
(c)	But if the owner of such animal sold shall apply to the city after the payment to the city treasurer, and prove the ownership thereof to his satisfaction, then the chief of police shall certify the facts to the mayor and council, stating the amount deposited in the city treasury and account of such animal, and therefrom a warrant shall be drawn upon the treasurer in favor of claimant for the amount so certified by the chief of police. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.16; Code 1983, § 4-116)
 
Sec. 6-245. Breaking open pound.
It is unlawful for any person to break open or in any manner directly or indirectly aid, assist in or counsel or advise the breaking open of any city pound, or to hinder, delay or obstruct any person duly authorized in taking up or taking to the city pound any animal liable to be impounded. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.17; Code 1983, § 4-112)
 
Sec. 6-246. Payment of food and care for impounding dog.
The fee for the food and care of any animal confined in the city pound under this chapter shall be set by the city council by motion or resolution. Before any dog shall be redeemed the full cost of the food and care shall have been fully paid by the owner. 
(Prior Code, § 6-1.29; Code 1983, § 4-132)
 
Secs. 6-247—6-270. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. COMMERCIAL ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENTS
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 6-271. Restrictions.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to offer any animal for sale, barter, or give away at any public market, flea market, swap meet, fair, commercial store, or similar establishment or for any person to provide facilities for the sale, barter, or give away of any animal except as provided in this article. 
(Code 1983, § 4-160; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-272. Compliance with Code.
(a)	Animal licensing and vaccination. An animal establishment shall not sell, trade or give away any dog or cat over three months of age unless the dog or cat has been licensed or vaccinated as required by this Code. 
(b)	Diseased animals. An animal establishment shall cease the sale of animals when it has been determined that an animal in their care has a contagious disease. The sale of animals can continue after certification by a veterinarian that the disease has been arrested or is of no threat to the other animals. Licenses will be revoked if an establishment sells sick or diseased animals. 
(c)	Inspection. The animal control authority shall be permitted to inspect any animal establishment and all animals and the premises where such animals are kept at any reasonable time during normal business hours to ensure compliance with all provisions of this article and the animal control code. 
(Code 1983, § 4-137; Ord. No. 290-A, 4-17-1990)
 
Sec. 6-273. Space requirements and restraints.
(a)	Cages or enclosures shall be large enough to ensure that each animal contained therein has space enough equal to a minimum of two times the length of its body and sufficient space to turn about freely in a standing position using normal body movements, to stand and sit erect, and to lie in a natural position. This requirement shall apply to each animal regardless of the number of animals within the cage or enclosure. 
(b)	Chains, ropes, or other devices used to contain animals must be of such length to allow the animal to sit erect, stand, or lie in a natural position, and to be so attached to a stake or other device so as to prevent the animal from becoming entangled in or from becoming wound around the stake or other device to which the chain, rope, or other device is attached. Animals tethered to fences along a public thoroughfare is prohibited. 
(Code 1983, § 4-161; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-274. Shelter.
Sufficient shade shall be provided to allow all animals to protect themselves from the direct rays of the sun and sufficient shelter shall be provided to allow all animals to remain dry during rain or inclement weather. 
(Code 1983, § 4-162; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-275. Food and water.
Fresh, non-contaminated water shall be accessible to the animals at all times. Watering receptacles shall be kept clean and sanitary at all times. Animals shall not be deprived of their daily food requirements as a result of their being confined for sale, barter or give away. 
(Code 1983, §§ 4-163, 4-164; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-276. Classification and separation.
Animals housed in the same cage or enclosure shall be maintained in compatible groups with species of their own kind. 
(Code 1983, § 4-165; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-277. Sick or injured animals.
Animals suspected of being sick, diseased, or injured shall be removed from the premises and must receive prompt veterinary care. 
(Code 1983, § 4-166; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-278. Disposal of waste.
Animal waste and uneaten food must be properly disposed of. Cages and enclosures shall be cleaned of waste as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals contained therein and to reduce disease hazards and odors. 
(Code 1983, § 4-167; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-279. Rabies vaccination.
Dogs, cats, and other animals requiring rabies vaccination by state law, for sale, barter, or give away shall have a current rabies vaccination certificate available for inspection. 
(Code 1983, § 4-168; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-280. Regulations to apply to all animals.
Any owner of such establishment will provide shelters and enclosures as prescribed by this section for all animals, including large animals, for example, horses, mules, ponies, cows, goats, sheep and swine. Such shelters and enclosures will comply with city ordinances. 
(Code 1983, § 4-169; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-281. Responsibility for compliance.
An owner or keeper of animals, or an occupant or owner of such establishment who charges fees for, or allows to occur free, such sales, barter, or give away of animals, will be responsible for the care requirements as set forth in this section. 
(Code 1983, § 4-170; Ord. No. 239-A, 3-20-1986)
 
Sec. 6-282. Pet shops.
All pet shops, including pet shops operated in conjunction with another holding facility, shall, in addition to the other requirements of this Code, comply with the minimum standards of this section. Failure to meet these standards shall be grounds for denial of a license or revocation of a license. Standards for pet shops are as follows: 
(1)	There shall be available hot water at a minimum temperature of 160 degrees Fahrenheit for washing cages and disinfecting, and cold water easily accessible to all parts of the shop. Fresh water shall be available to all species at all times. Containers are to be cleaned and disinfected each day; 
(2)	The room temperature of the shop shall be maintained at a level that is healthful for every species of animal kept in the shop; and 
(3)	All cages and enclosures are to be of a nonporous material for easy cleaning and disinfecting. Each cage must be of sufficient size that the animal will have room to stand, turn and stretch out to his full length. 
(Code 1983, § 4-135; Ord. No. 290-A, 4-17-1990)
 
Secs. 6-283—6-312. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. KENNELS
 
Sec. 6-313. Minimum operating standards.
All kennels shall, in addition to the other requirements of this Code, comply with the minimum standards of this section. Failure to meet these standards shall be grounds for denial of a license or revocation of a license. Standards for kennels are as follows: 
(1)	Enclosures must be provided which shall allow adequate protection against weather extremes. Floors of buildings, runs and walls shall be of an impervious material to permit proper cleaning and disinfecting; 
(2)	Building temperature shall be maintained at a comfortable level. Adequate ventilation shall be maintained; 
(3)	Each animal shall have sufficient space to stand up, lie down and turn around without touching the sides or top of cages; 
(4)	Cages are to be of material and construction that permit cleaning and sanitizing; 
(5)	Cage floors of concrete, unless radiantly heated, shall have a resting board or some type of bedding. Bedding is to be of material that permits cleaning and sanitizing, or should be changed and disposed of daily; 
(6)	Runs shall provide an adequate exercise area and protection from the weather. Runs shall have an impervious surface; 
(7)	All animal quarters and runs are to be kept clean, dry, and in a sanitary condition; 
(8)	The food shall be free from contamination, wholesome, palatable and of sufficient quantity and nutritive value to meet the normal daily requirements for the condition and size of the animal; 
(9)	All animals shall have fresh water available at all times; and 
(10)	All sick animals shall be separated from the rest of the animals at a distance to minimize infection of healthy animals. 
(Code 1983, § 4-134; Ord. No. 290-A, 4-17-1990)
 
Chapter 8 BUILDINGS AND CONSTRUCTION
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 8-1. Engineering department.
(a)	Department established; personnel. There is hereby established and created an engineering department which consists of a city engineer, a city inspector and such other personnel who may from time to time be authorized by the city council. The city engineer, the city inspector, and all other personnel of the engineering department shall be appointed by the city manager to serve during his pleasure and the city engineer shall be a registered licensed engineer. 
(b)	Duties of the engineer. It is the duty of the city engineer to prepare, at the request of the city manager or the city council, all plans and specifications for the erection, construction or addition to all utility systems, buildings and other structures owned or to be erected by or for the benefit of the city. He shall supervise all construction and shall advise the city council regarding all contractors bidding on contracts for the city, the needs of the city, and shall, from time to time, examine all building codes, fire codes, electrical codes, plumbing codes and other ordinances and regulations pertaining to buildings and development in the city and make recommendations to the council concerning same. He shall issue work orders to all private parties making additions to the streets, water and sewer systems of the city after approval of same by the city council. He shall perform such other duties as the city manager may, from time to time, designate. 
(c)	Duties of the inspector. The inspector shall inspect and examine all construction and additions of buildings, streets and utilities operated by the city for the purpose of checking the compliance with the various building codes of the city and to ascertain if all paving, sewer and water lines are being built to conform with plans and specifications approved by the city council. The inspector shall be charged with the duty of enforcing all ordinances relating to electrical wiring, plumbing, forced-air heating, building code and the buildings in the fire zone. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1.4; Code 1983, §§ 5-101—5-104)
 
Sec. 8-2. Building and dwelling addresses.
(a)	It is the duty of the record owner of every now-existing dwelling, building or structure in the city to place and maintain thereon, in a place visible from the street, figures at least three inches high, showing the number of the dwelling, building or structure. Any person failing to so number any now-existing dwelling, building or structure owned by him within 90 days after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, or, after receiving notice to do so from the city inspector, or shall fail to so number such dwelling, building or structure within 48 hours after such notice, shall be in violation of this section. 
(b)	The record owner of any dwelling, building or structure constructed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall place such figures thereon before or at the time the occupancy permit is issued. 
(Code 1983, § 5-305; Ord. No. 227-A, 4-11-1985)
 
Sec. 8-3. Penalty.
Any person who violates a provision of this chapter or fails to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, or who erects, constructs, alters, or repairs, or has erected, constructed, altered or repaired, a building or structure or portion thereof, in violation of a detailed statement or plan submitted and approved thereunder, is guilty of an offense subject to penalties as provided in the city fine schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 9-1.9; Code 1983, § 5-303)
 
Secs. 8-4—8-24. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. BUILDING PERMITS AND CERTIFICATES OF OCCUPANCY
 
Sec. 8-25. Enforcement authority of building inspector.
This article shall be enforced by a building inspector, acting at the direction of the city manager. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-1.6, 45-8.1; Code 1983, § 5-201)
 
Sec. 8-26. Building permit required.
It is a violation of this Code for any person to change or permit the change in the use of land or buildings or structures or to erect, alter, move, or improve any building or structure until a building permit or certificate of occupancy has been obtained under the following conditions; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to the erection of farm buildings not used for human habitation. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-1.6, 45-8.1; Code 1983, § 5-201)
 
Sec. 8-27. Permit issuance conditioned upon compliance with zoning and other city regulations.
Issuance of building permits and certificates of occupancy under this chapter is subject to such additional restrictions and prerequisites as may be provided elsewhere in this Code, specifically including, but not limited to, city zoning regulations which are cumulative to the provisions of this chapter. 
 
Sec. 8-28. Approval of building inspector or engineer required.
No building permits or permits relating to buildings, wiring, plumbing, paving, or the water system as provided by ordinance shall be issued until approved by the inspector or engineer or his designee. 
(Prior Code, § 12-1.5; Code 1983, § 5-105)
 
Sec. 8-29. Application for permit.
Every application for a building permit shall be accompanied by: 
(1)	A plat drawn to scale, showing the actual shape and dimensions of the lot to be built upon, the exact size and location on the lot of existing buildings and structures and the lines within which the proposed building or structure shall be erected or altered; 
(2)	A declaration of the existing and intended use of each building or part of a building, and the number of families and housekeeping units the building is designed to accommodate; and 
(3)	Such other information with regard to the lot and neighboring lots and their use as may be necessary to determine and provide for the enforcement of these regulations. 
(Code 1983, § 5-202)
 
Sec. 8-30. Certificate of occupancy.
(a)	No change shall be made in the use of any land or building or structure until a certificate of occupancy is approved by the city code enforcement officer and issued by the city clerk certifying that all of the provisions of this chapter are complied with. Whenever a building permit is issued for the erection of a new building or structure, an occupancy permit shall not be required, except when the use of the building or structure is changed from that for which the permit is issued or where the intended use is not clearly stated on the building permit. 
(b)	In certain circumstances, where it is revealed that undue hardship may otherwise result, the city manager or code enforcement officer, at his discretion, may issue a temporary certificate of occupancy not to exceed 60 days' duration, and only if compliance is probable within the time period. If compliance is not met within 60 days, for any reason whatsoever, whether or not within the control of the occupant, then the occupancy shall automatically and summarily cease. 
(Prior Code, § 45-8.4; Code 1983, § 5-203; Ord. No. 263-A, 6-30-1988)
 
Sec. 8-31. Permit and inspection fees.
Fees shall be paid for all new construction and altered construction within the city. All fees except the base inspection fee will be based upon square footage. Fees will be paid to the office of the city clerk before construction is started. The base fee shall be in such sum as set by the council by motion or resolution for each inspection or reinspection plus fees in accordance with the schedule adopted by the council. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-1.7, 9-1.7A, 9-1.8; Code 1983, § 5-204)
 
Sec. 8-32. State required fees for the issuance of building permits.
Pursuant to 59 O.S. §§ 1000.23 and 1000.25, the city shall apply a fee as provided in the city fee schedule per building or construction permit issued by the city to a fund to be remitted to the Uniform Building Code Commission before the 20th of each month. An additional fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be imposed and received by the city to support the processing and handling of this fee. 
(Ord. No. 529-04-10, 4-15-2010)
 
Secs. 8-33—8-53. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. CONSTRUCTION CODES
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 8-54. Adoption of building code.
(a)	Adoption of International Building Code.
(1)	The city adopts the 2012 edition of the International Building Code regulating and governing the conditions and maintenance of all property, building and structures by providing the standards for supplied utilities and facilities and other physical things and conditions essential to ensure that structures are safe, sanitary and fit for occupation and use, and the condemnation of buildings and structures unfit for human occupancy and use and the demolition of such structures in the city. 
(2)	The following sections of the 2012 edition of the International Building Code book are hereby revised: These regulations shall be known as the building code of the city, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(b)	Fire limits established. The fire limits of the city are hereby established as follows: All areas within hereafter may be zoned under class C by the ordinances or other authority of the city. 
(c)	Copies of code on file. Not less than two copies of construction codes adopted by the city shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1983, §§ 5-301—5-304; Ord. No. 460-10-04, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. 538-05-11, § 2, 5-19-2011)
 
Sec. 8-55. Adoption of existing building code.
(a)	That certain document, two copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Existing Building Code, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A and B (see International Existing Building Code section 101.7, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the existing building code of the city for regulating and governing the repair, alteration, change of occupancy, addition, and relocation of existing buildings, including historic buildings; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said existing building code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	The following sections are hereby revised: 
(1)	Section 101. These regulations shall be known as the existing building code of the city, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(2)	Section 1201. Applicability: Structures existing prior to December 16, 2004. 
(Code 1983, § 5-306; Ord. No. 456-02-05, 2-17-2005)
 
Secs. 8-56—8-83. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. PLUMBING
 
Sec. 8-84. Adoption of plumbing code.
(a)	That certain document, two copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Code Council Plumbing Code, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A through G (see International Plumbing Code section 102.5, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the plumbing code of the city for regulating and governing the construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of plumbing systems as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said plumbing code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	The following sections are hereby revised: 
(1)	Section 101.1. These regulations shall be known as the plumbing code of the city, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(2)	Section 106.6.2. The fees for work shall be as indicated in Ordinance 450-10-14. 
(3)	Section 106.6.3 Fee refunds: Not more than 50 percent of the permit fees paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. Not more than 50 percent of the plan review fee paid when an application is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended. 
(4)	Section 108.4. Persons, who shall violate a provision of this code, fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or erect, install, alter or repair work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine as provided in the city fine schedule or by imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(5)	Section 108.5. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine as provided in the city fine schedule. 
(6)	Section 305.6.1. Building sewers that connect to private sewage disposal systems shall be a minimum of six inches below finished grade at the point of septic tank connection. Building sewers shall be a minimum of four inches below grade. 
(7)	Section 904.1. All open vent pipes that extend through a roof shall be terminated at least 12 inches above the roof. 
(Code 1983, § 5-501; Ord. No. 452-02-05, 2-17-2005)
 
Sec. 8-85. Fees, permits and inspections.
No permit shall be issued for any plumbing fitting to any person other than a licensed and bonded journeyman plumber or plumbing contractor. Every plumber, before work of any kind covered by the applicable ordinances of the city, except in cases of repairing leaks inside of property lines, shall obtain a permit from the city for such work. The applicant for a permit shall pay to the city clerk an inspection fee in such amount as set by the city council by motion or resolution, a copy of which shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. If the plumbing inspector is required to make another or an additional inspection of the installation, necessitating another trip therefor, the permittee shall be required to pay the city clerk an additional sum as set by the council for additional inspection. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.1; Code 1983, § 5-502)
 
Sec. 8-86. Application for permit; issuance.
(a)	Before a plumber installs any gas fitting work, or makes additions to or alterations in existing plumbing appliances, fittings or fixtures, he shall file with the city clerk an application in writing for a permit. The application shall be made out on a form which shall be furnished by the city clerk. The following information shall appear: 
(1)	Street and house number of the premises where the plumbing work is to be done; 
(2)	Name of the owner or builder; 
(3)	Kind of building; 
(4)	A list of plumbing fixtures to be done; and 
(5)	Such other information as the plumbing inspector may reasonably require. 
(b)	The application shall be referred to the plumbing inspector who, after consideration thereof, shall issue a permit in accordance therewith if the application complies with the terms and provisions of the codes of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.2; Code 1983, § 5-503)
 
Sec. 8-87. Permits not transferable; second permits.
Permits are not transferable. The issuance of a second permit cancels a permit issued prior thereto. In the event a plumber obtains a permit for work to be performed and fails to finish it, another plumber who desires to finish the work may apply for a new permit. If after an investigation, the plumbing inspector finds that the master plumber who held or holds the original or first permit has not been diligent in performing his contract and finishing the work described in the permit, he must issue a new or another permit according to the plans and application therefor, upon the payment of the required fees for the issuance of the permit, as provided by the terms and provisions of the plumbing code. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.3; Code 1983, § 5-504)
 
Sec. 8-88. Expiration of permit.
If plumbing work under a permit is not commenced within six months after the issuance of a permit, or the work is discontinued for a period of one year from the date of the issuance thereof, the permit shall thereupon become void, and no work shall be done on the premises until a new permit is issued and all fees are paid. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.4; Code 1983, § 5-505)
 
Sec. 8-89. Plumbers' registration, fees.
No person shall practice or engage in the business, trade or occupation of a journeyman plumber, a plumbing contractor, or a plumber's apprentice unless he is registered as such with the plumbing inspector. The registration fees to be paid to the city shall be in such sums as the city council shall set by motion or resolution. 
(Code 1983, § 5-506)
 
Secs. 8-90—8-106. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. ELECTRICAL
 
Subdivision I. In General
 
Sec. 8-107. Adoption of electrical code.
(a)	That certain document, three copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Electrical Code—Administrative Provisions, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A through L (see International Electrical Code—Administrative Provisions section 102.5, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the International Electrical Code—Administrative Provisions of the city for regulating and governing the design, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of electrical systems; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said electrical code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	The following sections are hereby revised: 
(1)	Section 101.1. These regulations shall be known as the electrical code of the city, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(2)	Section 404.2. The fees for work shall be as indicated in Ordinance 450-10-14. 
(Code 1983, § 5-635; Ord. No. 450-02-05, 2-17-2005)
 
Sec. 8-108. Permit required.
(a)	No electric wiring shall be installed or altered, or changes made in existing wiring, in or on any building, without a permit being issued by the chief electrical inspector. No permit shall be issued except to a licensed electrical contractor or to a certified maintenance electrician in the employ of the owner of the building on which such electric wiring work is to be performed. Permits shall not be necessary for maintenance work or for repair work if wiring is not altered or rearranged. 
(b)	The electrical inspector may, if he deems it necessary, require or demand from the electrical contractor a set of plans and specifications of any job, in order that the electrical inspector may check them to determine if the plans and specifications comply with this division. The electrical inspector must render a decision on such plans and specifications within 24 hours after receiving them. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.16; Code 1983, § 5-612)
 
Sec. 8-109. Permits refused.
The electrical inspector has authority to refuse a permit for the installation of electric wiring as herein provided, or any additions or extensions to any electric wiring in or on any building where, in his judgment, the wiring done or proposed to be done is unsafe or not in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.17; Code 1983, § 5-613)
 
Sec. 8-110. Fees for permits.
In order to procure a permit for the installation of electric wiring, any licensed electrical contractor, before beginning any electrical work, shall make application to the city clerk and shall pay an inspection fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.18; Code 1983, § 5-614)
 
Sec. 8-111. Inspection.
(a)	The electrical inspector shall inspect all work for which permits have been issued. 
(b)	After inspecting any electric wiring, the electrical inspector shall leave notice in the form of a tag or label attached to the service entrance switch or branch cabinet. The notice shall clearly state whether the wiring is approved or is to be kept open for correction, and no person shall seal or in any manner conceal any electrical wiring until such wiring has been approved. However, it is the duty of the electrical inspector to make such partial inspection as is required to permit the continuous construction of the building. 
(c)	If, in any case, the wiring is in such a position as to interfere with the completion of the building as called for by the plans, the electrical contractor must be notified to change the same. Proper conveniences such as ladders must be provided to inspectors on work to be inspected by the firm, corporation, or individual desiring inspection. In all cases, on completion of the rough-in job, a final rough-in inspection must be called for. 
(d)	The roughing-in of each job shall include the installation of main and branch cabinets and the installation of all boxes and transformers. All rough-in wiring shall be tested, circuits made up, splices soldered or approved wire connectors used and taped, and wiring completed. From each active outlet box, one pair of wires not less than eight inches long shall be left for the fixture connection. 
(e)	A "finish" permit indicates that, upon inspection, the work will be found in condition for a service connection on final approval. The wireman who does the last work on the job shall assure himself that such a condition exists by testing each circuit, socket, and receptacle. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.19; Code 1983, § 5-615)
 
Sec. 8-112. Certificate of inspection.
(a)	On the completion of the work covered by a permit in accordance with all ordinances and laws, and after inspection and approval by the electrical inspector, the electrical inspector shall issue a certificate of inspection. In this certificate, the electrical inspector shall certify that the work is in accordance with the rules covering the respective class to which it belongs, as specified by this division. 
(b)	This certificate shall be issued to the electric service company, and shall be its authority to supply electric service to the premises. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.20; Code 1983, § 5-616)
 
Sec. 8-113. Temporary certificate.
When, for good and sufficient cause, it is necessary to have the electricity turned on at any installation before final certificate can be issued, the electrical inspector may, if the parts to which the current is applied are in a safe and satisfactory condition, issue a temporary certificate. Whenever a temporary service is installed satisfactory to the electrical inspector, the electric service company will not be permitted to make a connection to permanent service until after a final permanent certificate has been issued. Before the temporary certificate is issued, the party requesting it shall pay a fee as set by the city council by motion or resolution. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.21; Code 1983, § 5-617)
 
Sec. 8-114. Refusal of certificate.
The electrical inspector is hereby given the authority to refuse to issue a certificate of inspection for any addition or extension to any electric wiring in or on any building wherein the existing wiring is in an unsafe condition. 
(Code 1983, § 5-618)
 
Sec. 8-115. Connections by electric service companies restricted.
(a)	It is unlawful for any electric light or power company or any supplier of electricity for light, heat or power, to make any electrical connection to any building or electric wiring or apparatus until a certificate stating that the electric wiring has been approved, or written permit authorizing connection has been issued by the electrical inspector. 
(b)	All firms, corporations, or individuals, whether operating under a regular franchise granted by the city or not, shall, upon written notice by the electrical inspector, disconnect from any such circuit, including main service wires, branch feeder wires, or distribution as designated by the notice and shall not reconnect to the installation except upon written notice from the electrical inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.23; Code 1983, § 5-619)
 
Sec. 8-116. Defective workmanship or materials.
Any person engaged in the business of electrical construction and the installation of wiring and apparatus for electric light, heat, or power in the city who fails to correct promptly any defect in any work done by him contrary to this division, after having been notified thereof by the electrical inspector, shall not be issued any further permits until such defect has been corrected. In any case in which any person continues to violate or persistently violates the ordinances of the city in regard to electrical work or the orders of the electrical inspector in relation to the same, the license of such person shall be suspended or revoked. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.24; Code 1983, § 5-620)
 
Sec. 8-117. Fire, storm, or emergency.
Every person owning or controlling electrical wires and apparatus for the transmission of light, heat, or power shall, in time of fire or in case of a severe storm or any other emergency wherein lives or property of the citizens of the city may be endangered by the operation of such wires and apparatus, upon notice by the electrical inspector, the mayor, city manager, the chief of the fire department, or chief of police, disconnect such dangerous wires from current or service as are designated by the official. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.25; Code 1983, § 5-621)
 
Sec. 8-118. Poles, wires, and cables.
(a)	The placing, stringing, or attaching of telegraph, telephone, electric light, or other wires and cables, and the placing of all poles and appliances shall be done in accordance with the provisions of the National Electrical Safety Code, the National Electrical Code, and the Oklahoma Corporation Commission's orders, so as to prevent fires, accidents, or injury to persons or property. 
(b)	The electrical inspector shall notify the telephone, telegraph, or electric service companies of any such poles, wires, cables, or apparatus so placed as not to meet the requirements of the National Electrical Safety Code, the National Electrical Code, and the Oklahoma Corporation Commission's orders. All such wires, lights, cables, poles, and electrical apparatus now existing, as well as those hereafter constructed and placed, shall be maintained to meet the same requirements. 
(c)	The telephone, telegraph, or electric service company shall have a reasonable time in which to correct such conditions after being so notified by the electrical inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.26; Code 1983, § 5-622)
 
Sec. 8-119. Relocated buildings.
When a building or portion of a building containing electric wiring is moved from its foundation, the owner shall have the electric wiring and equipment in the building inspected and repaired and, where necessary, provide proper grounding wires, etc. The electrical contractor shall obtain a wiring permit and request inspection. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.27; Code 1983, § 5-623)
 
Sec. 8-120. Inspection no relief from responsibility.
This division shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibilities of any person, partnership, or corporation owning, operating, or installing electric wires, appliances, apparatus, construction, or equipment, for the damage to property or person injured by any defect therein. Nor shall the city or any agent thereof be deemed to assume any such liability by reason of the inspection issued by the electrical inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.28; Code 1983, § 5-624)
 
Sec. 8-121. Exceptions; communication companies; electric utilities.
The provisions of this division shall not be construed as affecting or applying to any work done by or for any telephone, telegraph, or other communication company in the installation, repair, or maintenance of wiring or other electrical apparatus, equipment, or device to be used exclusively in connection with its business, or as applying to any work done by or for any public utility electric service company operating under a franchise from the city or any central station powerhouse, substation, shop, or device belonging to such service company and used exclusively in the operation of its business. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.29; Code 1983, § 5-625)
 
Sec. 8-122. Service connection from overhead supply system.
A standard overhead service connection consisting of one span extending from the electric service company's supply system to the conductor support at the point of delivery on the building wall or other structure belonging to the property shall be supplied by the electric service company. All other service conductors, raceways, and facilities, except measuring devices belonging to and installed by the service company, shall be supplied and installed by the owner of the premises as a part of the electric wiring of the premises being served. The installation of electrical equipment covered in this division shall conform to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)	The point of delivery will be designated by the electric service company, and shall be at least ten feet, but not more than 25 feet, above the ground, and so located that adequate clearance from buildings and trees will be provided for the overhead service connection; 
(2)	The contractor shall provide adequate structural support for the attachment of the service-terminating device. The minimum size conduit for mast-type service shall be 1½-inch rigid galvanized steel conduit, and shall be installed in accordance with the electric service company's recommendations; 
(3)	If the service connection is attached to a structure constructed of materials other than wood, the contractor shall install a service rack, which shall be furnished by the electric company; 
(4)	Where an existing building or new building interferes with adequate clearance for the standard overhead service connection to another building, the service outlet shall be extended in conduit from such other building to the wall of the building or structure located most conveniently for connection to the electric service company's supply system, and all meters for the premises shall be grouped at such point of delivery; 
(5)	At locations where originally platted lots have been subdivided in such a manner that a serviced connection cannot be completed from the established utility reserve without crossing other property, the service connection must be extended in conduit so as to provide a point of delivery available to the electric supply system; 
(6)	Service entrance conductors shall be carried in an approved metal raceway. The raceway shall terminate on the exterior of the building at a point at least six inches above the point of delivery. The service entrance conductors shall extend not less than 30 inches beyond termination of the raceway. No service entrance conductor shall be smaller than number three AWG; 
(7)	All lighting and power installations shall be designed for a three-wire or a four-wire connection, corresponding to the type of distribution system established for the area; 
(8)	When a service entrance or any part of it is installed underground, it must be terminated on a support adequate for attachment of the standard overhead service connection. There shall be a weatherproof fused disconnect and meter mounting located six feet above the ground on such support.
