The electric service company's pole shall not be used for the support of the service entrance or meter; 
(9)	No overhead service to or between school buildings shall be permitted; and 
(10)	For voltages above 600 volts, the plans for service entrance and point of delivery must be approved by the electrical inspector and the electric service company before the permit is issued. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.30; Code 1983, § 5-626)
 
Sec. 8-123. Service connections from underground network distribution systems.
Standard electric service connections from an underground supply system shall be installed by the electric service company operating under franchise from the city. All other service conductors and facilities, except meters, transformers, and related equipment installed by the electric service company, shall be installed and maintained by the owner of the premises as a part of the electric wiring of the premises or buildings being served. The installation of electrical equipment covered in this section shall conform to the following rules and regulations: 
(1)	When service boxes are used as the terminating device for service connections, such boxes, not exceeding one box to each 50 feet of the property line, will be furnished and installed by the electric service company on the property line of the premises being served; 
(2)	If transformers are required on the premises, they shall be installed in a vault provided by the owner. The contractor shall extend and terminate the service entrance bus inside the vault wall. The length and type of termination shall be approved by the electric service company; 
(3)	The point of delivery shall be the service box when this type of service connection termination is used; and where a transformer vault is installed, the point of delivery shall be the point at which the service entrance bus terminates; 
(4)	Service entrance conductors between the point of delivery and the main disconnect device shall be furnished as a part of the electric wiring of the premises by the owner. If the main line disconnect is rated at 400 amperes or above, its interrupting capacity must be approved by the electrical inspector before being installed; 
(5)	When new buildings are being wired or the wiring changed in old buildings in the underground network area, the service entrances and building distribution system shall be designed and installed to conform to the type of service available in the area; and 
(6)	Commercial buildings shall be provided with service and distribution equipment arranged for three or four wires, 100 amperes capacity as a minimum. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.31; Code 1983, § 5-627)
 
Sec. 8-124. Meters and associated equipment.
All meters and related electrical equipment furnished and installed by the electric service company shall be installed subject to and in compliance with the following conditions, rules, and requirements: 
(1)	Outdoor meters shall be installed so that the top of the meter will not be more than six feet six inches nor less than five feet six inches above the ground; 
(2)	A meter board of soft lumber and of suitable dimensions for mounting the meter and cabinet shall be provided as a part of the rough-in job. It shall be located near the service entrance on a wall or structure free of excessive vibration and readily accessible at all reasonable hours; 
(3)	Outdoor metering installations shall be installed in all new or remodeled buildings whose service is to be supplied from an overhead electricity supply system through a single meter, and when the load does not exceed 100 amperes, single phase. Such meters shall be installed in the service entrance raceway on the outside of the building, and on the supply side of the service disconnect device. The electric service company shall provide an approved meter cabinet or socket for such installations, which shall be installed as a part of the service entrance by the electrical contractor. Outdoor metering installation shall be in a protected area and not on walls adjacent to passageways along which traffic may move; 
(4)	Each set of service entrance conductors shall be provided with a safety-type fused switch or circuit breaker, which shall be accessible to the occupants of the premises being serviced and be of ample capacity to carry and to interrupt the connected load; 
(5)	Where meters are installed outside of main buildings, branch panel cabinets shall be placed inside the buildings where they will be readily accessible to the occupants; 
(6)	Circuit breakers approved for branch circuit protection shall be installed on all new or remodeled old wiring installations for lighting circuits. No circuit breaker panels shall be installed in bathrooms. Breakers must be in place when the electrical inspector makes the final inspection. All circuit breaker panels and breakers shall be of the noninterchangeable type; 
(7)	All metering installations on electricity supply systems rated above 240 volts and those designed for a capacity over 200 amperes require instrument transformers; and for installations of this type, approved metal cabinets of sufficient size to enclose the instrument transformer cabinet and meters shall be furnished and installed by the contractor as a part of the wiring. The plans and specifications of such installations must be approved by the electrical inspector and the electric service company before the cabinets are installed; and 
(8)	Under no circumstances shall any meter be moved or relocated except by authorized employees of the electric service company. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.32; Code 1983, § 5-628)
 
Sec. 8-125. Wiring methods.
All electric wiring hereafter installed in or on any building, structure, or premises located within the city shall be installed by the use of one or more of the following approved wiring methods: 
(1)	All wiring shall be installed in rigid galvanized conduit, both on the interior and exterior of all buildings, below ground and in concrete slabs. The exceptions to this are listed below. (See subsection (6) of this section, concerning aluminum rigid conduit.) 
(2)	All connectors and couplings must be of an approved type. E.M.T. shall be bent with an approved type of wheel bender. One-half, three-fourths, and one inch E.M.T. only are permitted in the following locations: 
a.	Residences. On the exterior and above the slab; 
b.	Apartment houses, motels, duplexes, and similar type dwelling units. On the interior and above the slab; and 
c.	Commercial buildings. E.M.T. may be used in commercial or industrial buildings provided all of the following conditions are met: 
1.	No portion of the building or equipment is classed as hazardous (service stations, etc.); 
2.	Complies with National Electrical Code; and 
3.	On the interior and above the slab. 
(3)	Surface metal raceways shall not be concealed by any portion of the building, structure, or finish except to extend horizontally through a wall. 
(4)	Flexible metal conduit shall be used as follows: 
a.	Flexible terminations of rigid raceways; 
b.	Where the installation of a rigid raceway would damage the building; 
c.	Three-eighths inch is permitted only in lengths up to 48 inches, and shall contain no more than two number 12 AWG or its equivalent; 
d.	In moist locations or in the interior of buildings, it shall be of the neo prime type with approved weather-tight connectors; 
e.	Where permitted by the National Electrical Code as related to hazardous locations; or 
f.	When required in service runs, a minimum number six AWG bare or green insulated bonding jumpers shall be installed. This shall be suitably terminated at each end. 
(5)	The following apply to non-metallic sheathed cable: 
a.	Non-metallic sheathed cable may be used in single-family residential structures only. In no case will it be permitted in commercial buildings, schools, churches, or any other public buildings. 
b.	Non-metallic sheathed cable may be used in normally dry locations. It may be run or fished in air voids in masonry block walls, where such walls are not exposed to or subject to excessive moisture or dampness. Non-metallic sheathed cable shall not be installed where imbedded in masonry, concrete fill, or plaster; nor run in shallow chase in masonry or concrete and covered with plaster or similar finish. 
c.	Non-metallic sheathed cable in attics or roof spaces shall be secured by approved staples, straps, or similar fittings so designed and installed as not to injure the cable. Cable shall be secured in place at intervals not exceeding 4½ feet and within eight inches from every outlet box or fitting except in concealed work in finished buildings where such supporting is impractical, the cable may be fished from outlet to outlet. 
d.	Non-metallic cable in attics or roof spaces used for storage shall be run as follows: If run across the top of ceiling joists, the cable shall be protected by guard strips at least as high as the cable, unless the cable is run within 24 inches of the outside wall or where there is less than 18 inches of space between the ceiling joists and the rafters, or if the cable is run along the sides of rafters or joists or through holes bored through the rafters or joists. 
e.	If the cable is run at angle joists in unfinished basements, it shall be run through bored holes in the joists or run on running boards; where run parallel to the joists, cable shall be secured to the sides of the joists. 
f.	Grounding rules. 
1.	The cable shall contain a grounding conductor. The grounding conductor shall be secured to every metallic box by means of a grounding screw or approved grounding clip, which shall be used for no other purpose, or shall be connected to the wiring device where a screw for that purpose has been provided by the manufacturer; 
2.	The grounding conductor shall enter into every non-metallic outlet box in such a manner that it can be connected to any fitting or device that may require grounding; 
3.	Where more than one grounding conductor enters a box, all such conductors shall be in good electrical contact with each other by means of securing all conductors under grounding screws, or by connecting them together with an acceptable solderless connector and connecting one conductor only to the box by a grounding screw or an approved grounding device; and the arrangement shall be such that the disconnection or removal of a receptacle, fixture, or other device fed from the box will not interfere with or interrupt the ground continuity; 
4.	Grounding conductors, when run separately from the cable, shall be installed in the same manner as the cable, and shall not be smaller than number 14 AWG; 
5.	Electric ranges, ovens, and electric dryers may be grounded to the neutral conductor if it is the same size as the largest circuit conductor, but in no circumstances shall it be smaller than number ten AWG; 
6.	All receptacle outlet devices installed shall be of the grounding type designed to accept parallel blades and U-shaped grounding blade. 
(6)	Aluminum rigid conduit may be used as rigid conduit provided it meets the following requirements: 
a.	It shall not be installed in concrete slabs, or in contact with soil known to have an adverse effect on its life; 
b.	It shall not be used as a service mast; 
c.	No bare copper conductors or copper alloyed fittings are to be used with or come in contact with aluminum conduit; 
d.	It shall not be installed in locations subject to abuse; 
e.	All threaded joints are to be treated with a compound to prevent joint seizure; and 
f.	It shall not to be used in hazardous locations. 
(7)	All non-metallic underground conduits shall be installed in a minimum concrete envelope of three inches. A grounding or bonding conductor shall be installed in all ducts carrying conductors in excess of 100 volts above ground. 
(8)	Other conduits shall meet the following requirements: 
a.	All other conduits (bus-duct, floor ducts, wireways, etc.) shall be of a type approved for the installation and installed in accordance with the manufacturer's recommendations; and 
b.	Before starting or installation of any of these types of wiring, plans and specifications must be submitted to the electrical inspector for approval, and special permission, in writing, must be obtained before starting the job. 
(9)	Overhead feeders between buildings shall be dead ended at both ends on insulators, and when intermediate supports are required, the conductors must be supported on approved insulators, and such conductors shall be weatherproof and not smaller than number ten AWG. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.33; Code 1983, § 5-629)
 
Sec. 8-126. Conduits, raceways, and fittings.
(a)	In buildings, runs of conduit looped over wooden joists shall be so installed that they will not be more than four inches above a two-inch by four-inch joist or two inches above a two-inch by six-inch joist. They shall be blocked and strapped not more than 12 inches from the outlet, and blocked and strapped every additional six feet or less thereafter. 
(b)	In buildings where it is necessary to place conduits on the lower edges of wooded ceiling joists, the joists shall not be notched to a depth greater than one-fifth of the depth of the joists, nor at a distance of more than 18 inches from a supporting wall; except that, where joists are supported at points not more than four feet apart, notches not deeper than three-fourths inch may be cut. 
(c)	To reduce corrosion, the joining of dissimilar metals shall be avoided whenever possible. 
(d)	All conduit connections of cabinets, outlet boxes, and all other equipment shall, in addition to the end bushing, be provided with two lock nuts, one inside and one outside the fitting opening. All bushings shall be of the fiber or insulating type. 
(e)	Unused openings in cabinets, outlet boxes, and other equipment shall be effectively closed by the use of metal plugs or plates, affording protector equivalent to that of the material of the fittings. 
(f)	Metal conduit and tubing shall be installed so as to provide adequate drainage. 
(g)	Outlet boxes in concrete slabs and columns shall not be less than 2 ⅛inches deep. Conduit placed in concrete slabs shall be laid above the bottom layer of reinforcing steel in order to provide ample clearance from forms and to ensure fireproofing of wires and strength of structure. 
(h)	Conduit runs on the exteriors of buildings or structures shall be equipped with watertight fittings. 
(i)	In wood building construction, where two or more switch boxes are ganged between studs, they shall be adequately supported. 
(j)	Boxes enclosing flush devices shall be of sufficient size to allow 2½ inches of space for the device after the required space has been allowed for the wires pulled in or through the box. 
(k)	Lights in bathrooms, kitchens, and open porches shall be controlled by wall switches. 
(l)	Lights in clothes closets shall be installed in the ceiling or over the door of the clothes closet and controlled by a switch located in the wall or door jam. 
(m)	Pull-chain lamp holders or switches over concrete floors or near any grounded object shall have an insulating link installed in the pull chain. The uninsulated portion of the pull chain must be at least seven feet from the floor. 
(n)	All drops shall be reinforced cord or equal. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.34; Code 1983, § 5-630)
 
Sec. 8-127. Wiring capacity.
(a)	All residences shall be provided with a minimum service entrance capacity of three, number three RH or equivalent in 1¼-inch conduit. 
(b)	Minimum conductor size for branch circuit wiring shall be number 12. 
(c)	All installations shall be provided with a minimum availability of 12 circuits and a main disconnect. 
(d)	From each branch circuit panel, at least one three-fourths-inch empty conduit shall be stubbed into an accessible location for future use, or circuits shall be made accessible by other means. 
(e)	Not more than eight outlets shall be installed on one circuit excepting utility circuits. No convenience outlet shall be installed other than that of the grounding type. 
(f)	Utility circuits shall consist of receptacles in kitchens, dining rooms, breakfast rooms, and utility rooms. No lights may be connected to utility circuits. A maximum of four outlets are permitted on utility circuits, and each residence must contain at least two utility circuits. 
(g)	The number and requirements for outlets are as follows: 
(1)	In every kitchen, dining room, breakfast room, living room, parlor, library, den, sun room, recreation room, and bedroom receptacle outlets shall be installed so that no point along the floor line in any usable wall space is more than six feet, measured horizontally, from an outlet in that space including any unusable wall space two feet wide or greater and the wall space occupied by sliding panels in exterior walls. The receptacle outlets shall be spaced an equal distance apart or as nearly so as practicable; 
(2)	Hallways and passageways shall have a minimum of one receptacle when the gross distance around the hall or passageway measured horizontally along at the floor line meets or exceeds two linear feet; and 
(3)	Kitchens, dining rooms, breakfast rooms, and utility rooms shall have a minimum of two circuits with a maximum of four outlets per circuit. Separate dining rooms and separate utility rooms shall have a minimum of two receptacles in each room, and shall be installed on the utility circuit. Dishwasher and laundry outlets shall be classified as special circuits, and shall not be installed on required utility circuits. 
(h)	All receptacles installed on utility circuits shall be parallel blade with a U-shaped grounding slot. 
(i)	All room spaces planned or arranged for use as retail stores, offices, theaters, schools, hospitals, display rooms, beauty parlors, cafes, barber shops, churches, hotels, and all buildings where the public is to be served or where there will be public assembly shall have installed sufficient outlets and wiring capacities to provide not less than five watts per square foot for general illumination. 
(j)	A form of emergency lighting shall be provided in all public buildings, of a type that, on the failure of the normal power source, will provide sufficient lighting to gain exit from the place of gathering to the exterior of the building. This source shall come on automatically and remain on for a sufficient length of time. This does not apply to buildings normally occupied during the daylight hours that are not totally absent from natural light. 
(k)	In show windows, where wiring is brought to the terminals of sockets and receptacles through conduit raceway, special types of tubing, or metal strip, such wire, extending from the fitting terminals back to the first outlet or junction box, shall be of the slow-burning or asbestos-covered type. 
(l)	In beauty parlors, where appliances are connected to receptacles through cords and attachment plugs, one receptacle shall be allowed on 15 ampere circuits, or two receptacles on a 25 ampere circuit. 
(m)	In all gasoline service station pump stands, explosion-proof fittings shall be used in the pump stands, and where such motors will not be larger than one-third horsepower, one pair of number 12 wires may be used to feed such motors in groups as follows: 
(1)	If operating at 115 volts, three motors; 
(2)	If operating at 230 volts, five motors; and 
(3)	Not more than one raceway shall enter a gasoline dispensing pump stand. 
(n)	In all rooms designed or arranged for use as retail stores or display rooms, and fronting on a street, avenue, or public highway, one receptacle circuit shall be provided for each window. 
(o)	All stationary electric heating units of 1,000 watts or more shall be on a special circuit. All electric heating installed shall have thermal protection installed that will cut the power if the air flow is obstructed. All wiring installed within baseboard-type electric heating units shall be asbestos covered. All baseboard heating incorporated convenience outlet devices shall be wired with three wire circuits, and shall be grounded in accordance with the city's building regulations where wired with nonmetallic sheathed cable. Heating panels shall not be installed directly on concrete block walls or floors and must have a minimum of clearance one-eighth inch from walls three-fourths-inch from floor from this type of construction. Electric heating devices shall be protected at not more than 125 percent their rated capacity. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.35; Code 1983, § 5-631)
 
Sec. 8-128. Low-voltage, signal, and control circuits.
(a)	All concealed wires for door bells and other signal circuits shall be rubber or type TW, covered and braided, and not smaller than number 18 AWG. 
(b)	Door-bell wiring, furnace and heater control, and other low-voltage signal wiring shall be set up complete with the roughing-in of all lighting wiring. 
(c)	Signal wiring shall be installed so that the step down transformers are mounted in approved metal boxes and in accessible locations, preferably near the equipment that is to be controlled. If such transformers are located under a floor where there is no basement, a switch must be provided. 
(d)	The transformer wiring for door bells, chimes, and push or control buttons is considered to be a part of the roughing-in work. 
(e)	All low-voltage signal and control circuits may be installed without conduit protection except in concrete slabs, underground, or where exposed to weather or mechanical damage, or in hazardous locations. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.36; Code 1983, § 5-632)
 
Sec. 8-129. Remodeling installations.
(a)	The service entrance wiring shall be construed as being that part of the wiring system extending from the service company's wires up to and including the main switch, circuit breaker, or branch circuit distribution cabinet. When any part of the service entrance wiring is changed, moved, or rearranged, the service in its entirety shall be changed so as to comply with the National Electrical Code now in effect and the requirements of this division. 
(b)	If finished walls would be damaged by making the change over, metal distribution cabinets in good condition may be left in operation. 
(c)	All neutral wires must be placed on a common bus bar, eliminating fuse in neutral wire. 
(d)	Cabinets for less than four circuits may be arranged to not more than four circuits provided same can be done safely and in a neat mechanical manner. Neutral wires in such cabinets may be jointed together in a common joint if limited space prohibits mounting a bus bar. 
(e)	All cabinets made of wood must be replaced with metal cabinets. Service conductors and main feeders, if they are not moved, may remain as they are, provided they are large enough to meet the requirements of the National Electrical Code. 
(f)	Approved circuit breakers, approved for branch circuit protection, shall be installed where the old wiring is not of the metal-raceway method and the old wiring is not disturbed. 
(g)	The electrical inspector shall require the installation of nontamperable type over-current device on existing circuits which are protected with plug fuses whenever the actual connected load on the circuit exceeds the maximum ampere rating of the circuit or wherever there exists evidence of willful overfusing or fuse tampering. 
(h)	If as much as 30 percent of a job is being remodeled, the building must be rewired completely according to the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 5-633)
 
Sec. 8-130. Motors.
(a)	Before a motor installation is made, approval must be secured from the electrical inspector and the electric service company as to the voltage and phase available at the location. 
(b)	Motor protection and control equipment shall conform to the provisions of the National Electrical Code, but with this further requirement; a low voltage motor of the plug in type of not more than one-third horsepower may be connected by cord and attachment plug into a circuit having an overcurrent protection of not more than 15 amperes. Low voltage motors of more than one-third horsepower and less than one horsepower shall be connected through safety type switches which open all ungrounded conductors. Low voltage motors from one to five horsepower, inclusive, and which require starting and running overload current protection, shall be provided with either externally operated motor starting switches of the type which does not open the circuit when passing from the starting to the running position, or starters of the thermal relay type. Motors of more than 50 horsepower shall be provided with autotransformer or compensator type starters or other approved current limiting devices. 
(c)	The sizes of branch circuit conductors for individual squirrel cage motors shall be as indicated in table numbers 1 to 4 inclusive. All other types shall follow the rate covered in the National Electrical Code. (See code book for tables 1 to 4 inclusive.) 
(d)	Feeder conductors supplying a group of two or more motors and service entrance conductors and metering equipment shall have a current carrying capacity of not less than the sum of the starting current of the largest motor plus the full load running current of the other motors in the group or system. Where a number of motors of equal horsepower rating are the largest in the group, one of these motors shall be considered as the largest for the above calculations. Where two or more motors of a group must be started simultaneously, it will be necessary to use the starting current of all such motors if they are the largest in the group, or all but one of such motors if they are of smaller ratings, for the above calculations. Table numbers 1 to 4 show the approved sizes of overcurrent protection to be used. The setting of branch circuit breakers and group feeder circuit breakers shall comply with the rules contained in the National Electrical Code. 
(e)	Large motors shall be provided with starting devices to meet the following requirements: 
(1)	Where the user's demand, including the proposed installation is 100 kVA, the maximum permissible starting current of a single motor or group of motors starting simultaneously shall not exceed 200 amperes; 
(2)	Where the user's demand, including the proposed installation, is greater than 100 kVA, the maximum permissible starting current of a single motor or group of motors starting simultaneously shall not exceed 200 amperes, plus one ampere for each kVA of demand in excess of 100 kVA and in no case shall the total exceed 1,000 amperes; 
(3)	Motors with starting currents in excess of the values given above shall be started by increment starting devices. The current increments must not exceed the values stated above, and the time interval shall not be less than one-half second between current increments. The circuit shall not be opened during the starting interval. 
(f)	Stationary motors exceeding one-half horsepower shall have a disconnecting means placed within sight of the motor, and shall not be located more than 15 feet from the motor location. 
(g)	All control wiring shall be protected and shall not be fused in excess of 20 amperes unless the current carrying capacity of the conductor is as large as the maximum overcurrent devices. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.36; Code 1983, § 5-634)
 
Sec. 8-131. Sealing of service cabinets.
It is unlawful for any person other than an authorized employee of the electric service company, the electrical inspector, or authorized member of the fire department to break any seal of any electric meter, transformer, or cabinet. In case of emergency, an authorized employee of a licensed electrical contractor may break a seal when necessary to replace fuses. In all such cases, the electric service company must be notified by the party breaking the seal within 24 hours, in order that the equipment may be resealed. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.41; Code 1983, § 5-636)
 
Sec. 8-132. Covering or concealing switches or outlets.
It is unlawful for any plasterer, carpenter, or other workman to cover or conceal with plaster, building board, or any other material, any switch or other electrical outlet. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.42; Code 1983, § 5-637)
 
Secs. 8-133—8-162. Reserved.
 
Subdivision II. Contractors
 
Sec. 8-163. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this subdivision, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Apprentice electrician means any person who is learning the electric wiring trade and who is competent to assist under the supervision of a journeyman wireman in the work of installing or repairing electric wiring or installing nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus. 
Electrical contractor means any person engaged in the business of installing, repairing, or altering electric wiring or nonportable electric fixtures or apparatus in the city and who has complied with the terms of this subdivision. 
Electrical inspector means the chief electrical inspector of the city or any of his duly authorized assistants. 
Electrical wiring means the installation of electric raceways, conductors, or apparatus of any kind used, or to be used, in or on any building for the transmission and distribution of electric current for electric light, heat, or power, or nonportable electrical fixtures and apparatus of any nature to be connected to light, heat, or power services. The terms "electrical wiring," "electrical equipment," and "apparatus" do not include service lines, apparatus, and equipment for the sale, distribution, and regulation of electricity and remaining the property of the electric service company, or for telephone, telegraph, or other communication purposes, or in connection therewith. 
General maintenance electrician means any person accomplishing limited electrical maintenance in any building or factory. Limited electrical maintenance includes replacement of switches, breakers, fuses, and light bulbs; it does not include additions to or alterations of existing wiring. 
Journeyman electrician means any person qualified under the provisions of this subdivision to engage in the installing or repairing of electric wiring or installing nonportable electrical fixtures or apparatus in the city and who has complied with the terms of this subdivision. 
Maintenance electrician means any person engaged only in the work of operating, caring for, and maintaining the electrical installation of any building or factory. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.1; Code 1983, § 5-601)
 
Sec. 8-164. Electrical inspector; assistants.
There is hereby created the office of chief electrical inspector in the inspection division of the public works department. The chief electrical inspector shall be appointed by the city manager. He shall have had at least five years' practical experience as a journeyman wireman. He shall not be interested directly or indirectly in any way with any electrical contractor engaged in the electrical business or electrical supply business in the city or in any electrical work performed therein. The city manager may appoint such assistant electrical inspectors as may be necessary, who shall have the same qualifications as the chief electrical inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.2; Code 1983, § 5-602)
 
Sec. 8-165. Duties of electrical inspector.
(a)	The electrical inspector shall be charged with the duty of enforcing all the ordinances of the city relating to electrical wiring and the construction, installation, repair, alteration, and maintenance of electric wiring, apparatus, and fixtures, and the inspection of the same. The electrical inspector shall have the power to inspect or reinspect all overhead, underground, and interior wires and apparatus conducting electrical current for any of the purposes set forth in the electrical ordinances of the city. 
(b)	When such conductors or apparatus are found to be unsafe to life or property, he shall notify the person owning, using, or operating the same to place them in a safe condition within 48 hours. If the owner, user, or operator of such defective wiring or equipment refuses or fails to comply with the requirements of the electrical inspector and to correct all the defects as directed within the specified time, the electrical inspector shall notify, in writing, the service company, firm, or individual furnishing the electric current to such defective wiring or equipment to cease to supply electric current to same. Upon receipt of such notice, the service company, firm, or individual furnishing electric current to the defective wiring or equipment shall, within 24 hours, disconnect the service or feed wires and cease to supply current to the defective installation until the defects have been corrected. 
(c)	When any portion or all of the wiring in or on any building or premises is ordered changed for any reason, the electrical inspector shall leave attached to the main switch or service equipment a tag or label showing the date of the order and a memorandum of the correction to be made, and the signature of the authority making the order. 
(d)	The electrical inspector, in the discharge of his duties, may enter any building or premises at any time during business hours or at any reasonable hour. Upon the refusal of any owner, agent, or occupant to allow such inspection as required by the electrical inspector, he shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(e)	The electrical inspector shall also institute or cause to be instituted, by and with the advice of the city attorney, such prosecutions as may be necessary against any violators of any ordinance with the enforcement of which he is charged. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.3; Code 1983, § 5-603)
 
Sec. 8-166. Appeals.
An appeal may be taken to the board of appeals specified in the BOCA Building Code from any ruling, interpretation, requirement, or decision made by the electrical inspector by filing with the city clerk within five days from the ruling, interpretation, requirement, or decision, a statement in writing showing wherein the electrical inspector is alleged to have been wrong. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.4; Code 1983, § 5-604; Ord. No. 291-A, 3-22-1984)
 
Sec. 8-167. Journeymen electrician; apprentices.
(a)	No person shall work as a journeyman electrician in the city unless he possesses a state license and is registered with the city, upon payment of fees provided in the city fee schedule, has secured a registration certificate and works under the direct supervision of a licensed electrical contractor. 
(b)	Apprentice electricians shall be allowed to work without registering with the city if they work under the direct and personal supervision of a journeyman electrician on the job. No journeyman electrician will have more than one apprentice wireman under his supervision at any time. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.6; Code 1983, § 5-605)
 
Sec. 8-168. Maintenance and general maintenance electricians; certificate and registration necessary.
(a)	No person may engage in the occupation of maintenance electrician without first being registered with the chief electrical inspector of the city by the owner of the building or by the authorized representative of such owner, and without first having a state license and paying the fees required for such occupation as provided in this subdivision. Such registration shall show the name of the employer and the place of employment, and shall certify that the maintenance electrician named is a regular employee giving his full time to this employer's service. 
(b)	No person shall engage in the occupation of general maintenance electrician without being registered with the owner of the building, or by the authorized representative of such owner, and without first having a state license and paying the fees required for such occupation as provided in the city fee schedule. Such registration must show the name of the employer, the place of employment, and certify that the general maintenance electrician named is a regular employee giving his full time to this employer's service. 
(c)	A registration certificate issued to a maintenance electrician shall lapse when he leaves the employment under which he is registered, and the license shall not authorize the maintenance electrician to do electric wiring in or upon any building other than that named in his registration. The owner of a building may in person, or by an authorized agent, add under the registration of a maintenance electrician the name or location of any other building which may come under the control of the owner. Such license shall not authorize or permit the maintenance electrician to do any electrical wiring or other electrical work in any house or building that is used or designed solely as a place of residence for less than three families. 
(d)	The registration certificate of a general maintenance electrician shall lapse on the termination of the employment for which it is registered. 
(Prior Code, §§ 5-3.8, 5-3.9; Code 1983, § 5-606)
 
Sec. 8-169. Electrical contractors.
No person shall engage in the business of installing, repairing, or altering electric wiring or installing nonportable electrical fixtures or apparatus within the city and no partnership, firm, or corporation shall engage in the business of installing, repairing, or altering electric wiring or installing nonportable electrical fixtures or apparatus within the city, unless and until such person, or in the case of a partnership, firm, or corporation, either an official, partner, or employee, possesses the state electrical contractor's license and is registered as provided in this subdivision. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.10; Code 1983, § 5-607)
 
Sec. 8-170. Contractors issuance of registration certificate.
(a)	An applicant who possesses a state license shall, upon: 
(1)	Providing a copy of the license to the city clerk; 
(2)	Paying the prescribed fees; and 
(3)	Filing the bond as provided herein; 
Receive a certificate of registration from the city clerk. 
(b)	If the electrical contractor associated with any partnership, firm, or corporation, under the provisions of section 8-169, resigns, withdraws from or is discharged from such partnership, firm, or corporation, then such partnership, firm, or corporation shall not engage in business for a longer period than ten days without compliance with section 8-169. 
(c)	An electrical contractor's certificate shall not permit the holder thereof personally to install or alter electric wiring unless he also holds a journeyman electrician's license. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.11; Code 1983, § 5-608)
 
Sec. 8-171. Fees; expiration date.
(a)	The fees for initial and renewal registration shall be as set by the council by motion or resolution for journeyman or maintenance and electrical contractors. 
(b)	All certificates provided herein shall expire on June 30 following the date of issue, and no reduction for partial year shall be made. 
(c)	Any certificates renewed within 90 days may be renewed at a renewal fee as set by the council. Licenses renewed after 90 days but less than 180 days will be at a higher rate as set by the council. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.13; Code 1983, § 5-609)
State law reference(s)—State licensing of electricians, city powers to require registration, 59 O.S. § 1680 et seq. 
 
Sec. 8-172. Transfer of certificate.
It is unlawful for any person holding a certificate to transfer it or allow the use of it, directly or indirectly, by any other person for the purpose of obtaining a permit to do any of the electrical work herein specified. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.14; Code 1983, § 5-610)
 
Sec. 8-173. Bond for electrical contractor.
An applicant for electrical contractor's registration shall execute a bond, which he shall renew annually, in the sum of $2,000.00 in favor of the city. The bond shall be conditioned for the faithful and proper conduct of the registrant's business in compliance with all ordinances of the city relating to electric wiring and all rules and regulations made thereunder, and for the protection and indemnification of the city against all damages resulting from or in any way growing out of an injury received by anyone on account of the negligence or unskilled work on the part of such licensee. The surety on such bond shall be a surety company authorized by the state. 
(Prior Code, § 9-3.15; Code 1983, § 5-611)
 
Secs. 8-174—8-199. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. GAS APPLIANCES AND GAS PIPING
 
Sec. 8-200. Purpose and scope.
The purpose of this division is to provide minimum standards, provisions, and requirements for safe installation of gas appliances and gas pipes designed and intended to be employed by gas consumers in conveying natural gas to and utilizing the same in buildings, and to regulate the sale, maintenance, and repair of such gas appliances. All such gas appliances or gas pipes to be utilized in connection therewith that are hereafter sold, installed, maintained, or repaired shall conform to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 9-5.1; Code 1983, § 5-701)
 
Sec. 8-201. Adoption of fuel gas code.
(a)	That certain document, two copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as International Fuel Gas Code, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A through L (see International Fuel Gas Code section 102.5, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the international fuel gas code of the city for regulating and governing the fuel gas systems and gas fired appliances; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said fuel gas code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)	The following sections are hereby revised: 
(1)	Section 101.1. These regulations shall be known as the fuel gas code of the city hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(2)	Section 106.5.2. The fees for work shall be as indicated in Ordinance 450-10-14. 
(3)	Section 106.5.3. Fee refunds. Not more than 50 percent of the permit fee paid when no work has been done under a permit issued in accordance with this code. Not more than 50 percent of the plan review fee paid when an application is withdrawn or canceled before any plan review effort has been expended. 
(4)	Section 108.4. Persons, who shall violate a provision of this code, fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or erect, install, alter or repair work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine as provided in the city fine schedule or by imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(5)	Section 108.5. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine as provided in the city fine schedule. 
(Code 1983, § 5-704; Ord. No. 454-02-05, 2-17-2005)
 
Sec. 8-202. Application; premises.
This division shall apply to all buildings and consumer premises that are served by or connected to the city water distribution or sewerage system. 
(Prior Code, § 9-5.2; Code 1983, § 5-702)
 
Sec. 8-203. Application; kinds of installations.
These requirements apply to gas piping systems extending from the point of delivery to the inlet connections of appliances, and the installation and operation of residential and commercial gas appliances. They are intended to cover the design, fabrication, installation, tests, and operation of systems distributing natural gas. They are not intended to cover systems or portions of systems supplying equipment engineered, designed, and installed for specific manufacturing, production, processing, and power generating applications, such as large and high pressure boilers, melting and treating furnaces, production ovens, etc., or for public utility piping in gas distribution and transmission systems, in gas compressing stations, and in gas processing plants. 
(Prior Code, § 9-5.3; Code 1983, § 5-703)
 
Sec. 8-204. Inspector; certificate, licenses, and permits; fee.
All inspections required by this division shall be made by the plumbing inspector of the city and the issuance of certificates pertaining to inspections shall be issued by the city clerk after approval by the inspector. The licenses and permits provided in this division shall be issued by the city clerk, and the inspection fee shall be paid to the city clerk. 
(Prior Code, § 9-5.5; Code 1983, § 5-705)
 
Sec. 8-205. Application for permit; issuance.
(a)	Before a master gas fitter installs any gas fitting work, or makes additions to or alterations in existing gas fittings, appliances, or fixtures, he shall file with the city clerk an application in writing for a permit. The application shall be made out on a form which shall be furnished by the city clerk. The following information shall appear: 
(1)	Street and house number of the premises where the gas fitting work is to be done; 
(2)	Name of the owner or builder; 
(3)	Kind of building; 
(4)	A list of the gas work to be done; and 
(5)	Such other information as the plumbing inspector may reasonably require. 
(b)	The application shall be referred to the plumbing inspector who, after consideration thereof, shall issue a permit in accordance therewith if the application complies with the terms and provisions of the applicable codes of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.2; Code 1983, § 5-706)
 
Sec. 8-206. Permit not transferable, second permits.
Permits are not transferable. The issuance of a second permit cancels a permit issued prior thereto. In the event a master gas fitter obtains a permit for work to be performed and fails to finish it, another master gas fitter who desires to finish the work may apply for a new permit. If after an investigation, the plumbing inspector finds that the master gas fitter who held or holds the original or first permit has not been diligent in performing his contract and finishing the work described in the permit, he must issue a new or another permit according to the plans and application therefor upon the payment of the required fees for the issuance of the permit as provided by the terms and provisions of the applicable code. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.3; Code 1983, § 5-707)
 
Sec. 8-207. Expiration of permit.
If plumbing work under a permit is not commenced within six months after the issuance of the permit, or the work is discontinued for a period of one year from the date of the issuance thereof, the permit shall thereupon become void, and no work shall be done on the premises until a new permit is issued and all fees are paid. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.4; Code 1983, § 5-708)
 
Sec. 8-208. Fees; permits and inspections.
(a)	No permit shall be issued for any gas fitting to any person other than a licensed and bonded meter fitter. Every master gas fitter shall, before work of any kind covered by applicable ordinances of the city, except in cases of repairing leaks inside of property lines, obtain a permit from the plumbing inspector of the city for such work. 
(b)	The applicant for such permit shall pay to the city clerk an inspection fee in such amount as set by the city council by motion or resolution, a copy of which shall be kept on file in the city clerk's office. If the plumbing inspector is required to make another or an additional inspection of the installation, necessitating another trip therefor, the permittee shall be required to pay the city clerk a fee as set by the council for additional inspection. 
(Prior Code, § 9-6.1; Code 1983, § 5-709)
 
Secs. 8-209—8-239. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 5. LIQUEFIED PETROLEUM GAS AND GASOLINE
 
Subdivision I. In General
 
Sec. 8-240. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Liquefied petroleum gas means and includes any material which is composed predominantly of any of the following hydrocarbons, or mixtures of propane, propylene, butanes (normal butane or isobutane) and butylenes, regardless of by what means such substances may be hereafter known. 
Liquefied petroleum gas equipment means and includes all devices, piping and equipment pertinent to the use of liquefied petroleum gas, except gas-burning appliances. The term "appliances" as herein referred to, is construed to embrace all gas-burning appliances intended for use with liquefied petroleum gas. 
(Prior Code, §§ 17-3.1, 17-3.2; Code 1983, §§ 5-801, 5-802)
 
Sec. 8-241. Installation, notice, approval.
No system for the use or dispensation of liquefied petroleum gases shall be installed within the city, until written notice thereof is given to the inspection department of the city and the plans and specifications for such system have been submitted to the fire department and approved by the fire chief or his appointee. Every such system installed or used in the city shall be tested and listed either by the Underwriters Laboratories, Inc., or by a nationally recognized testing laboratory, and shall be approved by the state liquefied petroleum gas administrator. Any installation must be performed by a liquefied petroleum gas installer licensed by the state. 
(Prior Code, § 17-3.3; Code 1983, § 5-803)
 
Sec. 8-242. Records of installation.
Every person, firm or corporation installing liquefied petroleum gas equipment, other than gas-burning appliances, and replacing of portable cylinders, shall keep a record of each installation showing the name and address of the customer at whose place the liquefied petroleum gas equipment has been installed and the date of installation. Such reports shall be disclosed to the fire chief or his appointee of the city at any time upon request during regular business hours. However, the fire chief or his appointee may, at any time he deems it necessary as a precautionary measure, inspect such records. The fire chief or his appointee may, at any reasonable time, inspect the installation of liquefied petroleum gas equipment. 
(Prior Code, § 17-3.5; Code 1983, § 5-804)
 
Sec. 8-243. Standards for use and installation of liquefied petroleum gas equipment.
The use and installation of liquefied petroleum gas equipment shall be in conformity with the provisions of this division, with the statutes of the state and with any orders, rules or regulations issued by authority thereof, the liquefied petroleum gas administrator of the state, and with generally recognized standards, for safety to person and property. Where no specific standards are prescribed by this article or by state statutes, or by any orders, rules or regulations issued by authority thereof, the liquefied petroleum gas administrator of the state, conformity with the standards of pamphlet number 54, Liquefied Petroleum Gas, Storage and Handling, of the National Board of Fire Underwriters for the design, installation and handling of liquefied petroleum gases, as amended, as recommended by the National Fire Protection Association, shall be prima facie evidence of conformity with generally recognized standards for safety to persons and property. 
(Prior Code, § 17-3.5; Code 1983, § 5-805)
 
Sec. 8-244. Permit and fee required.
Before any person, firm or corporation shall install any equipment in the city for the storage, dispensation or handling of liquefied petroleum gases, such person, firm or corporation shall first obtain a permit therefor from the city clerk. In granting or refusing such permit, the fire chief or his appointee shall take into consideration the proposed location of such equipment, and the probable hazards involved by reason of the proposed location thereof, and must have the approval of the state liquefied petroleum gas administrator in conformity with the state laws. A permit for the storage or dispensation of liquefied petroleum gas shall not be issued until a fee as set by the city has been paid to the city clerk. Before any installation of appliances are done, a permit must be secured from the inspection department and a fee paid to the city clerk as provided by the plumbing code of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 17-3.6; Code 1983, § 5-806)
 
Sec. 8-245. Duty of city inspector.
It is the duty of the fire chief and the city inspector to see that this division is enforced. 
(Prior Code, § 17-3.8; Code 1983, § 5-807)
 
Secs. 8-246—8-268. Reserved.
 
Subdivision II. Gasoline Storage
 
Sec. 8-269. Storage for distribution.
No tank for the storage and distribution of oil, gasoline and other inflammable and explosive liquids and commodities, excepting liquefied petroleum gas, shall ever be erected, built, rebuilt, constructed, maintained or enlarged in the city limits, unless such tank is constructed and maintained at least three feet below the natural surface of the earth. This section is not to be construed to prevent the use of such tanks as have already been established and are in operation on the initial effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived, so long as the tanks are in a safe condition. 
(Prior Code, § 17-2.1; Code 1983, § 5-820)
 
Sec. 8-270. Location of tanks.
It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to construct, maintain or operate any gasoline tank or receptacle at any point on or under any sidewalk or parking lot, or in any easement in the city or to construct, operate or maintain any pump or apparatus for the purposes of furnishing oil, gasoline, air or water or other supplies to automobiles within 19 feet of a street, right-of-way line or abutting property line. 
(Prior Code, § 17-2.2; Code 1983, § 5-821)
 
Sec. 8-271. Keeping for personal use.
All oil, gasoline and other inflammable and explosive liquids, excluding liquefied petroleum gas, where kept for personal use is to be kept in an iron or steel container, securely closed, in quantities not to exceed the sum of 100 gallons. 
(Prior Code, § 17-2.3; Code 1983, § 5-822)
 
Sec. 8-272. Keeping for commercial use.
All oil, gasoline and other inflammable and explosive liquids, excluding liquefied petroleum gas, where kept for use in heavy or commercial equipment, shall be kept in an iron or steel container, securely closed, in quantities not to exceed 300 gallons, and may not be located in a highly populated area, and not closer than 100 feet from any commercial or residential building. 
(Prior Code, § 17-2.4; Code 1983, § 5-823)
 
Secs. 8-273—8-292. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 6. RESIDENTIAL
 
Sec. 8-293. Adoption of residential code.
That certain document, two copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the international residential code, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A through L (see international residential code section 102.5, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the residential code of the city for regulating and governing the construction, alteration, movement, enlargement, replacement, repair, equipment, location, removal and demolition of detached one- and two-family dwellings and multiple single-family dwellings (townhouses) not more than three stories in height with separate means of egress as herein provided; providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said residential code on file in the office of the city clerk are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this section, with additions, insertions, deletions and changes, if any, prescribed in section 8-294. 
(Code 1983, § 5-901; Ord. No. 455-11-04, 12-16-2004)

(3)	Section P2603.6.1. Building sewers that connect to private sewage disposal systems shall be a minimum of 12 inches deep below finished grade or a minimum of six inches below frost line at the point of septic tank connection. Building sewers shall be a minimum of 18 inches below frost line. 
(4)	Section P3103.1. All open vent pipes which extend through a roof shall be terminated at least 12 inches above the roof or two inches above the anticipated snow accumulation. 
(Code 1983, § 5-901; Ord. No. 455-11-04, 12-16-2004)

DIVISION 7. MECHANICAL
 
Sec. 8-322. Adoption of mechanical code.
(a)	That certain document, two copies of which are on file in the office of the city clerk, being marked and designated as the International Mechanical Code, 2012 edition, including appendix chapters A and B (see International Mechanical Code section 101.2.1, 2012 edition), as published by the International Code Council, is hereby adopted as the code of the city for regulating the design, construction, quality of materials, erection, installation, alteration, repair, location, relocation, replacement, addition to, use or maintenance of mechanical systems in the city, and providing conditions and terms of such international mechanical code, 2012 edition, published by the International Code Council, on file in the city clerk's office are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof as if fully set out in this section.

a.	The full amount of any fee paid hereunder which was erroneously paid or collected.

(4)	Section 108.4. Persons, who shall violate a provision of this code, fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof or erect, install, alter or repair work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor punishable by a fine as provided by the city fine schedule or by imprisonment not exceeding 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(5)	Section 108.5. Any person who shall continue any work in or about the structure after having been served with a stop work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine as provided in the city fine schedule. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1501; Ord. No. 449-02-05, 2-17-2005)
 
Sec. 8-323. Fees; permits and inspections.
No permit shall be issued for any mechanical installation to any person other than a licensed and bonded mechanical contractor. Every mechanical contractor, before work of any kind covered by the applicable ordinances of the city, except in cases of emergency repairs, shall obtain a permit from the city for such work. The applicant for a permit shall pay to the city clerk-treasurer an inspection fee in such amount as set by the city council by motion or resolution, a copy of which shall be kept on file in the city clerk-treasurer's office. If the mechanical inspector is required to make another or an additional inspection of the installation, necessitating another trip therefor, the permittee shall be required to pay the city clerk-treasurer an additional sum as set by the council for additional inspection. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1502; Ord. No. 309-A-91, 4-11-1991)
 
Sec. 8-324. Application for permit; issuance.
(a)	Before a mechanical contractor installs, makes additions to or alterations in existing mechanical systems, he shall file with the city clerk-treasurer an application in writing for a permit. The application shall be made out on a form which shall be furnished by the city clerk-treasurer. The following information shall appear: 
(1)	Street and house number of the premises where the mechanical work is to be done; 
(2)	Name of the owner or builder; 
(3)	Kind of building; 
(4)	A list of work to be done; and 
(5)	Such other information as the mechanical inspector may reasonably require. 
(b)	The application shall be referred to the mechanical inspector who, after consideration thereof, shall issue a permit in accordance therewith if the application complies with the terms and provisions of the codes of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1503; Ord. No. 309-A-91, 4-11-1991)
 
Sec. 8-325. Permits not transferable; second permits.
Permits are not transferable. The issuance of a second permit cancels a permit issued prior thereto. In the event a mechanical contractor obtains a permit for work to be performed and fails to finish it, another contractor who desires to finish the work may apply for a new permit. If, after an investigation, the mechanical inspector finds that the mechanical contractor who held or holds the original or first permit has not been diligent in performing his contract and finishing the work described in the permit, he must issue a new or another permit according to the plans and application therefor upon the payment of the required fees for the issuance of the permit as provided by the terms and provisions of the mechanical code. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1504; Ord. No. 309-A-91, 4-11-1991)
 
Sec. 8-326. Expiration of permit.
If mechanical work under a permit is not commenced within six months after the issuance of a permit, or the work is discontinued for a period of six months from the date of the issuance thereof, the permit shall thereupon become void and no work shall be done on the premises until a new permit is issued and all fees are paid. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1505; Ord. No. 309-A-91, 4-11-1991)
 
Sec. 8-327. Mechanical contractor registration fees.
No person shall engage in the business, trade or occupation of a mechanical contractor, journeyman, or apprentice unless he is registered as such with the mechanical inspector. The registration fees to be paid to the city clerk-treasurer shall be in such sums as the council shall set by motion or resolution. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1506; Ord. No. 309-A-91, 4-11-1991)
 
Secs. 8-328—8-357. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 8. PROPERTY MAINTENANCE
 
Sec. 8-358. Adoption of property maintenance code.
A certain document, on file in the building department of the City of Spencer, Oklahoma, being marked and designated as the International Property Maintenance Code, 2012 Edition ("IPMC"), including appendix chapters A through L (see IPMC section 102.5, 2012 edition as published by the International Code Council, Inc., is hereby adopted as the Property Maintenance Code of the City of Spencer in the State of Oklahoma pursuant to Chapter 8, Article 111, Division 8, Section 8-359.6; for the control of buildings and structures as herein provided; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said property maintenance code are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof by reference, as if fully set out in this section, with the additions, insertions, deletions, amendments and augmentations prescribed in this section. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1701; Ord. No. 451-11-04, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. 451 , § 8, 1-16-2020)
 
Sec. 8-359. Amendments to code.

(1)	Section 101.1. These regulations shall be known as the property maintenance code of the city, hereinafter referred to as "this code." 
(2)	Section 103.5. The fees for work shall be as indicated in Ordinance 450-10-14. 
(3)	Section 304.14. During the period from April through October, every door, window and other outside opening required for ventilation of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas or any areas where products to be included or utilized in food for human consumption are processed, manufactured, packaged or stored, shall be supplied with approved tightly fitting screen of not less than 16 mesh per inch (16 mesh per 25 mm) and every swinging door shall have a self-closing device in good working condition. 
(4)	Section 602.3. Every owner and operator of any building who rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling unit, rooming unit, dormitory or guestroom on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to the occupants thereof shall supply heat during the period from October through May to maintain a temperature of not less than 68 degrees Fahrenheit (20 degrees Celsius) in all habitable rooms, bathrooms, and toilet rooms. 
(5)	Section 602.4. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall be supplied with heat during the period from October through May to maintain a temperature of not less than 65 degrees Fahrenheit (18 degrees Celsius) during the period the spaces are occupied. 
(6)	Administrative Policy #2020001 of the City of Spencer/Spencer. [The] utility authority housing inspection program is hereby created in order to protect the safety and well-being of the city residents; program description, application instructions, inspection, property owner certification, occupant certification, property manager certification, housing inspection brochure, abbreviated inspection checklist, certificate of occupancy, fees, and penalties. 
(Code 1983, § 5-1702; Ord. No. 451-11-04, 12-16-2004; Ord. No. 451 , § 8, 1-16-2020)
