No auctioneer is employed in the conduction of any such sale until such party shall be licensed or have a permit as provided for in the terms of this division. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.8; Code 1983, § 9-208)
 
Sec. 10-80. False bidders or cappers.
No false bidder, capper or other person shall be employed by the owner of the merchandise being sold or by auctioneer in charge thereof, or by any person acting in behalf of either, for the purpose of submitting false bids or fictitious bids in order to boost or increase the sale price of any article so offered for sale at auction, nor shall any false bidder or capper be permitted or allowed to take part in any such auction sale. It is unlawful for any auctioneer or auctioneer's helper or assistant to falsely or fraudulently represent or imply that a bid has been made for any article so offered at auction unless a bona fide bid has been made by some person in attendance at the auction sale and who is not a false bidder or capper. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.9; Code 1983, § 9-209)
 
Sec. 10-81. Substitution of merchandise.
It is unlawful to substitute another article for and in place of the article sold to the purchaser. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.10; Code 1983, § 9-210)
 
Sec. 10-82. False representation of merchandise.
False representation as to the ownership, source of acquisition, character, origin, manufacturer, nature or quality of goods sold or offered for sale, or falsely representing goods to be bankrupt stock, damaged goods, or goods saved from fire, or false representation as to the previous history or character of goods shall be unlawful. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.11; Code 1983, § 9-211)
 
Sec. 10-83. Fee, amount.
Before any license is issued as provided in this article, the applicant shall first pay a fee as set forth in the city fee schedule. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.14; Code 1983, § 9-212)
 
Sec. 10-84. Auction houses.
(a)	The term "auction house" means an auction that occurs in a regular place of business and whose location remains stationary. 
(b)	Prior to establishing an auction house within the city, prospective owners shall: 
(1)	Meet with all terms and conditions shown in article I of this chapter, except section 10-83 shall not apply. 
(2)	Pay an annual fee as set forth in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1983, § 9-250; Ord. No. 486-03-06, 8-17-2006)
 
Sec. 10-85. License revoked for violation.
Upon conviction in the municipal court of the violation of any of the provisions of this article, the license or permit issued to the party convicted shall immediately and automatically be thereby revoked, and all rights thereunder shall be deemed waived and terminated by the party to whom the license or permit shall be issued. 
(Prior Code, § 7-1.15; Code 1983, § 9-213)
 
Secs. 10-86—10-113. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. CLOSING OUT SALES
 
Sec. 10-114. License required, fee.
It is unlawful for any person to advertise or conduct or carry on in the city any sale of goods, wares or merchandise at retail that is represented as being bankrupt, bankrupt stock or price, insolvent, assignees, trustees, executors, administrators, receivers, wholesalers, jobbers, manufacturers, closing out, quitting business, going out of business, liquidation, closing stock, fire, fire damage, smoke, smoke damage, water, water damage or other similar sale without obtaining a license as required in this article. The fee for the license shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule, for a period not exceeding 30 days. The 30 days provided in this section shall mean calendar days exclusive of Sundays and legal holidays. At the end of the 30-day period upon application for renewal of the license sworn to by the applicant, a renewal license may be issued for a period of 30 days, Sundays and legal holidays excluded. The fee for such renewal license shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule for each 30 days, provided that only one such license shall be issued for any one person within a 12-month period, and no such license shall be issued or renewed for more than 30 days at a time. 
(Prior Code, § 7-2.1; Code 1983, § 9-220)
 
Sec. 10-115. Application, oath, inventory.
(a)	The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)	The nature of the occupancy of the place where such sale is to be held, whether by lease or otherwise, and the effective date of termination of such occupancy; and 
(2)	A full and complete statement of the facts regarding the proposed sale including reason why such sale is being conducted, the manner in which sale will be conducted, and the commencement and termination date of such sale. 
(b)	The application shall be signed by the person seeking to secure license or by the proper officer of the corporation, and the application shall be sworn to be the proper person signing such application which oath shall state that the information given herein is full and true and known by the affiant to be sold. 
(Prior Code, § 7-2.2; Code 1983, § 9-221)
 
Sec. 10-116. Grounds for cancellation of license.
It is unlawful for any person to receive a license under the provisions of this division to fail or refuse to give to the city clerk or any person designated by him for that purpose, all the facts connected with the stock of goods, wares and merchandise on hand, or the proper information regarding goods sold, or any other information that he may require in order that he may make a thorough investigation of all phases connected with this sale. The failure to comply with any of the provisions of this division shall be sufficient grounds for the cancellation of license issued under the provisions hereof. 
(Prior Code, § 7-2.5; Code 1983, § 9-222)
 
Secs. 10-117—10-145. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 4. PRIVATE SECURITY OFFICERS
 
Sec. 10-146. Purpose.
The purpose of this division is to provide the procedures for licensing and regulation of private security officers or organizations offering their services as independent contractors within the city. 
(Code 1983, § 9-301; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-147. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Guard service means stationary armed guards serving private citizens at a particular and specified place or location. 
Patrol service means motorized armed patrol serving private citizens or companies in a specified geographical area, which area shall be established by naming the streets forming the exterior boundaries of the area served. 
Permanent security service means regularly armed scheduled service furnished hourly, daily, weekly, monthly or for any other period at a specified place area or location. 
Private security company means any organization or security system offering services as an independent contractor and employing armed security officers who are commissioned under the provisions of this chapter. A one-man operation shall not be considered a private security company. 
Private security officer means any officer commissioned to provide patrol or guard service as an independent contractor and under the provisions of this chapter who shall be authorized to carry firearms. 
Temporary security service means service not offered on a regular armed scheduled basis. 
(Code 1983, § 9-302; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-148. Commissions.
The chief of police, subject to the provisions of this division, is authorized to grant commissions to private officers and permits to private security companies in the city. 
(Code 1983, § 9-303; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-149. Applications and processing fees.
Each individual applicant for appointment for commission shall make written application on forms available at the police department. A fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be charged for processing. Each private security company applying for a permit to furnish service within the city shall make written application on forms available at the police department. A fee as provided in the city fee schedule per annum per company shall be charged for processing. 
(Code 1983, § 9-301; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-150. Contents of applications.
Applications for commissions or permits shall contain the following information: 
(1)	For private security officer for guard service: 
a.	Company, if any, employing the applicant; 
b.	A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided by the chief of police; and 
c.	Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of police. 
(2)	For private security company permit for guard service: 
a.	Names of the officers, principals, or resident managers of the company; 
b.	A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided by the chief of police; and 
c.	Such other and additional information deemed necessary by the chief of police. 
(3)	For private security officer commission for patrol service: 
a.	The specific places or area where services would be rendered; 
b.	Hours of the day when services would be rendered if the applicant is self-employed; and 
c.	A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided by the chief of police. 
(4)	For private security company permit for patrol service: 
a.	The names of the officers, principals or resident managers of the company; 
b.	A standard personal history statement completed on a form provided by the chief of police; and 
c.	The specific area or properties where the service would be furnished and the hours of the day that service would be furnished. 
(Code 1983, § 9-305; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-151. Time and place of permanent security service.
The chief of police shall designate the specific place or area and hours of the day that each private officer or company may furnish permanent security patrol service. 
(Code 1983, § 9-306; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-152. Restrictions on commissioned private officers.
Duly commissioned private officers or private security companies shall at all times service only the place or specifically defined area where they are authorized to serve under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1983, § 9-307; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-153. Application for changes in service areas.
(a)	Before a private security officer or company performing patrol service may service additional areas, application for permission must be made to and approved by the chief of police. 
(b)	Before a private security officer or company performing guard service may furnish permanent security service at an additional place or location, notification must be made to the chief of police. 
(c)	Before a private security officer or company shall furnish temporary security service at an additional place or location, the chief of police, or his designated representative, shall be notified of the company or officer, the place or location and the anticipated duration of service. 
(d)	When permanent service is discontinued in an area or at a location, written notification will be sent to the chief of police. 
(Code 1983, § 9-308; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-154. Annual application required for commission and permits.
Reapplication shall be made annually for each commission and permit. The application for renewal need not be processed, but shall be filed with the police department, by April 15. Unless the applications are received by April 15, the commissions or permit shall be terminated without further action on May 1. 
(Code 1983, § 9-309; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-155. Bond requirements.
Prior to the issuance of a commission, each individual applicant shall file with the city clerk a surety bond or certificate of insurance of general liability in the amount of $10,000.00, made by a duly qualified bonding or insurance company licensed to do business in the state. Each company filing an application may file a $10,000.00 bond or certificate of insurance which shall be renewed and filed annually with the application for renewal. A copy of a general liability bond or certificate of insurance on file with the state will satisfy the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1983, § 9-310; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-156. Investigation, interview, and persons ineligible for commissions.
(a)	Prior to the issuance of a commission, the police department shall conduct a complete background inquiry of the applicant, and the applicant shall be personally interviewed by the chief of police or his representative and the applicant's photograph and fingerprints shall be obtained. 
(b)	Each applicant will be interviewed as to his ability to safely handle firearms. 
(c)	It is the duty of the chief of police to refuse such commissions to all persons having been convicted of a felony under the laws of the state or any other state or of the United States, or any offense involving moral turpitude, and to all minors, drug addicts, habitual drunkards, unnaturalized foreign born persons, and such other persons as he has reasonable cause to believe are not qualified. 
(Code 1983, § 9-311; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-157. Orientation required.
A commissioned private officer shall attend those classes of orientation reasonable and appropriate to his service to be rendered, as designed by the chief of police and given by his designated representative. 
(Code 1983, § 9-312; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-158. Rules and regulations.
The chief of police shall promulgate and publish those additional rules and regulations consistent with this division and as may be necessary to its implementation. Copies shall be furnished to applicants upon request. 
(Code 1983, § 9-313; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-159. Appointments of time.
If the chief of police, subject to the requirements contained herein, finds an applicant eligible for commission, the applicant may be appointed as a private officer to serve in accordance with this division. The chief of police shall act on applications and applications for renewal within 15 business days from the time of submission of the application. 
(Code 1983, § 9-314; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-160. Suspension or revocation of commission or permit.
The commissions of any private security officer or permit of any private security company may be suspended or revoked at any time by the chief of police for violation of any of the requirements necessary for a commission or permit or for violation of any rule or regulation established pursuant to this division. Upon a violation occurring, the chief of police or his representative shall give the private security officer or private company notice of any suspension or revocation hearing at least five days prior to the date of the public hearing, and such notice shall be furnished by mail. The suspension or revocation hearing will be conducted by a two-member board consisting of the chief of police or his representative, and the city manager or his representative. 
(Code 1983, § 9-315; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-161. No authority to arrest.
A duly commissioned private officer is not a member of the police department and shall not have the authority of a police officer. He shall, while on duty at his assigned place, have the right to carry a pistol or revolver and make arrests only as a private citizen is granted authority by state statutes. 
(Code 1983, § 9-316; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-162. Badge and uniform.
A duly commissioned private officer, when on duty, shall have on his person his commission and shall wear uniform, badge or other emblems of authority as approved by the chief of police, which shall in any event be clearly distinctive and different from that of regular city officers and shall designate the officer as a "private officer," "security officer" or "security service." 
(Code 1983, § 9-317; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-163. Non-liability of city.
Any commissioned private officer, when on duty as a private officer, shall not be an agent, servant or employee of the city, and the city shall not be liable for his actions to third parties, nor shall the city be liable for any injury or damage he might suffer. 
(Code 1983, § 9-318; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Sec. 10-164. License expiration.
Licenses issued under this division shall expire on April 30 of each year. 
(Code 1983, § 9-319; Ord. No. 64A, 8-8-1974)
 
Secs. 10-165—10-181. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 5. PRIVATE SEWAGE TREATMENT SYSTEM INSTALLERS
 
Sec. 10-182. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Small sewage treatment system includes any septic tank, subsurface absorption field and open intermittent sand filter as described in the state department of health engineering bulletin number 0575. 
(Code 1983, § 9-401; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-183. License required.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to install, construct, repair or extend any small sewage treatment system within the city without first having been qualified and licensed to install small sewage treatment systems in accordance with the provisions of this division; provided, however, that such license shall not be required of any person holding a current plumbing contractor's license. 
(Code 1983, § 9-402; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-184. Examination and certificate.
(a)	The city manager is hereby empowered to prepare and administer an examination for applicants for a license to install small sewage treatment systems and determine whether such applicant has adequate knowledge of the design, construction, operation and use of small sewage treatment systems, for the purpose of installing, constructing or repairing such systems. 
(b)	If it is determined that such applicant is qualified, the city manager shall issue a certificate to that effect. 
(Code 1983, § 9-403; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-185. License; issuance; expiration; renewal.
(a)	The city manager, upon application and receipt of the fee provided for herein, shall issue a license for the installation of small sewage treatment systems to any person who holds a certificate from the city manager to the effect that such applicant is qualified for such license. 
(b)	A license may be applied for and secured at any time during the year but in no event shall the fee for such license be less than for a full year. All licenses shall expire on the last day of April and may be renewed without penalty within 90 days after the expiration thereof. 
(Code 1983, § 9-404; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-186. Bond.
(a)	Before a license is issued or renewed, each applicant shall give and keep in force, for the entire duration of such license, a bond with approved sureties, running to the city. The bond shall be in the amount of $1,000.00 and shall be conditioned that the licensee will comply with the provisions and requirements of this and other ordinances and regulations of the city. All such bonds shall also provide that the principal or licensee shall save harmless the city from any and all damages resulting from or in any way growing out of any injury or damage received by anyone due to the negligence or unskilled work on the part of the licensee, their agents or employees. All such bonds shall be approved by the city attorney as to form and by the city council as to sufficiency and the same shall then be filed with the city clerk. 
(b)	The bond requirements of this section shall not apply to nor be required of those persons installing a small sewage treatment system for the personal use and benefit of the person and his family nor shall a bonded plumbing contractor be required to comply with this section. 
(Code 1983, § 9-405; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-187. Permit required.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to install, construct, repair or extend any small sewage treatment system within the city without first having obtained a permit from the city manager for such installation, construction, repair or extension, paying the fees for such permit as provided for herein and complying with the provisions of this and all other ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1983, § 9-407; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-188. Specifications and requirements.
Any small sewage treatment systems installed, constructed, repaired or extended under this chapter shall comply with the minimum specifications and requirements of the state department of health engineering bulletin number 0575 or its successor, a certified copy of which is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(Code 1983, § 9-408; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-189. Inspections required.
It is unlawful and an offense to use or operate any small sewage treatment system installed, constructed, repaired or extended hereunder without first having been inspected and approved by the city manager. The fee for such inspection is provided for herein and shall be paid at the time the permit is obtained. An additional fee shall be required in advance for each additional inspection required until the disposal system being inspected is approved. 
(Code 1983, § 9-409; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-190. Prepaid accounts.
(a)	License holders under this division shall have the option of establishing a prepaid account for percolation test, permit and inspection fees, with the city manager or pay for percolation test, permits and inspections on an individual basis. A prepaid account may be established by making application to the city manager and depositing in advance, not less than $50.00 with the city treasurer. 
(b)	With the establishment of a prepaid account, the licensee may telephone in request for a percolation test, permit or inspection and will not be required to come to the office of the city manager, provided that sufficient funds are on hand in the licensee's account to cover such cost. 
(Code 1983, § 9-410; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Sec. 10-191. Fees and permit charges.
The charges levied for permits and tests under this division as provided in the city fee schedule: 
(Code 1983, § 9-411; Ord. No. 132A, 11-13-1980)
 
Secs. 10-192—10-220. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 6. PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS OR CANVASSERS
 
Sec. 10-221. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Peddler includes the terms "hawker" and "huckster" and means any person, whether a resident of this city or not, who travels by foot or by any type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house or from street to street carrying, conveying or transporting goods, wares or merchandise of whatsoever nature, offering and exposing the same for sale, or who, without traveling from place to place, sells or offers the same for sale from any vehicle or conveyance or on any public street or thoroughfare. 
Solicitor or canvasser means a person, whether a resident of this city or not, who travels by foot or by any type of conveyance from place to place, from house to house or from street to street taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of whatsoever nature for future delivery, or for services to be furnished or performed in the future. 
(Code 1983, § 9-501; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-222. Exclusions.
(a)	The following persons or entities are hereby specifically excluded from the terms of the definitions given in section 10-221. They must however, make application for and secure a permit. No fee will be charged for such permit. 
(1)	Persons engaged in selling personal property at wholesale to dealers in such property; 
(2)	Merchants having regular places of business in the city, and their employees, in taking orders at the houses of their customers for goods held in stock at such places of business, and in delivering the goods so ordered; 
(3)	Newspaper persons selling newspapers; 
(4)	Milk delivery men operating in compliance with the city-county health regulations; 
(5)	Any other delivery man delivering foodstuffs on a regular daily route, from house to house, operating in compliance with city-county health regulations; and 
(6)	Any church, synagogue, school, civic or charitable organization, etc. 
(Code 1983, § 9-502; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-223. Duty of police to enforce.
It is the duty of any police officer of the city to require any person seen peddling, and who is not known by such officer to be duly licensed, to produce his peddler's permit and to enforce the provisions of this division against any person found to be violating the same. 
(Code 1983, § 9-503; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-224. Permit required.
No person or any agency or employee thereof shall engage in the business of peddler, solicitor, canvasser, hawker or huckster as defined herein without first obtaining a permit therefor as herein provided, and paying the prescribed fees for same. 
(Code 1983, § 9-504; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-225. Application for permit required.
The applicant for a permit hereunder shall file with the city clerk in duplicate a sworn application in writing on a form to be furnished by the clerk, which shall give the following information: 
(1)	Name and brief description of applicant; 
(2)	Address, both legal and local; 
(3)	Nature of business, kinds of goods to be sold and, if applicant is a farmer or truck gardener, whether the goods are produced by him on lands he owns, cultivates and controls; 
(4)	If employed by another, the name and address of applicant's employer together with a brief description of credentials showing the exact relationship; 
(5)	Length of time for which the right to do business is desired; 
(6)	Description and license number or other identification of any vehicle to be used; and 
(7)	Applicants will be fingerprinted and photographed at a cost as provided by the city fee schedule before a license is issued. 
(Code 1983, § 9-505; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-226. Minimum age.
No permit hereunder shall be issued to any person under the age of 16 years. It is unlawful for any permittee hereunder to employ, apprentice, engage or to suffer, cause or allow any minor under the age of 16 years to be employed, apprenticed or engaged, either as a huckster, peddler, hawker, helper or solicitor in connection with the business permitted hereunder. 
(Code 1983, § 9-506; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-227. Investigation; issuance of permit.
Upon receipt of an application for a permit hereunder, the city clerk shall refer to the applicant and one copy thereof to the chief of police, who shall note thereon any record concerning the applicant and conduct such investigation as he deems necessary and return to the city clerk. The city clerk shall cause such other investigation or inquiry to be made concerning the applicant as he may deem necessary to determine the character and business responsibility of the applicant, and whether his application is in compliance with the terms and conditions of this chapter. If as a result of such investigation the character and business responsibility of the applicant are found to be satisfactory and the application is in compliance with the terms and conditions herein, the city clerk, upon payment of the prescribed permit fee, shall issue the permit together with any badge, tag or plates properly an accompaniment thereto. 
(Code 1983, § 9-507; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-228. Appeal.
Any person denied a permit issuance or renewal under this division may appeal to the city council within ten days of denial by making written application to the clerk of the court. Upon receipt of the appeal, the clerk shall place the matter on the agenda for the next regular council meeting occurring not less than ten days from the date of filing of the appeal. 
 
Sec. 10-229. Permit fees.
Fees for permits under this division shall be as provided in the city fee schedule; however, nothing in this division shall require the payment of a fee by persons selling only grains, vegetables and articles of their own raising. 
(Code 1983, § 9-508; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-230. Free permits; rebates.
Except as provided in section 10-222, no free permits shall be granted nor rebates allowed for any cause, nor any sum accepted less than the amount herein specified, for a shorter period than therein required. 
(Code 1983, § 9-509; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-231. Regulations for issuing permits.
(a)	Fee prerequisite to permit. Except as provided in section 10-222, no permit shall be issued until the amount prescribed therefor shall have been paid to the city clerk. 
(b)	Permits not to be prorated, returned, transferred. No permit shall in any case be prorated, returned or transferred from person to person. 
(c)	Signing, sealing of permits. Permits shall be signed by the city clerk and the clerk shall affix the corporate seal of the city thereto. 
(d)	Expiration. All permits except as otherwise provided shall expire on December 31 next after the same are issued, provided that all permits that are issued for six months shall expire on June 1 and December 1 next after same are issued. 
(Code 1983, §§ 9-510—9-513; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Sec. 10-232. Duty to exhibit permit; misuse of permit prohibited; use of streets.
(a)	Duty to exhibit. Peddlers are required to exhibit their permits at the request of any citizen. 
(b)	Misuse. No permit or badge issued under the provisions of this division shall be used or worn at any time by any person other than the one to whom it was issued. 
(c)	Use of streets. No peddler shall have any exclusive right to any location in the public streets, nor shall he be permitted a stationary location, nor shall he be permitted to operate in any congested area where his operations may impede or inconvenience the public. For the purpose of this division, the judgment of a police officer, exercised in good faith, shall be deemed conclusive as to whether the area is congested or the public impeded or inconvenienced. 
(Code 1983, §§ 9-514—9-516; Ord. No. 237-A, 1-21-1986)
 
Secs. 10-233—10-257. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 7. RETAIL MERCHANTS SUBLETTING TO MULTIPLE BUSINESSES
 
Sec. 10-258. License tax or fee.
Merchants, retail, all kinds, which sublet to multiple business users, pursuant to sections 10-19 through 10-28, shall pay to the city a license tax or fee as set forth in section 10-28 per day for any space sublet to multiple business users. 
(Code 1983, § 9-601; Ord. No. 338-4-95, 8-10-1995)
 
Sec. 10-259. Definitions.
(a)	The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Multiple business users means more than one lessee or sublessee leasing space for business purposes from merchants, retail, all kinds, as provided in section 10-28, if such lessee or sublessee leases and utilizes such space for periodic short intervals of time, such as, for example, but not limited to, per day or per week, regardless of the duration of the lease or sublease agreement between the merchant, owner or operator and the lessee or sublessee. 
Swap meet orflea market means merchants, retail, all kinds, which sublet to multiple business users. The owner or operator of any swap meet or flea market within the city shall pay to the city a license tax or fee as set forth in section 10-28 per day for each booth, stall or space leased or subleased to vendors or sellers utilizing the facilities of such swap meet or flea market. 
(b)	Payment of the daily license tax or fee by the merchant, retail, all kinds, which sublet to multiple business users, or the owner or operator thereof, shall not be required for any day its space, booths or stalls are not leased, subleased or utilized by its lessees or sublessees. 
(Code 1983, § 9-602; Ord. No. 338-4-95, 8-10-1995)
 
Sec. 10-260. Revocation of licenses.
The city may revoke any license of the owner or operator of any merchants, retail, all kinds which sublet to multiple business users within the city, if the licensee refuses or fails to comply with this division, or any other law, ordinance or regulation governing the operation of merchants, retail, all kinds which sublet to multiple business users, including refusal to allow inspection of the establishment as provided by city codes or ordinances. Upon revocation, the licensee shall immediately cease operation. 
(Code 1983, § 9-603; Ord. No. 338-4-95, 8-10-1995)
 
Secs. 10-261—10-283. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 8. GARAGE SALES
 
Sec. 10-284. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Garage sale means any sale of what is held out to be or is commonly known as yard, porch, room, backyard, or patio sale or another type of general sale conducted from residences within the city. 
(Code 1983, § 9-701; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-285. Permit required.
No person shall hold, conduct, engage in, or participate in any manner in a garage sale or other type of sale referenced in section 10-284 without submitting an application for a permit for same. A separate permit application shall be required for each location at which a garage sale is to be held. 
(Code 1983, § 9-702; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-286. Permit fee.
The fee for a garage sale shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1983, § 9-703; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-287. Issuance of permit.
The city clerk or the clerk's designee is hereby authorized to grant a permit for garage sales for a period not to exceed three consecutive days to any person applying who otherwise complies with the requirements of this division. The city clerk or a designee may conduct an investigation as may be reasonably necessary to determine if there is compliance with this division. 
(Code 1983, § 9-704; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-288. Intervals between sales.
No person shall hold, conduct, engage in or participate in any manner or allow a garage sale to be held or conducted on premises under his control or ownership more than once in a 30-day period unless otherwise the provisions for inclement weather apply. 
(Code 1983, § 9-705; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-289. Rain checks for garage sale permits.
If the garage sale permit is issued and the sale is terminated during the first day of the sale due to inclement weather conditions, the city clerk or the clerk's designee may issue another permit to the applicant for another garage sale to be conducted at the same location within 30 days from the date when the first sale was to be held for no additional charge. 
(Code 1983, § 9-706; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-290. Signs.
Signs announcing garage sales must be removed within 24 hours of the completion of the sale. 
(Code 1983, § 9-707; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-291. Display of goods.
The sale area of any residential sale shall be confined to the premises for which the license has been issued. 
(Code 1983, § 9-708; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-292. Collection of sales tax on garage sales.
Citizens that have been granted a garage sale permit shall be required to file a sales tax report to the state tax commission within 30 days following the last day of the garage sale. 
(Code 1983, § 9-709; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Sec. 10-293. Exemptions.
Charitable organizations conducting sales on their premises when all gross sales from the sale are used directly for charitable purposes and the goods or articles are not sold on a consignment basis, auctions, and persons acting pursuant to a court of competent jurisdiction shall be exempt from section 10-286 and section 10-292. Charitable organizations shall be required to show proof of nonprofit status. 
(Code 1983, § 9-710; Ord. No. 442-07-04, 4-19-2004)
 
Secs. 10-294—10-320. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 9. RENTAL PROPERTY REGISTRY
 
Sec. 10-321. Scope.
(a)	This division shall apply to any structure or part thereof that is let for occupancy by persons other than the owner pursuant to an oral or written rental or lease agreement regardless as to any monetary or other valuable consideration. Such structures shall include all residential uses or structures, including manufactured homes, whether purpose-built or converted, whether attached or unattached, regardless of zoning district, which are being used as rental housing. 
(b)	This division shall not apply to buildings or building areas described in one or more of the following subsections: 
(1)	Hotel, motel, dorm, medical or long-term care facilities, bed and breakfast establishments, group homes or assisted living group homes zoned as such; 
(2)	A dwelling unit that constitutes the owner's principal residence; 
(3)	A single-family detached dwelling owned by an express private trust duly registered under the laws of the state that is occupied by an individual who is designated a trustee, a designated beneficiary or the person named within a living trust; or 
(4)	A single family detached dwelling owned by an individual which is not designated for tax purposes as a rental property and within which an immediate family member, within one degree of consanguinity, resides without payment of rent or other tangible compensation. 
(c)	In order to qualify for an exemption under the provisions under this section, the city may require the filing of an affidavit of exemption signed by an owner or legally designated representative of the owner, along with proof attached to such affidavit in support of the exemption. 
(d)	This diision shall be governed and administered in conjunction with the provisions of the most recently adopted version of the International Property Maintenance Code as adopted by the Midwest City Council. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2001), 1-19-2012)
 
Sec. 10-322. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. Where terms are not defined in this Code and are defined in the International Property Maintenance Code, such terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them as stated therein. 
Local agent means an individual representing the owner, operator, manager or other agency. 
Multi-housing unit means apartment complexes designed for multifamily dwelling. 
Purpose built multi-unit housing means any building that was originally built for the purpose of multi-unit (two or more units) housing. 
Rental housing orrental property means any structure or part thereof which is let for occupancy by persons pursuant to an oral or written rental or lease agreement regardless as to any monetary or other valuable consideration required of any occupant therein. 
Semi-detached housing or semi-detached family dwelling includes those rental dwelling units to include duplexes, townhomes, condominiums which are non-owner occupied, and any other rental dwelling units that do not include those dwellings defined as single-family detached dwellings or multi-housing units. 
Single-family detached dwelling means a dwelling unit designed for single-family occupancy with no other family dwelling units attached. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2002), 1-19-2012)
 
Sec. 10-323. Single-family detached dwelling and semi-detached family dwelling rental registration.
(a)	Requirements. After January 1, 2012, it shall be unlawful for any owner of rental property to lease or operate residential rental property without registering each rental property with the city, designating a local agent, and complying with the provisions of this division, together with all other applicable ordinances of the city. Every owner of any rental dwelling unit is required to register the rental property pursuant to this ordinance and shall comply with the following: 
(1)	All existing rental property shall be registered by July 1, 2012. The registration shall be valid for a one-year period and shall be renewed annually by August 1 of each year. 
(2)	A valid registration shall be non-transferable when the owner of a rental property changes during the course of the year. The new owner must re-register each rental property within 30 days of the date of the sale or closing. New owners of rental property are responsible for the completion of the re-registration process. 
(3)	All newly constructed residential structures which are to be used as rental housing, including those that are legally being converted from owner-occupied housing to rental housing, shall be registered prior to any use or occupancy as rental housing. 
(4)	The owner must designate a local agent and/or service agent if the owner of such subject rental property does not reside within the county. When the owner is a corporation, partnership, trust, or other non-individual legal entity, a local agent and/or service agent shall also be designated. The owner is required to designate a local agent and/or service agent at the time of registration and each subsequent re-registration, designating an individual with a physical address within the county or within an immediately adjacent county to Oklahoma County to accept service of legal process on behalf of the owner. The registration shall require the signature of the designated individual who shall be the local agent and/or service agent. The local agent and/or service agent shall be responsible for the conveyance of all notices, orders, and citations relative to property maintenance to the owner and shall answer on behalf of the owner for the purpose of responding to notices, orders or citations and appearance for hearings. An individual owner may designate himself as his own local agent if he resides within the county or within a county immediately adjacent to Oklahoma County. 
(b)	Process.
(1)	Registration forms shall be made in such form as prescribed by the city clerk and in accordance with instructions as may be provided by the city clerk and shall, at a minimum, contain the following information: 
a.	The name of the owner of the property, including the trustee if the ownership is a trust, the officers' or partners' names if the ownership is a corporation or partnership, and their related contact information; 
b.	The name of the person authorized to manage the rental property and their related contact information; 
c.	The name of the individual authorized to act for and on behalf of the owner for the purpose of receipt of service of process, and receiving and receipting for notices, including their related contact information if different from subsection (b) above; and 
d.	The address of all residential rental properties and number of units therein associated with each ownership. 
(2)	The owner of the rental property must keep the information required to be furnished by this section current and the owner shall notify the city of any change in the information within ten days. Changes in the registration information shall be submitted in writing to the city, identifying the address of such rental dwelling property. 
(3)	The registration form for rental properties may be completed by the local agent if authorized by the property owner in writing. 
(4)	The city shall issue an acknowledgment of registration upon submission of a properly completed registration form with all required information and payment of all required fees. 
(c)	Fees.
(1)	There shall be no fee assessed for the initial registration process during the first effective year of registration, provided a registration form has been submitted with all required information by July 1, 2013. Thereafter, for each registration submitted after that initial date or for each registration renewal that is due by July 1 of each subsequent year, an annual fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be paid. There will be no proration of this fee. There shall be no fee for updating registration information provided within the one-year duration of a valid registration. A late fee as provided in the city fee schedule may be assessed for late registrations or renewals. Late registration fees shall be assessed beginning August 1 of each calendar year. 
(2)	Registration fees may be waived for active duty military personnel who receive permanent change of station orders as long as the below listed criteria are met. If the listed criteria are not met, the military personnel must pay the full registration or renewal fee as provided in the city fee schedule: 
a.	Owner of the dwelling intends to rent the dwelling; 
b.	Owner of the dwelling intends to reoccupy the dwelling as a primary residence upon completion of station duty; 
c.	Owner provides a copy to the city of the permanent change of station orders; 
d.	Owner does not own more than one dwelling within the city; 
e.	Renewal registration is submitted timely each calendar year, with a late fee as provided in the city fee schedule assessed if renewal is made after August 1 of any calendar year. 
(3)	Residential rental property is ineligible for new utility services until the rental registration is completed. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2002), 1-19-2012)
 
Sec. 10-324. Multi-housing rental registration.
(a)	Requirements. After January 1, 2012, it shall be unlawful for any owner to lease or operate rental property without registering each rental property with the city, designating a local agent, and complying with the provisions of this division, together with all other applicable ordinances of the city. Every owner of a residential rental property must register the property pursuant to this division and shall comply with the following: 
(1)	The registration shall be valid for a one-year period and shall be renewed annually by July 1 each year. 
(2)	A valid registration shall be non-transferable if the owner of the rental property changes during the course of the year. The new owner shall be required to re-register each subject property within 30 days of the date of the sale or closing. New owners of rental property are responsible for the completion of the re-registration process. 
(3)	All newly constructed multi-housing structures that are to be used as residential rental property, shall be registered prior to any use or occupancy. 
(4)	A local agent is required to be designated if the owner of such subject rental property does not reside within the county. A local agent and/or service agent shall also be designated when the owner is a corporation, partnership, trust, or other non-individual legal entity. The owner is required to designate a local agent at the time of registration and each subsequent re-registration, designating an individual with a physical address within the county who shall be responsible for the operation and maintenance of the subject rental property as well as a person with a physical address designated to accept service of legal process on behalf of the owner. The registration shall require the signature of the designated individual who shall be the local agent and/or person to accept service of legal process. The local agent shall be responsible for the operation of the owner's residential rental properties located within the city pursuant to the registration. 
(b)	Process.
(1)	Registration forms shall be made in such form as prescribed by the city clerk and in accordance with instructions as may be provided by the city clerk and shall, at a minimum, contain the following information: 
a.	The name of the owner of the property, including the trustee if the ownership is a trust, the officers' or partners' names if the ownership is a corporation or partnership, and their related contact information; 
b.	The name of the person authorized to manage the rental property and their related contact information; 
c.	The name of the individual authorized to act for and on behalf of the owner for the purpose of receipt of service of process, and receiving and receipting for notices, including their related contact information if different from subsection (b) above; and 
d.	The address of all residential rental properties and number of units therein associated with each ownership. 
(2)	The owner of the residential rental property must keep the information required to be furnished by this section current and the owner shall notify the city of any change in the information within ten days. Changes in the registration information shall be submitted in writing to the city, identifying the address of such rental dwelling property. 
(3)	The registration form for rental properties may be completed by the responsible local agent if authorized by the property owner in writing. 
(4)	The city shall issue an acknowledgment of registration upon submission of a properly completed registration form with all required information and payment of all required fees. 
(c)	Fees.
(1)	There shall be no fee assessed for the initial registration process during the first effective year of registration, provided a registration form has been submitted with all required information by July 1, 2012. Thereafter, for each registration submitted after that initial date or for each registration renewal that is due by July 1 of each subsequent year, an annual fee as provided in the city fee schedule shall be paid for each rental unit within the multi-housing complex. There will be no proration of this fee. There shall be no fee for updating registration information provided within the one-year duration of a valid registration. A late fee as provided in the city fee schedule per unit may be assessed for late registrations or renewals. Late registrations fees shall be assessed beginning August 1 of each calendar year. 
(2)	All penalties and late fees must be paid prior to the issuance of a utility account of rental dwelling property on each and/or any individual unit. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2003), 1-19-2012)
 
Sec. 10-325. Penalty.
(a)	Any owner of a residential rental property who fails to register each rental property, fails to maintain registration in compliance with this division, or fails to comply with any other provision of this division, the International Property Maintenance Code, or any other applicable ordinance, shall be guilty of an offense. Upon conviction, a fine as provided in the city fine schedule per unregistered residential rental property and the associated court costs may be assessed as directed by the municipal court. Each day that a violation exists shall constitute a separate punishable offense. 
(b)	Failing to register or renew registration of a residential rental property shall be defined as any residential rental property not registered or renewed by August 1 of each calendar year. 
(c)	It is unlawful and shall be a violation of this division for any person to provide any false or inaccurate information on a rental registration form or for any person to file a rental registration form without the proper authority to do so. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2004), 1-19-2012)
 
Sec. 10-326. Revocation.
The city may revoke a rental registration at any time for just cause including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)	A finding that information submitted in a rental registration form is false; 
(2)	A rental property that has been registered has failed to comply with the requirements of this division on more than two occasions or the owner has been convicted of more than two violations of a city ordinance or the International Property Maintenance Code relative to any property maintenance issue within a single registration year; or 
(3)	Change of ownership of a registered rental property within the city. The revocation of a rental registration shall require the city to give notice to the last known and listed local agent within ten days of the effective date of the revocation, except where a change of ownership has occurred. The revocation of a rental registration shall not be subject to appeal. 
(Ord. No. 543-12-11, § 1(5-2005), 1-19-2012)
 
Chapter 12 COURTS AND JAILS
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Secs. 12-1—12-18. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. MUNICIPAL COURT
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 12-19. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Chief of police means the peace officer in charge of the police force of the city. 
Clerk means the city clerk, including any deputy or member of the office staff of the clerk while performing duties of the clerk's office. 
Court means the municipal court of the city. 
Judge means the judge of the municipal court, including any acting judge or alternate judge thereof as provided for by the statutes of this state and this article. 
Judicial district means the district court judicial district of the state wherein the government of this city is situated. 
(Code 1983, § 6-102; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-20. Organization of municipal court.
This article shall govern the organization and operation of the municipal criminal court of the city as put into operation by resolution duly passed on June 11, 1981, and filed in accordance with state law. To the extent of conflict between any provisions of this article and the provisions of any ordinance of this city, the provisions of this article shall control. The court shall be operative on or after June 11, 1981. 
(Code 1983, § 6-101; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-21. Jurisdiction of court.
The court shall exercise original jurisdiction to hear and determine all prosecutions wherein a violation of any ordinance of this city is charged, including any such prosecutions transferred to the court in accordance with applicable law. 
(Code 1983, § 6-103; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Secs. 12-22—12-45. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. JUDGES
 
Sec. 12-46. Judge; qualifications.
There shall be one judge of the court who must be duly licensed to practice law in this state. The judge of the court may engage in the practice of law in other courts, but he shall not accept employment inconsistent with his duties as judge, or arising out of facts which give rise to or are connected with cases within the jurisdiction of the court, pending therein or which might become the subject of proceedings therein. 
(Code 1983, § 6-104; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-47. Appointment of judge.
The judge of the court shall be appointed by the mayor with the consent of the city council. A proposed appointment shall be submitted in writing to the city council at the next to the last regularly scheduled meeting prior to the day upon which the appointment is to take effect, and shall be acted upon at the next regularly scheduled meeting. The city council may decide upon the proposed appointment by a majority vote of a quorum present and acting. Failure of decision upon a proposed appointment shall not prevent action thereon at a later regularly scheduled meeting of the city council unless the mayor withdraws the proposed appointment. 
(Code 1983, § 6-105; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-48. Term of judge.
The official term of the judge shall be two years expiring on February 1 in each odd numbered year. Each judge, unless sooner removed for proper cause, shall serve until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(Code 1983, § 6-106; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-49. Alternate and acting judges.
There shall be appointed for each judge of the court an alternate judge possessed of the same qualifications as the judge. His appointment shall be for the same term and made in the same manner as the judge. He shall sit as acting judge of the court in any case if the judge is: 
(1)	Absent from the court; 
(2)	Unable to act as judge; or 
(3)	Disqualified from acting as judge in the case. 
(Code 1983, § 6-107; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-50. Selection of acting judge.
If at any time there is no judge or alternate judge, duly appointed and qualified, available to sit as judge, the mayor shall appoint some person, possessing the qualifications required by this article for the judge, who shall preside as acting judge over the court in the disposition of pending matters until such time as a judge or alternate judge shall be available. 
(Code 1983, § 6-108; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-51. Salary and payments to judges.
(a)	A judge, other than an alternate judge or an acting judge, shall receive a salary as fixed by the city council, paid in the same manner as the salaries of other officials of this city. 
(b)	The city council shall provide for the compensation of an acting or alternate judge of the court, as required. 
(Code 1983, § 6-109; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-52. Removal of judge.
(a)	Judges shall be subject to removal from office by the city council for the causes prescribed by the constitution and laws of this state for the removal of public officers. Proceedings for removal shall be instituted by the filing of a verified written petition setting forth facts sufficient to constitute one or more legal grounds for removal. Petitions may be signed and filed by (i) the mayor; or (ii) 25 or more qualified electors of this city. Verification of the number or qualifications of electors shall be executed by one or more of the petitioners. 
(b)	The city council shall set a date for hearing the matter and shall cause notice thereof, together with a copy of the petition, to be served personally upon the judge at least ten days before the hearing. At the hearing, the judge shall be entitled to: 
(1)	Representation by counsel; 
(2)	Present testimony and to cross examine the witnesses against him; and 
(3)	Have all evidence against him presented in open hearing. 
So far as they can be applicable, the provisions of the state Administrative Procedures Act governing individual proceedings shall govern removal proceedings hereunder. Judgment of removal shall be entered only upon individual votes, by a majority of all members of the city council, in favor of such removal. 
(Code 1983, § 6-110; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-53. Vacancy in office of judge.
A vacancy in the office of judge shall be filled in the same manner as provided for the appointment of the judge in the first instance. 
(Code 1983, § 6-111; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Secs. 12-54—12-79. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 3. OTHER COURT PERSONNEL
 
Sec. 12-80. Court marshal, police chief.
All writs or processes of the court shall be directed, in his official title, to the chief of police, or to some other appropriate peace officer, who shall be the principal officer of the court. 
(Code 1983, § 6-114; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-81. Clerk of the court; duties.
(a)	The city clerk, or a deputy designated by him, shall be the clerk of the court. The clerk shall: 
(1)	Assist the judge in recording the proceedings of the court and in preparing writs, processes or other papers; 
(2)	Administer oaths required in proceedings before the court; 
(3)	Be responsible for the entry of all pleadings, processes, and proceedings in the dockets of the court; 
(4)	Perform such other clerical duties relating to the proceedings of the court as the judge shall direct; and 
(5)	Receive and give receipt for forfeitures, fines, fees, deposits, and sums of money payable to the court. 
(b)	Such sums of money and funds shall be deposited and disbursed upon appropriate vouchers as directed by the city. 
(Code 1983, § 6-115; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-82. Prosecuting attorney; duties; conflict of interest.
The attorney for this city, or his duly designated assistant, shall be the prosecuting officer of the court. He shall prosecute all alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. He shall be authorized, in his discretion, to prosecute and resist appeal, proceedings in error and review from this court to any other court of the state, and to represent this city in all proceedings arising out of matters in this court. 
(Code 1983, § 6-116; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-83. Bond of judge and court clerk.
The clerk of the court shall give bond in the form provided by 12 O.S. § 27-111, in a sum to be determined by the city council. When executed, the bond shall be submitted to the city council for approval. The city council may require that the judge, alternate judge and an acting judge, or any of them, give bond to the city. If bond is required, it shall be in an amount to be fixed by the city, conditioned in the same manner as the bond that is required of the clerk of the court. The bonds of the clerk and any judges shall be approved by the city. When approved, it shall be filed with the clerk of the city and retained in the city archives. 
(Code 1983, § 6-117; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Secs. 12-84—12-109. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. RULES OF PROCEDURE
 
Sec. 12-110. Rules of court.
The judge may prescribe rules, consistent with the laws of the state and with the ordinances of this city, for the proper conduct of the business of the court. 
(Code 1983, § 6-113; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-111. Change of venue, disqualification.
In prosecutions before the court no change of venue shall be allowed from the municipal court, but the judge before whom the case is pending may certify his disqualification or he may be disqualified from sitting under the same terms and conditions provided by law for courts of record. If a judge is disqualified, the matter shall be heard by an alternate or acting judge appointed as provided in this article. 
(Code 1983, § 6-112; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-112. Fees, fines and forfeitures.
All of the fees, fines and forfeitures which come into the municipal court shall be paid by the clerk of the court to the city treasurer. The treasurer shall credit such deposits to the fund designated by the city. The court clerk shall make duplicate receipts for the fees, fines and forfeitures collected by him, one of which shall be retained by the treasurer together with a detailed statement of the items of all costs, the style of the case in which they were paid, and the name of the party paying the same. 
(Code 1983, § 6-118; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-113. Enforcement of rules.
Obedience to the orders, rules and judgments made by the judge or by the court may be enforced by the judge, who may fine or imprison for contempt committed as to him while holding court, or committed against processes issued by him, in the same manner and to the same extent as the district courts of the state. 
(Code 1983, § 6-119; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-114. Written complaints to prosecute ordinance violations.
All prosecutions commenced in the municipal court shall be by complaint which shall be subscribed by the person making complaint and shall be verified before a judge, the court clerk, a deputy court clerk, or a police officer. However, no warrant for arrest shall be issued until the complaint has been approved by the municipal attorney or the judge of the court. All prosecutions for the violation of municipal ordinances shall be styled: The City of Spencer vs. ___________ (naming the person or persons charged). 
(Code 1983, § 6-120; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-115. Fines in lieu of appearance.
The city council by ordinance may prescribe a schedule of fines which the defendant may pay in lieu of his appearance before the court and such payment shall constitute a final determination of the cause against the defendant. 
(Code 1983, § 6-121; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-116. Bail; release on own recognizance; traffic citations.
(a)	Whenever a resident is arrested for the violation of any ordinance, traffic or nontraffic, by a law enforcement officer, the officer shall immediately release such person if he acknowledges receipt of a citation by signing it unless it reasonably appears to the officer that the person may cause injury to himself or others or damage to property if released or that the person will not appear in response to the citation. If such person fails to appear in response to the citation, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest and his appearance shall be compelled. 
(b)	Whenever a resident is arrested by a law enforcement officer for the violation of any ordinance and is not released by being permitted to sign a citation as provided in subsection (a) of this section, he shall be admitted to bail either before or after arraignment, or released on his own recognizance. 
(c)	Whenever a nonresident is arrested for a violation, other than a traffic violation, by a law enforcement officer, the defendant shall be eligible to be admitted to bail before or after arraignment. 
(d)	The city shall require a person who is arrested for a municipal traffic violation by a law enforcement officer to comply with the procedures provided in section 12-120 and by law in 22 O.S. § 1114.1 for state traffic violations with respect to release of the arrested person and the methods of posting bail. 
(e)	The amount and conditions of bail granted under subsection (b) and (c) of this section shall be determined by the judge who shall prescribe rules for the receipt of bail and for the release by recognizance. In the event of arrests at night, or other emergency, or when the judge is not available, the chief of police or his designated representative shall be authorized by the judge under such conditions as shall be prescribed by the judge to accept a temporary cash bond in a sufficient amount to secure the appearance of the accused, but in no event shall the cash bond be more than the maximum fine provided by ordinance for each offense charged. The chief of police or his designated representative is authorized subject to such conditions as shall be prescribed by the judge to release a resident on his own recognizance. 
(Code 1983, § 6-123; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-117. Failure to appear according to terms of bond; forfeiture.
If, without sufficient excuse, a defendant fails to appear according to the terms or conditions of his bond, either for hearing, arraignment, trial or judgment, or upon any other occasion when his presence in court or before the magistrate may be lawfully required, the judge may direct that fact to be entered upon the court minutes, thereby declaring the bond to be forfeited. Court costs shall be collectable from the proceeds of the bond. 
(Code 1983, § 6-124; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-118. Summons for arrest.
(a)	Upon the filing of a complaint charging violation of any ordinance, the judge, unless he determines to issue a warrant of arrest or unless the defendant previously has been issued a citation or has been arrested and has given bond for appearance, he shall issue a summons, naming the person charged, specifying his address or place of residence, if known, stating the offense with which he is charged and giving him notice to answer the charge in the court on a certain day, after the summons is served upon him, and including such other pertinent information as may be necessary. 
(b)	The summons shall be served by delivering a copy to the defendant personally. If he fails to appear and to answer the summons within the prescribed period, a warrant shall be issued for his arrest, as provided by this article. 
(Code 1983, § 6-125)
 
Sec. 12-119. Form of arrest warrant.
(a)	Except as otherwise provided in the ordinances of this city, upon the filing of a complaint approved by the endorsement of the attorney of this city or by the judge, there shall be issued a warrant of arrest, in substantially the following form: 
The City of Spencer to the Marshal of the Municipal Court of Spencer, Oklahoma. 
Complaint upon oath having this day been made by ___________ (naming complainant) that the offense of ___________ (naming the offense in particular but general terms) has been committed and accusing ___________ (name of defendant) thereof, you are commanded therefore forthwith to arrest the above named defendant and bring ___________ before me, at the municipal courtroom, Witness my hand this ___ day of ___________, 20___. 
Judge of the Municipal Criminal Court 
Spencer, Oklahoma. 
(b)	It is the duty of the marshal, personally, or through a duly constituted member of the police force of this city, or through any other person lawfully authorized so to act, to execute a warrant as promptly as possible. 
(Code 1983, § 6-126)
 
Sec. 12-120. Bail procedures for traffic violations.
(a)	In addition to other provisions of law for posting bail, any person, whether a resident of this state or a nonresident, who is arrested by a law enforcement officer solely for a misdemeanor violation of a state traffic law or municipal traffic ordinance shall be released by the arresting officer upon personal recognizance if: 
(1)	The arrested person has been issued a valid license to operate a motor vehicle by this state, another state jurisdiction within the United States, or any party jurisdiction of the nonresident violator compact; 
(2)	The arresting officer is satisfied as to the identity of the arrested person; 
(3)	The arrested person signs a written promise to appear as provided for on the citation; and 
(4)	The violation does not constitute: 
a.	A felony; 
b.	Negligent homicide; 
c.	Driving or being in actual physical control of a motor vehicle while impaired or under the influence of alcohol or other intoxicating substances; 
d.	Eluding or attempting to elude a law enforcement officer; 
e.	Operating a motor vehicle without having been issued a valid driver's license, or while the license is under suspension, revocation, denial or cancellation; 
f.	An arrest based upon an outstanding warrant;. 
g.	A traffic violation coupled with any offense stated in subsections (a)(4)a through (a)(4)f of this section; 
h.	An overweight violation, or the violation of a special permit exceeding the authorized permit weight; or 
i.	A violation relating to the transportation of hazardous materials. 
(b)	If the arrested person is eligible for release on personal recognizance as provided for in subsection (a) of this section, then the arresting officer shall: 
(1)	Designate the traffic charge; 
(2)	Record information from the arrested person's driver's license on the citation form, including the name, address, date of birth, personal description, type of driver's license, driver's license number, issuing state, and expiration date; 
(3)	Record the motor vehicle make, model and tag information; 
(4)	Record the arraignment date and time on the citation; and 
(5)	Permit the arrested person to sign a written promise to appear as provided for in the citation. 
The arresting officer shall then release the person upon personal recognizance based upon the signed promise to appear. The citation shall contain a written notice to the arrested person that release upon personal recognizance based upon a signed written promise to appear for arraignment is conditional and that failure to timely appear for arraignment shall result in the suspension of the arrested person's driver's license in this state, or in the nonresident's home state pursuant to the nonresident violator compact. 
(c)	Procedures for arraignment, continuances and scheduling, timely appearances, pleas of guilty or nolo contendere, posting bail, payment of fines and costs, issuance of arrest warrants, and requests for suspension of driver's license, shall be required in, 22 OS §§ 1115.1 through 1115.5. 
(d)	A defendant released upon personal recognizance may elect to enter a plea of guilty or nolo contendere to the violation charged at any time before he is required to appear for arraignment by indicating such plea on the copy of the citation furnished to him or on a legible copy thereof, together with the date of the plea and his signature. The defendant shall be responsible for assuring full payment of the fine and costs to the court clerk. The defendant shall not use currency for payment by mail. If the defendant has entered a plea of guilty or nolo contendere as provided for in this subsection, such plea shall be accepted by the court and the amount of the fine and costs shall be as prescribed by ordinance for the violation charged or as prescribed by the court. 
(e)	If, pursuant to the provisions of subsection (d) of this section, the defendant does not timely elect to enter a plea of guilty or nolo contendere and fails to timely appear for arraignment, the court may issue a warrant for the arrest of the defendant and the municipal or district court clerk, within 120 calendar days from the date the citation was issued by the arresting officer, shall notify the state department of public safety that: 
(1)	The defendant was issued a traffic citation and released upon personal recognizance after signing a written promise to appear for arraignment as provided for in the citation; 
(2)	The defendant has failed to appear for arraignment without good cause shown; 
(3)	The defendant has not posted bail, paid a fine, or made any other arrangement with the court to satisfy the citation; and 
(4)	The citation has not been satisfied as provided by law. 
(f)	The court clerk shall request the state department of public safety to either suspend the defendant's driver's license to operate a motor vehicle in this state, or notify the defendant's home state and request suspension of the defendant's driver's license in accordance with the provisions of the nonresident violator compact. Such notice and request shall be on a form approved or furnished by the state department of public safety. The court clerk shall not process the notification and request provided for in this subsection if, with respect to such charges: 
(1)	The defendant was arraigned, posted bail, paid a fine, was jailed, or otherwise settled the case; 
(2)	The defendant was not released upon personal recognizance upon a signed written promise to appear as provided for in this section or if released, was not permitted to remain on such personal recognizance for arraignment; 
(3)	The violation relates to parking or standing, an overweight violation, an overweight permit, or the transportation of hazardous materials; or 
(4)	A period of 120 calendar days or more has elapsed from the date the citation was issued by the arresting officer. 
(g)	The court clerk shall maintain a record of each request for driver's license suspension submitted to the state department of public safety pursuant to the provisions of this section. When the court or court clerk receives appropriate bail or payment of the fine and costs, settles the citation, makes other arrangements with the defendant, or otherwise closes the case, the court clerk shall furnish proof thereof to such defendant, if the defendant personally appears, or shall mail such proof by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the defendant at the address noted on the citation or at such other address as is furnished by the defendant. Additionally, the court or court clerk shall notify the home jurisdiction of the defendant as listed on the citation, if such jurisdiction is a member of the nonresident violator compact, and shall in all other cases, notify the state department of public safety of the resolution of the case. The form of proof and the procedures for notification shall be approved by the state department of public safety; provided, however, the court or court clerk's failure to furnish such proof or notice in the manner provided for in this subsection shall in no event create any civil liability upon the court, the court clerk, the state or any political subdivision thereof, or any state department or agency or any employee thereof but duplicate proof shall be furnished to the person entitled thereto upon request. 
(Code 1983, § 6-127)
 
Sec. 12-121. Arraignment and pleadings by defendant.
Upon making his appearance before the court, the defendant shall be arraigned. The arraignment shall be made by the court. The judge or the prosecuting attorney shall read the complaint to the defendant, inform him of his legal rights, including the right of trial by jury, if available, and of the consequences of conviction, and ask him whether he pleads guilty or not guilty. If the defendant pleads guilty, the court may proceed to judgment and sentence or may continue the matter for subsequent disposition. If the plea is not guilty, and the case is not for jury trial, the court may proceed to try the case, or may set it for hearing at a later date. 
(Code 1983, § 6-128; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-122. Procedure; judicial notice of statutes and ordinances; writs and processes.
The code or procedure in the municipal court, except as may be otherwise provided herein, shall be the same as is now provided by law for the trial of misdemeanors. The court shall take judicial notice of state statutes and the ordinances of the city in which it is located. Writs and processes of the court may be issued by the judge or clerk thereof to any proper officer. 
(Code 1983, § 6-129; Ord. No. 142A, 6-11-1981)
 
Sec. 12-123. Trial by jury and waiver.
(a)	In all prosecutions for violations of ordinances punishable by fine of more than $100.00, including costs, or by imprisonment, or by both fine and imprisonment, trial shall be by jury, unless waived by the defendant and the city. If trial by jury is waived, and for all other offenses, trial shall be to the court. 
(b)	A jury in the court shall consist of six jurors, good and lawful men or women, citizens of the county in which the court sits, possessing the qualifications of jurors in district court. A verdict of the jury may be rendered by the vote of five jurors. 
(c)	At arraignment, the defendant shall be asked whether he demands or waives trial by jury. His election shall be recorded in the minutes of the arraignment and entered on the docket of the court respecting proceedings in the case. 
(d)	An election waiving jury trial, made at arraignment, may be changed by the defendant at any time prior to the day for which trial by the court is set; an election demanding jury trial may be changed at any time prior to the commencement of proceedings to impanel the jury for the trial, but if that change occurs after the case has been set for jury trial, it may not thereafter be rechanged so as again to demand trial by jury. 
(Code 1983, § 6-130)
 
Sec. 12-124. Selection and summons of jurors.
Jurors in the municipal court shall be selected under the same terms and conditions as are provided for by law for the district courts.
