(b)	Each mechanical or computer generated telephone call made to a telephone located within the city limits shall, at the beginning of each presentation, state the following: 
(1)	Name of the company which generated the telephone call; 
(2)	Street mailing address of the company; 
(3)	Working telephone number of the company; 
(4)	Name of the chief executive officer of the company; 
(5)	If the company generating the call is representing a separate company, the information required by subsections (b)(1) through (b)(4) of this section shall also be included for the represented company; and 
(6)	Prior to any presentation, the purpose of the call, such as, but not limited to, sales presentation, request for donation, etc. 
(c)	Each such mechanical or computer generated telephone call generated to a telephone located within the city shall be so designed such that if the recipient of the telephone call should disconnect prior to the end of the message or computer program, the mechanical device or computer shall also disconnect, thereby clearing the telephone line for other incoming or outgoing telephone calls from the recipient's telephone. 
(d)	Each such mechanical or computer generated telephone call made to telephones located within the city which does not comply with the requirements contained within this section shall constitute an offense. 
(Code 1983, § 8-418; Ord. No. 307-A-91, 3-14-1991)
 
Secs. 28-182—28-200. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE VII. OFFENSES BY OR RELATING TO MINORS
 
Sec. 28-201. Purpose.
The purpose of this article is to curb the increasing problem of juvenile crime; to educate and reform juvenile offenders, to punish juvenile offenders, and to create an environment whereby adults and juveniles take responsibility for the actions of juveniles. It is further intended by this article to continue to hold neglectful or careless parents to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall not be a defense to the committing of any violation of any offense contained in this article that a parent, guardian or any other person whose responsibility it is to exercise control over a minor, was completely unaware or indifferent to the activities, conduct or whereabouts of such minor. 
(Code 1983, § 10-802; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-202. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Curfew hours means those hours during the period ending at 6:00 a.m. all days of the week, and beginning at 12:00 midnight on Sunday through Thursday and 1:00 a.m. on Friday and Saturday night. 
Minor means any person under 18 years of age. Furthermore, the term "minor" shall be synonymous with the term juvenile. 
Parent means any person having legal custody of a minor: 
(1)	As a natural or adoptive parent; 
(2)	As a legal guardian; 
(3)	As a person who stands in loco parentis; or 
(4)	As a person to whom legal custody has been given by order of a court. 
Public place means any street, alley, highway, sidewalk, park, playground or place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose. A public place shall include, but not be limited to, any store, shop, restaurant, tavern, bowling alley, cafe, theater, drugstore, poolroom, shopping center and any other place devoted to amusement or entertainment of the general public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of the above. 
Remain means to stay behind, to tarry and to stay unnecessarily upon the streets, including the congregating of groups (or of interacting minors) totaling four or more persons in which any minor involved would not be using the streets for ordinary or serious purposes such as mere passage or going home. 
Street means a way or place, of whatsoever nature, open to the use of the public as a matter of right for purposes of vehicular travel or, in the case of a sidewalk, for pedestrian travel. The term "street" includes the legal right-of-way, the cartway or traffic lanes, the curb, the sidewalks whether paved or unpaved, and any grass plots or other grounds found within the legal right-of-way of a street. 
Time of night means based upon the prevailing standard of time, whether central standard time or central daylight-saving time generally observed at that hour by the public. 
Year of age continues from one birthday, such as the 17th to, but not including the day of, the next, such as the 18th birthday, making it clear that 17 or less years of age is herein treated as equivalent to the phrase "under 18 years of age." 
(Code 1983, § 10-803; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-203. Original jurisdiction of municipal court in certain juvenile cases.
The municipal court of the city may elect to have and possess original jurisdiction to hear and determine any offenses committed by persons under 18 years of age and penalize juveniles found guilty as allowed by state law. 
(Code 1983, § 10-804; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-204. Curfew for minors.
(a)	It is unlawful for any person 17 or less years of age (under 18 years of age) to be or remain in or upon the streets within the city at night during the period ending 6:00 a.m. and beginning: 
(1)	At 11:00 p.m. for minors 14 years of age or younger; 
(2)	At 12:00 midnight for minors more than 14 years of age on Sunday through Thursday; and 
(3)	At 1:00 a.m. on Saturday morning and Sunday morning for minors more than 14 years of age. 
(b)	In the following exceptional cases a minor on a city street during the nocturnal hours for which subsection (c) of this section is intended to provide the maximum limits of regulation shall not, however, be considered in violation of the curfew ordinance: 
(1)	When accompanied by a parent of such minor; 
(2)	When accompanied by an adult authorized by a parent of such minor to take the parent's place in accompanying the minor for a designated period of time and purpose within a specified area; 
(3)	When exercising first amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech and the right of assembly. Such minor shall provide evidence of the bona fides of such exercise by possessing a written communication, signed by such minor and countersigned, by a parent of such minor with their home address and telephone number, specifying when, and where and in what manner the minor will be on the streets at night (during hours when the curfew ordinance is otherwise applicable to the minor) in the exercise of a first amendment right specified in such communication; 
(4)	In case of reasonable necessity, but only if the minor has in the minor's possession a written communication signed by the minor, countersigned by a parent of such minor evidencing their home address and telephone number, and establishing such reasonable necessity relating to specified streets at a designated time for a described purpose including points of origin and destination; 
(5)	When the minor is on the sidewalk of the place where such minor resides, or on the sidewalk of either next door neighbor not communicating an objection to the police officer; 
(6)	When returning home, by a direct route from (and within 30 minutes of the termination of) a school activity or activity of a religious or the voluntary association, provided the minor has a written communication in the minor's possession, countersigned by a parent indicating the home address and telephone number, the purpose for the event when, where and in what manner the minor will be on the streets at night; 
(7)	When authorized, by regulation issued by the city council, in other similar cases of reasonable necessity, similarly handled but adopted to necessary nighttime activities of more minors than can readily be dealt with on an individual special permit basis. Normally such regulation by the city council permitting use of the streets should be issued sufficiently in advance to permit appropriate publicity through news media and through other agencies such as the schools, and shall define the activity, the scope of the use of the streets permitted, the period of time involved not to extend more than 30 minutes beyond the time for termination of such activity, and the reason for finding that such regulation is reasonably necessary and is consistent with the public interest and the purposes of this section; 
(8)	When the minor carries a certified card of employment, briefly identifying the minor, the addresses of his home and his place of employment or carries a valid proof of employment which may include the latest payroll receipt not over 30 days old; or 
(9)	When the minor is, with parental consent, in a motor vehicle. This contemplates normal travel. This clearly exempts bona fide interstate movement through the city, particularly on normal routes. 
(c)	It is unlawful for a parent having legal custody of a minor knowingly to permit or by inefficient control to allow such minor to be or remain upon any city street under circumstances not constituting an exception to, or otherwise beyond the scope of, the curfew ordinance. The term "knowingly" includes knowledge which a parent should reasonably be expected to have concerning the whereabouts of a minor in that parent's legal custody. It is intended to continue to keep neglectful or careless parents up to a reasonable community standard of parental responsibility through an objective test. It shall be no defense that a parent was completely indifferent to the activities or conduct or whereabouts of such minor. 
(d)	It shall be unlawful for any person operating or having charge of any public place to knowingly allow, permit or suffer the presence of minors in violation of the curfew established by this article. 
(e)	Upon finding or having attention called to any minor on the streets in prima facie violation of the curfew ordinance, a police officer of the city shall normally take the minor to the city police station, or other place designated by the chief of police, where a parent shall immediately be notified to come for such minor, whereupon they shall be interviewed. This is intended to permit ascertainment, under constitutional safeguards, of relevant facts, and to centralize responsibility in the personnel then on duty for accurate, effective, fair, impartial and uniform enforcement, and recording, thus making available experienced supervisory personnel, the best facilities and access to information and records. In the absence of convincing evidence such as a birth certificate, a police officer on the street shall in the first instance use his best judgment in determining age: 
(1)	Police procedures shall constantly be refined in the light of experience and may provide, inter alia, that the police officer may deliver to a parent thereof a minor under appropriate circumstances. For example, a minor of tender age near home whose identity may readily be ascertained or is known; 
(2)	In any event such police officer shall within 24 hours, file a written report with the chief of police. The report shall be treated for purposes of juvenile records in accordance with state statutes; 
(3)	When a parent, immediately called, has come to take charge of the minor, and the appropriate information has been recorded, the minor shall be released to the custody of such parent. If the parent cannot be located, or fails to take charge of the minor, then the minor shall be released to the juvenile authorities, except to the extent that in accordance with police regulations, approved in advance by juvenile authorities, the minor may temporarily be entrusted to a relative, neighbor or other person who will, on behalf of a parent, assume the responsibility of caring for the minor pending the availability or arrival of a parent; or 
(4)	In the case of first violation by a minor, the chief of police shall cause to be personally delivered or by certified mail, send to a parent written notice of violation with a warning that any subsequent violation shall result in full enforcement of the curfew ordinance, including enforcement of parental responsibility and of applicable penalties. 
(f)	If after the warning notice pursuant to subsection (e)(4) of this section of a first violation by a minor, a parent violates section 28-206 (in connection with a second violation by the minor), this shall be treated as an offense by the parent. 
(Code 1983, § 10-805; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-205. Allowing or encouraging a minor to commit offenses; penalty.
It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly or willfully aid, abet, allow, and encourage or, by omission of a duty, encourage or assist a minor to commit any municipal, state or federal offense. 
(Code 1983, § 10-806; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-206. Parental responsibility; failure to control; penalty.
(a)	Failure to control. It shall be unlawful for any parent to fail to control a minor that is under the parent's supervision by, after notification of a prior offense committed by the minor, failing to prevent the minor from committing the same offense or more than one other offense within one year of the date the minor committed the first offense. 
(b)	Written promise to return child to court to answer charges. When a minor child taken into police custody for violation of a municipal ordinance is released to the personal custody of the child's parent, legal guardian, legal custodian or other responsible adult such person shall sign a written promise to return the child to the municipal court to answer the municipal charges on the date and at the time set by the municipal court and to assume responsibility for cost for damages by the child if the child causes damages while committing any acts in violation of municipal ordinance after being released. As provided in 10A O.S. § 2-2-102, the failure of the parent, legal guardian, legal custodian or other responsible adult to comply with the written promise shall constitute an offense and the penalty for violation of this subsection shall be as provided in section 1-8. 
(c)	Parent refusing responsibility shall constitute offense. As provided in 10A O.S. § 2-2-102, the refusal of the parent, legal guardian or legal custodian to assume custody of a minor child taken into police custody for violation of a municipal ordinance shall constitute an offense and the penalty for violation of this subsection shall be as provided in section 1-8. 
(Code 1983, § 10-807; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998; Ord. No. 493-01-07, 2-21-2008)
 
Sec. 28-207. Commission of a crime in the presence of minors; penalty.
It shall be unlawful for any person to commit any municipal, state or federal offense in the presence of any person under 18 years of age. 
(Code 1983, § 10-808; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-208. Permitting crimes or disorderliness on premises; penalty.
No owner, operator, proprietor, manager or employee of any place shall permit minors who have congregated on the premises to commit any offense, or to carouse, make unnecessary noises, disturb, disrupt or annoy the people residing or carrying on business in the immediate neighborhood or so as to disturb the peace. Furthermore, no owner, operator, proprietor, manager or employee of any place shall permit any minor to loiter, litter or cause any disturbance on the property of a neighboring resident or business. 
(Code 1983, § 10-809; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-209. Truancy; penalty.
(a)	It shall be unlawful for a parent of a minor who is over the age of six years and under the age of 18 years, to neglect or refuse to cause or compel such minor to attend and comply with the rules of a public, private or other school of the parent's choosing in which the minor is enrolled. 
(b)	It shall be unlawful for any minor who is over the age of six and who has not finished four years of high school work, to neglect or refuse to attend and comply with the rules of some public, private or other school, or receive an education by other means for the full term the schools of the district in which the minor attends are in session; provided that this section shall not apply: 
(1)	If any such minor is prevented from attending school by reason of mental or physical disability, as determined by the board of education of the district upon a certificate of the school physician or public health physician or, if no such physician is available, a duly licensed and practicing physician; 
(2)	If any such minor is excused from attendance at school, due to an emergency, by the principal of the school in which the minor is enrolled, at the request of the parent of the minor; 
(3)	If any such minor is excused from attending school by: 
a.	The administrator of the school or district where the minor attends school; and 
b.	The parent of the minor. 
Provided, further, that no minor be excused from attending school by such joint agreement between a school administrator and the parent of the minor unless and until it has been determined that such action is in the best interest of the minor and/or the community, and that said minor thereafter is under the supervision of the parent until the minor has reached the age of 18 years; and 
(4)	If any such minor is observing religious holy days if prior to the absence, the parent of the minor submits a written request for the absence. The school district shall excuse a student pursuant to this subsection for the days on which the religious holy days are observed and for the days on which the student must travel to and from the site where the student will observe the holy days. 
(c)	Any parent convicted of violating any provision in this section shall be punished as provided in the city fine schedule by a fine of not more than $200.00, plus costs, or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each separate day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(d)	Any minor convicted of violating any provision in this section shall be punished as provided in the city fine schedule on the first offense by a fine of not more than $50.00, on the second offense by a fine of not more than $100.00, and on every subsequent offense by a fine of not more than $200.00, plus costs. Each separate day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1983, § 10-810; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Sec. 28-210. Furnishing tobacco products to minors; minors in possession of tobacco products; penalty.
Any person who shall furnish to any minor by gift, sale or otherwise any cigarettes, cigarette papers, cigars, snuff, chewing tobacco or any other form of tobacco product shall be guilty of an offense. It shall be an offense for any minor to be in possession of any cigarettes, cigarette papers, cigars, snuff, chewing tobacco or any other form of tobacco product. 
(Code 1983, § 10-811; Ord. No. 383-11-98, 11-12-1998)
 
Chapter 30 PARKS AND RECREATION
 
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
 
Sec. 30-1. Employment and duties of parks superintendent.
A parks superintendent shall be an employee of the city. The parks superintendent shall be appointed by the city manager for an indefinite term and removable by the city manager. The parks superintendent shall have supervision and control of all park equipment and facilities. The superintendent shall delegate all park related tasks as deemed necessary for the maintenance and the upkeep of facilities to appropriate staff. The superintendent and staff shall maintain, improve and operate the parks and other recreational facilities of the city and any recreational programs now or hereafter carried on by the city. 
(Code 1983, § 11-202; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Secs. 30-2—30-20. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE II. PARKS ADVISORY BOARD
 
Sec. 30-21. Creation and duties.
(a)	The purpose of this article is to foster and promote the maintenance and operation of city parks and recreational facilities through the creation of parks policy and project oversight. 
(b)	There is hereby created a parks advisory board that shall be composed of seven members who are to be appointed by the city council. Members shall be appointed to a four-year term. 
(c)	In the event that a vacancy on the parks advisory board comes open before the four-year term is expired, another person shall be appointed by the city council to fill out that term. 
(d)	If the membership of the parks advisory board drops to less than three members, the parks advisory board shall cease to operate until such time that new members are appointed. During such time the city manager or his designee shall work with existing members to provide direction of parks programs, maintenance, and project oversight until the parks advisory board resumes operation. 
(e)	Any parks advisory board member may be removed at any time by a vote of the city council. Likewise, the parks advisory board by majority vote may request removal of a fellow parks board member with council approval. Parks board members may resign at any time by submitting written notice to the city council. 
(f)	All votes of the parks advisory board shall pass with a simple majority. 
(g)	The parks advisory board shall create a yearly project list for each public park. The list shall outline all projects to be completed for each public park, including, but not limited to, renovation, new construction, demolition, and monthly maintenance. 
(h)	The project list shall be submitted to the city council for approval at the first regular city council meeting in April. 
(i)	The city manager shall be responsible for seeing to the completion of the projects on the list. The city manager may delegate authority as necessary. 
(j)	The project list may be amended by the parks advisory board, pending approval by the city council at the next scheduled city council meeting. 
(k)	The city manager may alter the project list in the case of an emergency. 
(l)	The parks advisory board shall maintain a calendar of events for each park. 
(m)	The parks advisory board shall make recommendations to the city council concerning fees, security, and cleanup for the events. 
(n)	The parks advisory board shall seek volunteer assistance and grants to aid the city manager in the completion of the projects. 
(o)	The parks advisory board shall meet at least once a month with the city manager or the city manager's representative to discuss the project list and upcoming events. 
(Code 1983, § 11-201; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. 485-03-06, 8-17-2006)
 
Sec. 30-22. Organization and procedures.
The parks advisory board, upon the appointment of its members, shall organize by election of one of its members as chairman; another of its members as vice chairman to preside at meetings. The parks advisory board, with city council approval, shall make such rules or procedures, as it deems appropriate for the transaction of park related business. 
(Code 1983, § 11-203; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Sec. 30-23. Minutes.
The city clerk or his designee shall record and maintain the minutes of the proceedings of the parks advisory board and submit same to the city council after each meeting. The parks advisory board shall be subject to the provisions of the state open meetings and open records law. 
(Code 1983, § 11-204; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Sec. 30-24. Regular meetings.
The parks advisory board shall meet at least once each month, or such other time as the board may designate, or at such times as the city council may request. The parks advisory board shall be subject to the provisions of the Oklahoma Open Meetings and Open Records Act. 
(Code 1983, § 11-205; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Sec. 30-25. Absence from meetings.
The provisions of 11 O.S. § 8-108 shall govern absence of the parks advisory board members from regular and special meetings. 
(Code 1983, § 11-206; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Secs. 30-26—30-53. Reserved.
 
ARTICLE III. PARK RULES
 
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
 
Sec. 30-54. Hours of operation.
All city parks and recreational areas shall be opened from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. from April to September and from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. from October to March unless otherwise allowed through the purchase of a permit through the city. It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to occupy the parks' facilities other than during these hours specified in this section. 
(Code 1983, § 11-101; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Sec. 30-55. Posting signs.
The city manager or his designee shall post signs indicating the hours of operation of each public park operating within the city. Signs shall be posted at the front entrance of each public park. No other signs or advertisements shall be posted within any public park facility unless otherwise permitted by subsection 30-86(a). 
(Code 1983, § 11-102; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Sec. 30-56. Acts prohibited in city parks.
(a)	The following acts are prohibited in city parks: 
(1)	Moving or displacing rock, soil, or gravel, or digging holes. 
(2)	Damaging, destroying, displacing or removing trees, shrubs, picnic tables or picnic seats, signs, fences, or any other public property, including fireplaces, water lines, or other public utilities. 
(3)	Dumping, depositing or leaving any bottles, broken glass, paper, boxes, cans, rubbish, waste, garbage, refuse or other trash, except in proper receptacles. 
(4)	Taking part in activities involving throwing or otherwise propelling objects such as stones, arrows, javelins, and other dangerous games. No firearms may be discharged in the park areas. 
(b)	No private enterprise, corporate enterprise, other business of any nature, nor nonprofit or charitable organization including, but not limited to, garage sales, bake sales, displays or solicitations of any kind, may use any public park property for the purpose of conducting any business or enterprise, or conduct sales or other money generating activities without application to and approval of the city manager or his designated representative. Nothing in this section shall prevent the city from permitting city operated or city sponsored programs and events or creating a lease with individuals for the use of city park property to operate, or cause to be operated, concessions, services, or events as allowed under the terms and requirements as set out in the lease. Such leases shall be considered by the city council, upon the recommendation of the city parks advisory board. 
(Code 1983, § 11-103; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Secs. 30-57—30-85. Reserved.
 
DIVISION 2. PERMITS
 
Sec. 30-86. Required.
(a)	A permit is required for any group using any public park facility. The facility use price list is set forth in the city fee schedule. Permits for the use of any public park facility shall be issued by the city on printed forms, which have been signed and approved by the city or its officials. 
(b)	The rodeo arena at Kringlen Park can be reserved for individual or instructional uses by contacting the parks advisory board. 
(c)	With the exception of individual and/or instructional uses, no verbal agreement for the use of any public park facility shall be binding upon the city. 
(d)	All advertisements or signs attached to the rodeo arena, ball field, or pavilion shall be charged an advertisement fee as provided in the city fee schedule to be renewed annually and paid to the city. 
(e)	Camping will be allowed in set-aside areas with deposits and per-day charges as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(f)	The permittee shall accept the permit issued by the city for any use of any public park facility, and such permit, when so accepted, shall constitute the contract between the city and the permittee, which permit shall be subject to approval of the city and as to the form thereof shall be approved by the city attorney. 
(g)	The city may cancel the contract of any person or organization as to the use of any public park facility when such person or organization, in the opinion of the city manager or city council, is not acting for the best public interest. 
(h)	By acceptance of a permit as hereinabove provided, the permittee shall covenant and agree to relieve and discharge the city and the officers and employees of the city from any and all liability for loss and injury and damages to any person or property that may be sustained by reason of the occupancy and use of any public park facility, and to save them free and harmless therefrom. Every permittee shall further agree to pay for any and all damages to any public park facility and damages to or loss of any public property and equipment of the city resulting either directly or indirectly from such occupancy and use of a public park facility, by or through the negligence or other acts of the permittee, his agents and employees or any person participating in or attending the performance, attraction or affair in connection with or during the use and occupancy; provided, however, that the city may, whenever in its opinion the circumstances may warrant the same, require that such permittee shall secure and indemnify the city, and such other persons as the city shall designate, against any and all such liability, loss, injury and damage by procuring, paying for and keeping in force a policy of liability or indemnity insurance or a surety bond, for such purpose, which policy of insurance or bond shall be written and issued by a reputable and solvent insurance or surety company, as the case may be, authorized to do business in the state, and such policy or bond shall be subject to approval as to form thereof by the city attorney. 
(i)	The payment of all federal, state, county and city taxes in connection with any attraction shall always be the responsibility of the permittee. 
(j)	Nothing herein shall be construed to prevent the use of a public park or any part of facility thereof for municipal purposes, subject to the approval of the city; except, however, that when an admission fee is charged or revenues from such municipal usage or other privileges of any character operated by or under the authority of representatives of the city, the city shall collect out of the gross receipts or any other revenues therefrom and pay over and deposit with the treasurer of the city not less than an amount equal to the actual operating and gross overhead expense incidental to such usage as computed by the city, nor more than the maximum rental rates and other charges as prescribed by this chapter. 
(k)	The rental of a public park at the rates herein provided shall not entitle the permittee to any personnel service in connection with the staging of the event or attraction for which the permit is issued; provided, however, that the city may, at its discretion, furnish at no extra cost to the permittee the services of those employees of the city who are regularly employed. Such services shall not include extra services as set forth in the schedule of rentals. The permittee shall hire and pay the salaries of all other employees, including workers' compensation, required in connection with the event or attraction. 
(l)	All lessees, permittees, licensees, concessionaires and their agents and employees shall at all times conform to all rules and regulations for the use and occupancy of, and operations in a public park facility as adopted, issued and ordained from time to time by the city council of the city. Any violation of such rules and regulations by any of the foregoing persons mentioned in this section shall, at the discretion of the city, subject such violator to immediate expulsion from a public park and the forfeiture of all rents, percentages or other fees required to be paid under such permit for the full term thereof. 
(m)	Each lessee, permittee, licensee, concessionaire and/or his employees shall at all times strictly comply with and abide by all federal, state or municipal laws and ordinances pertaining to or affecting the use or occupancy of any public park located within the corporate boundaries of the city. Inspections shall be conducted by the city code enforcement and fire department to ensure safety in regards to electrical hookups, extension cords, and other types of fire hazards. 
(n)	Concessionaires selling perishable items at a public park within the corporate boundaries of the city will obtain appropriate inspections and permits from the city-county health department for the safety and the health of the public. Proof of inspection by the city-county health department must be displayed no less than two hours prior to the event and kept on display through the duration of the event. 
(o)	All vendors conducting business for profit at a public park facility shall comply with the fee schedule included in subsection (a) of this section. Vendors must make application to the city and place approved permit on display during the course of the respective event for public view and city inspection. Violators will become subject to a fine in the amount provided in the city fine schedule. 
(p)	Unless otherwise permitted, lessees, permittees, licensees, or concessionaires setup for events will be allowed no more than four hours prior to the event. Lessees, permittees, licensees, concessionaires will be required to remove all trash, equipment, etc., no less than four hours after the conclusion of the event. 
(q)	Every lessee, permittee, licensee, or concessionaire shall furnish such police protection as may be required by the city during his occupancy. If any lessee, permittee, licensee, and/or concessionaire fails or refuses to furnish police protection satisfactory to the city, the city may furnish the same and charge the cost thereof to the same, or cancel the event. 
(r)	Property or equipment left over 30 days at a public park facility shall become the property of the city. 
(s)	Any repairs requested by the renter shall be submitted no less than 15 days prior to the event. 
(t)	Any unapproved repairs performed by the renter shall be done at the renter's expense. 
(u)	Deposit fees must be paid 30 days in advance of the event. 
(Code 1983, § 11-301; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003; Ord. No. 525-08-09, § 1, 8-20-2009)
 
Sec. 30-87. Permits and fees waived.
Events sponsored by charitable organizations or events involving youth related functions may request, in writing with justification, a fee waiver for permits and fees from the city council. 
(Code 1983, § 11-302; Ord. No. 433-09-03, 9-18-2003)
 
Chapter 32 SIGNS AND ADVERTISING
 
Sec. 32-1. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Erect means to build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend, or affix, and also includes the painting of wall signs. 
Facing or surface means any surface of the sign upon, against, or through which the message is displayed or illustrated on the sign. 
Illuminated sign means any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outlines illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as part of the sign proper. 
Incombustible material means any material which will not ignite at or below a temperature of 1200 degrees Fahrenheit and will not continue to burn or glow at that temperature. 
Non-illuminated sign means any sign which has characters, letters, figures, designs or outlines which is not illuminated by electric lights or luminous tubes as a part of the sign proper. 
Other advertising structure means any marquee, canopy, awning or street clock as further defined herein. 
Sign means and includes every sign, billboard, ground sign, wall sign, roof sign, illuminated sign, non-illuminated sign, projecting sign, temporary sign, marquee, awning, canopy and street clock, and includes any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display illustration or insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any person when it is placed out of doors in view of the general public. 
Sign contractor means any person, firm or corporation engaged in the business of manufacturing, installing, erecting, repairing, altering, servicing or removing signs as hereinabove defined. 
Structural trim means the molding, battens, cappings, nailing strips, latticing, and platforms which are attached to the sign structure. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.2; Code 1983, § 5-1401)
 
Sec. 32-2. Sign contractor's license.
(a)	No person, firm or corporation, except a licensed sign contractor, is to engage in the business of manufacturing, installing, erecting, repairing, altering, servicing or removing signs. A sign contractor's license may be obtained from the city clerk and a fee as provided in the city fee schedule for illuminated sign contractor or for a non-illuminated sign contractor is to be paid to the city clerk therefor. Such license expires one year from date of issuance. Employees of duly licensed sign contractors are not required to obtain such license or pay a fee in order to engage in the work of manufacturing, installing, erecting, repairing, altering, servicing or removing signs in the regular course of employment. 
(b)	Duly licensed electrical contractors are not required to obtain a license hereunder where the contractors are only installing wiring to electrical signs in the course of their business as electrical contractors. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.3; Code 1983, § 5-1402)
 
Sec. 32-3. Sign contractor's bond.
No sign contractor's license shall be issued until the applicant therefor has deposited with the city clerk a surety bond in the sum of $5,000.00 to be known as "sign contractor's bond." Such bond shall be executed by the sign contractor and the surety thereon shall be a corporate surety company authorized to do business in the state. The bond shall be in favor of the city and conditioned that the licensee will faithfully and properly conduct his business in compliance with all of the ordinances of the city relating to signs and sign contractors and for the payment of all fines and penalties imposed for the violation of such laws and for the protection and indemnification of the city against all damages resulting directly or indirectly from any injury to persons or property on account of the negligence or unskilled work of the licensee. Such bond shall be renewed annually and no person, firm or corporation engages in the business of a sign contractor unless a bond, as herein provided, is on file with the city clerk and in full force. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.4; Code 1983, § 5-1403)
 
Sec. 32-4. Permits required.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to erect, alter or re-locate within the city any sign or other advertising structure as defined in this chapter without first obtaining a permit from the city clerk and making payment of the fee required by this chapter. All illuminated signs are, in addition, subject to the provisions of the electrical code, and where the electrical code does not cover, the Underwriter's Laboratories Inc. standard for electric signs shall cover, and the permit fees required thereunder. No person, other than a duly authorized sign contractor, shall be issued such permit. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-8.5, 3-1-77; Code 1983, § 5-1404)
 
Sec. 32-5. Application for erection permit.
Application for erection permits shall be made upon blanks provided by the city clerk and contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)	Name, address and telephone number of the applicant; 
(2)	Location of building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the sign or other advertising structure is to be attached or erected; 
(3)	Position of the sign or other advertising structure in relation to nearby buildings or structures; 
(4)	Two blueprints or ink drawings of the plans and specifications and method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground, when required by the building inspector; 
(5)	Copy of stress sheets and calculations showing the structure is designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount required by this and all other laws and ordinances of the city, when required by the building inspector; 
(6)	Name of person or association erecting structure; and 
(7)	Such other information as the building inspector requires to show full compliance with this and all other laws and ordinances of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.6; Code 1983, § 5-1405)
 
Sec. 32-6. Illuminated signs; approval by electrical inspector.
The application for a permit for erection of a sign or other advertising structure in which electrical wiring and connections are to be used shall be submitted to the electrical inspector if required by the building inspector. The electrical inspector shall examine the plans and specifications respecting all wiring and connections to determine if it complies with the electrical code of the city or Underwriters Laboratories standard for electrical signs. The building inspector shall approve the permit if the plans and specifications comply with the code, or disapprove the application if noncompliance with the code is found. This action of the electrical inspector shall take place prior to submission of the application to the engineering department for final approval or disapproval of the erection permit. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.7; Code 1983, § 5-1406)
 
Sec. 32-7. Permit issued if application in order.
It is the duty of the building inspector upon the filing of an application for an erection permit to examine such plans and specifications and other data and the premises upon which it is proposed to erect the sign or other advertising structure, and if it appears that the proposed structure is in compliance with all the requirements of this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the city, he then issues the erection permit. If the work authorized under an erection permit has not been completed within one year after date of issuance, the permit becomes null and void. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.8; Code 1983, § 5-1407)
 
Sec. 32-8. Permit fees.
(a)	Fee for permits under this chapter shall be in the amount provided in the city fee schedule. 
(b)	For the purpose of computing the square foot area of any sign, the total opposite overall dimensions in the two widest parts is used. This area is considered solid with no openings deducted. 
(c)	It is unlawful and an offense to commence the erection of any sign or advertising structure without obtaining a permit therefor and the amounts of any and all fees above established shall be tripled if the erection of any sign or other advertising structure is commenced prior to the issuance of a permit therefor. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-8.9, 3-1-9; Code 1983, § 5-1408)
 
Sec. 32-9. Inspection.
The building inspector shall inspect at such times as he deems necessary each sign or other advertising structure regulated by this chapter for the purpose of ascertaining whether it is secure or insecure, and whether it is in need of removal or repair. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.10; Code 1983, § 5-1409)
 
Sec. 32-10. Unsafe and unlawful signs.
If the building inspector finds that any sign or other advertising structure regulated herein is unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter, he gives written notice to the permittee or owner thereof. If the permittee or owner fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards herein set forth within ten days after such notice, such sign or other advertising structure may be removed or altered to comply by the building inspector at the expense of the permittee or owner of the property upon which it is located. The city clerk, upon recommendations of the building inspector, shall refuse to issue further permits to any permittee or owner who refuses to pay costs so assessed. The building inspector may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed summarily and without notice. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.11; Code 1983, § 5-1410)
 
Sec. 32-11. Duty to remove unsafe and unlawful signs.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to maintain a sign which is dangerous to the safety, health or peace of the public. It is the duty of the owner or lessee of such sign and the owner of the property upon which such sign may be located to immediately remove, alter or repair such sign upon receipt of written notification from the building inspector. It is the duty of any person who has erected or who is maintaining any sign or structure in violation of the provisions of this or any ordinance of the city to forthwith remove the same upon receiving notice to do so by the building inspector. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.12; Code 1983, § 5-1411)
 
Sec. 32-12. Number, date, name, and voltage to be on sign.
Every sign or other advertising structure hereafter erected must have painted in a conspicuous place thereon the date of erection, the name of the person, firm or corporation that erected it, and the voltage of any electrical apparatus used in connection therewith. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.13; Code 1983, § 5-1412)
 
Sec. 32-13. Wind pressure and dead load requirements.
All signs and other advertising structures shall be designed and constructed to withstand a wind pressure of not less than 40 pounds per square foot of area and be constructed to receive dead loads as required in the building code or other ordinances of the city. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.14; Code 1983, § 5-1413)
 
Sec. 32-14. Removal of certain signs.
Any sign now or hereafter existing which for a period of more than a year no longer advertises a bona fide business conducted, or a product sold, will be taken down and removed by the owner, agent, or person having the beneficial use of the building or structure upon which such sign may be found within ten days after written notification from the building inspector. Upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in such order, the building inspector is hereby authorized to cause removal of such sign and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of the building or structure to which such sign is attached. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.15; Code 1983, § 5-1414)
 
Sec. 32-15. Exemptions.
The provisions and regulations of this chapter do not apply to the following signs; provided, however, the signs are subject to city building and zoning regulations: 
(1)	Real estate signs not exceeding eight square feet in area which advertise the sale, rental or lease of the premises upon which the signs are located only; 
(2)	Professional name plates not exceeding two square feet in area; 
(3)	Bulletin boards not over eight square feet in area for public, charitable or religious institutions when they are located on the premises of the institutions; 
(4)	Signs denoting the architect, engineer or contractor when placed upon work under construction, and not exceeding 16 square feet in area; 
(5)	Occupational signs denoting only the name and profession of an occupant in a commercial building, public institutional building or dwelling house, and not exceeding two square feet in area; 
(6)	Memorial signs or tablets, names of buildings and date of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other incombustible materials; and 
(7)	Traffic or other municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing signs, danger, and such temporary, emergency or non-advertising signs as may be approved by the city council. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.16; Code 1983, § 5-1415)
 
Sec. 32-16. Obstructions to doors, windows or fire escapes.
No sign shall be erected, re-located or maintained so as to prevent free ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape. No sign of any kind shall be attached to a stand-pipe or fire escape. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.17; Code 1983, § 5-1416)
 
Sec. 32-17. Signs not to constitute traffic hazard.
No sign or other advertising structure as regulated by this chapter shall be erected at the intersection of any streets in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision; or at any location where, by reason of the position, shape or color it may interfere with, obstruct the view of or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or devise; or which makes use of the words "STOP," "LOOK," "DRIVE-IN," "DANGER" or any other word, phrase, symbol or character in such manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. The provisions of this section includes air traffic. No sign or other advertising structure as regulated by this chapter or the city's airport zoning code shall be erected in such a manner that would: 
(1)	Create electrical interference with radio or other electronic communications between the airport and aircraft; 
(2)	Make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others, result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport, impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport; or 
(3)	Otherwise endanger the landing, taking off, or maneuvering of aircraft. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.18; Code 1983, § 5-1417)
 
Sec. 32-18. Handbills posted on telephone and light poles.
Posting of any bills, cards, notices, signs, or advertising of any kind whatsoever, upon any telegraph, telephone, electric light pole or post, or official street sign within the corporate limits of the city is prohibited. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-1; Code 1983, § 5-1418)
 
Sec. 32-19. Sign boards in right-of-way prohibited.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person, firm or corporation to erect, construct, establish, maintain or permit to exist any sign board, bill board, bulletin board or any other device for advertising purposes in, upon, or over any street, right-of-way, avenue, alley, sidewalk or any part thereof, within the city except as provided in this Code. The provisions of this section do not apply to any official sign authorized by law or ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-3; Code 1983, § 5-1419)
 
Sec. 32-20. Sign boards prohibited in residential area; exceptions.
(a)	No sign board, bill board, bulletin board shall be erected, constructed, established, maintained or permitted to exist in a residential area, except that a "For Sale" or "For Rent" sign, or a sign of similar import may be installed on residential property, not exceeding ten square feet in size. One non-illuminated name plate of not more than two square feet in area may be attached to a main or accessory building. 
(b)	In areas properly zoned for multiple family dwellings or manufactured homes, in addition thereto, one nameplate and sign relating only to the use of the property and structure located thereon may be erected; such sign or plate shall not exceed 40 square feet in size (only one side of double face sign shall be used in computing the area of the sign) and shall be harmonious with other designed features of the dwelling unit. The height of the sign is not to exceed 12 feet or the height of the nearest building, whichever is smaller. Such sign is not to be located within 15 feet of any property line, nor be on or over a street right-of-way. If the sign is to be provided with outdoor lighting, such lighting shall have an arrangement of reflectors, and an intensity of lighting which will not interfere with adjacent land use, or the use of adjacent streets, and is not to be of the flashing or intermittent type. No part of this section shall be construed to allow construction of a sign not in accordance with any other city ordinance. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-4; Code 1983, § 5-1420)
 
Sec. 32-21. Sign boards in business districts.
All signs, billboards, bulletin boards, sign boards, and other advertising devices shall be maintained only in the business district, except as may be provided by this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-5; Code 1983, § 5-1421)
 
Sec. 32-22. Sign board dimension.
No sign, sign board, bulletin board, billboard or other advertising device shall be erected, established, maintained or permitted to exist within the city in excess of 200 square feet in size. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-6; Code 1983, § 5-1422)
 
Sec. 32-23. Electric and neon signs.
(a)	All electric signs or neon signs must conform to the electric code, and in addition to the fee for erection of the sign as provided in this chapter, the fee for electric inspection shall be paid as provided by the city fee schedule. 
(b)	The mere holding of an electrical contractor's license or a journeyman wireman's license does not authorize the holders of such to erect or install signs. Before any sign is erected or installed by such license holders, they shall be required to comply with the advertising and sign ordinances of the city. 
(c)	There shall be provided a sign circuit fused separately from all inside and display window lighting and stubbed out in conduit on the face of the building and provided with weatherproof service head, in rooms designed for use as retail stores or display rooms. Each sign circuit also shall be provided with a switch of not less than 20-ampere capacity, so designed as to open each undergrounded conductor. This switch shall be installed as a part of the rough-in wiring, or shall be considered as a part of the finish if it is to be a time switch and is so reported to the electrical inspector. In the latter case, the opening for the time switch shall be installed with the original wiring. 
(d)	All wiring for neon signs shall be run in conduit, and all such conduit shall be grounded regardless of its length. The size of the conduit wiring and protection shall be adequate to carry, without voltage drop in excess of three percent, the total wattage indicated by the sum of the name-plate rating of the transformers connected to each such circuit. When transformers are rated in milliamperes and output voltage, the input load in watts, for determining wiring capacities necessary under this rule, shall be fixed by the following formula: 
milliamperes × output voltage watts = 1,000. 
(e)	When luminous-tube signs are installed on branch circuits carrying other loads in addition to the signs, such as outside decorative, border, outline, or marquee illumination, separate fuses, independent of the branch-circuit fuses, shall be installed in the sign conduit. 
(Prior Code, §§ 9-3.38, 3-1-8; Code 1983, § 5-1423)
 
Sec. 32-24. Signs, accessory.
There shall be allowed or permitted to any lawful authorized business in the city one accessory sign erected on the premises of the business, upon the obtaining of the permit, and the paying of the fees as provided in this chapter. The sign shall not exceed 200 square feet in size, and the major portion thereof is built of noncombustible material, and provided that the sign complies with the building set-back line, required for the main building. An accessory sign may be permitted to extend over the sidewalk, not more than eight feet if it does not exceed beyond the sidewalk, and is not more than two feet in width, and not less than eight feet above the sidewalk, and such signs are securely fastened to secure their stability. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-11; Code 1983, § 5-1424)
 
Sec. 32-25. Obstruction of view.
Anything contained in this Code to the contrary notwithstanding, it is unlawful and an offense, and it is a nuisance for any person to erect, construct or permit to exist any sign board, bill board, bulletin board, or other advertising device so as to obstruct the view of any street or alley intersection. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-12; Code 1983, § 5-1425)
 
Sec. 32-26. Signs in residential developments.
Nothing contained in this chapter shall prohibit the erection of a sign of a temporary nature in a newly developed residential area while houses are under construction, and being sold. All such signs must comply with the setback line. 
(Prior Code, § 3-1-14; Code 1983, § 5-1426)
 
Sec. 32-27. Face of sign shall be smooth.
All signs or other advertising structures which are constructed on street lines, or within five feet thereof, shall have a smooth surface and no nails, tacks or wires shall be permitted to protrude therefrom, except electrical reflectors and devices which may extend over the top and extend in front of the advertising structures. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.19; Code 1983, § 5-1427)
 
Sec. 32-28. Goose neck lights.
Goose neck lights shall be permitted on ground signs, roof signs, and wall signs; provided, however, the lights shall be placed so as to concentrate the illumination upon the area of the sign so as to prevent glare upon the street or adjacent property. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.20; Code 1983, § 5-1428)
 
Sec. 32-29. Illumination.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to maintain any sign which extends over public property which is wholly or partially illuminated by more than 30 footcandles per square foot. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.21; Code 1983, § 5-1429)
 
Sec. 32-30. Obscene matter prohibited.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to display upon any sign or other advertising structure any obscene, indecent or immoral matter. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.22; Code 1983, § 5-1430)
 
Sec. 32-31. Swinging signs.
It is unlawful and an offense for any person to install any type of swinging sign. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.23; Code 1983, § 5-1431)
 
Sec. 32-32. Ground signs.
(a)	Ground sign, as regulated by this chapter, includes any sign supported by uprights or braces placed upon the ground and not attached to any building. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All ground signs for which a permit is required under this chapter shall have a surface or facing of incombustible material; provided, however, that combustible structural trim may be used thereon; and 
(2)	All letters, figures, characters or representations in cut-out or irregular form, maintained in conjunction with, attached to, or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built or attached to the sign structure and shall comply with all city building and zoning regulations. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	It is unlawful and an offense to erect any ground sign whose total height is greater than 30 feet above the level of the street upon which the sign faces, or above the adjoining ground level, if such ground level is above the street level; 
(2)	Ground signs have an open space of not less than two feet between the base line of the sign and the ground level. This open space may be filled in with a platform or decorative lattice work which does not close off more than one-half of any square foot of such open space. No ground sign shall be nearer than two feet to any other sign, building or structure, provided that this does not apply to double faced signs; 
(3)	No ground sign shall be nearer the street than the property line established by law; and 
(4)	All ground signs shall conform to all city building and zoning regulations. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All ground signs shall be securely built, constructed and erected upon posts and standards sunk at least three feet below the natural surface of the ground, and if supported and braced by timbers, or metal rods in the rear thereof, they must extend from the top thereof to a point in the ground at least a distance equal to one-half the height of such sign, measured along the ground, from the posts or standards upon which the same is erected; 
(2)	All posts, anchors and bracing of wood shall be treated to protect them from moisture by creosoting or other approved methods when they rest or enter into the ground; and 
(3)	All ground signs shall conform to all city building and zoning regulations. 
(e)	All ground signs and the premises surrounding the same shall be maintained by the owner thereof in a clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish and weeds. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.24; Code 1983, § 5-1432)
 
Sec. 32-33. Wall signs.
(a)	Wall signs, as regulated by this chapter, include all flat signs of solid face construction which are placed against a building or other structure and attached to the exterior front, rear, or side wall of any building or other structure. 
(b)	All wall signs for which a permit is required under this chapter shall have a surface or facing of incombustible material; provided, however, that combustible structural trim may be used therein. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	No wall sign shall cover wholly or partially any wall opening, nor project beyond the ends or top of the wall to which it is attached, and any one wall sign shall not exceed an area of 750 square feet; 
(2)	No wall sign shall be permitted to extend more than 15 inches beyond the building line, and shall not be attached to a wall at a height of less than ten feet above the sidewalk or ground; and 
(3)	No wall sign shall be erected, re-located or maintained so as to prevent free ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All wall signs shall be safely and securely attached to the building wall by means of metal anchors, bolts or expansion screws of not less than three-eighths inch in diameter embedded in the wall at least five inches; provided, however, that such signs may rest in, or be bolted onto strong, heavy metal brackets or saddles set not over six feet apart, each of which is securely fixed to the wall as hereinbefore provided. In no case shall any wall sign be secured with wire, strips of wood or nails; and 
(2)	All wall signs shall conform to all city building and zoning regulations. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.25; Code 1983, § 5-1433)
 
Sec. 32-34. Roof signs.
(a)	A roof sign, as regulated by this chapter, means any sign erected, constructed and maintained wholly upon or over the roof of any building with the principal supports on the roof structure. 
(b)	Every roof sign, including the uprights supports and braces thereof, shall be constructed entirely of incombustible materials, provided, however, that combustible structural trim may be used thereon. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	No roof sign shall have a surface area exceeding 750 square feet, nor have its highest point extended more than 20 feet above the roof level, or fire wall; 
(2)	No roof sign shall be erected or maintained with the face thereof nearer than five feet to the outside wall toward which the sign faces; 
(3)	All roof signs shall have a space at least five feet in height between the base of the sign and the roof level, and have at least five feet clearance between the vertical supports thereof; and 
(4)	No roof sign shall be placed on the roof of any building or structure in such manner as to prevent free passage from one part of the roof to any other part thereof or interfere with openings in the roof and will comply with all city building and zoning regulations. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Every roof sign shall be thoroughly secured to the building by iron or other metal anchors, bolts, supports, rods, or braces. When erected upon buildings which are not constructed entirely of fireproof material, the bearing plates of the sign shall bear directly upon masonry walls and intermediate steel columns in the building. No roof sign will be supported or anchored to the wooden framework of a building; and 
(2)	All roof signs shall conform to all city building and zoning regulations. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.26; Code 1983, § 5-1434)
 
Sec. 32-35. Projecting signs.
(a)	A projecting sign, as regulated by this chapter, includes any sign which is attached to a building or other structure and extends beyond the line of the building or structure or beyond the surface of that portion of the building or structure to which it is attached. The term "horizontal projecting sign" means any sign which is greater in width than in height. The term "vertical projecting sign" means any sign which is greater in height than in width. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Every projecting sign, including the frames, braces and supports thereof, will be designed by a structural engineer or manufacturer and be approved by the building inspector as in compliance with the building code of the city and by the electrical inspector as in compliance with the electrical code of the city and where the electrical code does not cover, the Underwriters' Laboratories standard for electric signs shall cover, and shall be constructed of incombustible materials; 
(2)	The lights shall concentrate the illumination upon the area of the sign and prevent glare upon the street or adjacent property; 
(3)	The lettering or advertising designs to be illuminated may be composed of glass or other transparent or semitransparent incombustible material. Any glass forming a part of any sign shall be safety glass or plate glass at least one-half inch thick and in case any single piece or pane of glass has an area exceeding three square feet, be wired glass. One section, not exceeding three square feet in area, constructed of wire glass or safety glass shall be permitted on each side of a sign; 
(4)	Any moveable part of a projecting sign such as the cover of a service opening shall be securely fastened by chains or hinges; and 
(5)	Except by special permission of the city council, projecting signs shall be limited in area as follows: 
a.	Horizontal projecting signs 50 square feet each side; and 
b.	Vertical projecting signs 100 square feet each side. 
(6)	The distance measured between the principal faces of any projecting sign shall not exceed 18 inches. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Every projecting sign shall be placed at least ten feet above the sidewalk over which it is erected and a distance not greater than two feet from the face of the wall to which it is attached, measuring from the point on the sign nearest thereto, nor any sign or part thereof extend over the property line; 
(2)	Every projecting sign shall be erected in full compliance with all city building and zoning regulations. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Projecting signs exceeding ten square feet in area or 50 pounds in weight shall not be attached to nor supported by frame buildings nor the wooden framework of a building. The signs shall be attached to masonry walls with galvanized expansion bolts at least three-eighths inch in diameter, shall be fixed in the wall by means of bolts extending through the wall, shall contain proper size metal washer or plate on the inside of the wall and shall comply with all city building and zoning regulations. 
(2)	No projecting sign shall be secured with wire, strips of wood or nails, nor any projecting sign be hung or secured to any other sign. 
(e)	V-shaped signs, consisting of two single face signs erected without a roof or ceiling, are not permitted. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.27; Code 1983, § 5-1435)
 
Sec. 32-36. Temporary signs.
(a)	Temporary signs as regulated by this chapter shall include any sign, banner, pennant, valance or advertising display constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric, cardboard, wall board or other light materials, with or without frames, intended to be displayed for a short period of time only. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	No temporary sign of combustible material shall exceed four feet in one of its dimensions or 100 square feet in area, and provided such signs in excess of 60 square feet shall be made of rigid materials, that is, of wall board or other light materials with frames; and 
(2)	Every temporary sign weighing in excess of 50 pounds must be approved by the building inspector as conforming to the safety requirements of the building code of the city. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	No temporary sign shall extend over or into any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public thoroughfare and not be placed or projected over any wall opening; and 
(2)	No temporary sign shall be erected so as to prevent free ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape, nor shall such sign be attached to any stand pipe or fire escape. 
(d)	Every temporary sign shall be attached to the wall with wire or steel cables and no strings, ropes or wood slats for anchorage or support purposes shall be permitted. 
(e)	Permits for temporary signs authorizes the erection of the signs and their maintenance for a period not exceeding 30 days. 
(f)	The advertisement contained on any temporary sign pertains only to the business, industry or pursuit conducted on or within the premises on which such sign is erected or maintained. This provision shall not apply to signs of a civic, political or religious nature. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.28; Code 1983, § 5-1436)
 
Sec. 32-37. Marquees.
(a)	A "marquee," as regulated by this chapter, shall include any hood or awning of permanent construction projecting from the wall of a building above an entrance and extending over a thoroughfare. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All marquees, including the anchors, bolts, supports, rods and braces thereof shall be constructed of incombustible materials and shall be designed by a structural engineer and approved by the building inspector as in compliance with the building code of the city and by the electrical code of the city and where the electrical code does not cover, the Underwriters' Laboratories standard for electric signs shall cover, and shall be illuminated; 
(2)	The roofs of all marquees shall be properly guttered and connected by down spouts to a sewer so that the water therefrom will not drip or flow onto public property; and 
(3)	The roofs of all marquees shall be used for no other purpose than to form and constitute a roof, and at least 25 percent of the area of the roof of every marquee shall be of glass or other incombustible transparent substance. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	No portion of a marquee shall be less than ten feet above the level of the sidewalk or other public thoroughfare; 
(2)	No marquee shall be permitted to extend beyond a point two feet inside the curb line; and 
(3)	No marquee shall be wider than the entrance of the building, plus five feet on each side thereof, provided, however, that where the entrances to a building are not more than 20 feet apart, a marquee may be made a continuous single structure between the entrances. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Marquees shall be supported solely by the building to which they are attached, and no columns or posts shall be permitted as support therefor; 
(2)	The roof of any marquee except glass area required shall be designed and constructed to support a live load of not less than 100 pounds per square foot. The wind pressure requirements shall be as stated in city building and zoning regulations; and 
(3)	No marquee shall be erected on any building of wood frame construction unless attached to the masonry, concrete or steel supports of the building. 
(e)	Signs attached to or hung from a marquee shall be completely within the borderline of the marquee outer edge, and in no instance be lower than ten feet above the sidewalk or public thoroughfare. No sign or advertising material shall exceed five feet in height exclusive of the name of the establishment exhibiting such marquee. No advertising material shall be placed upon the roof of any marquee. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.29; Code 1983, § 5-1437)
 
Sec. 32-38. Awnings and canopies.
(a)	The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Auto canopy or awning includes any structure designed for the purpose of sheltering an automobile and carried by a frame supported by the ground. 
Awning includes any structure made of cloth or metal with a metal frame attached to a building and projecting over a thoroughfare, when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in use. 
Canopy includes any structure other than an awning made of cloth or metal with metal frame attached to a building, projecting over a thoroughfare, and carried by a frame supported by ground or sidewalk. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Awnings may be constructed of cloth or metal provided, however, all frames and supports shall be of metal; and 
(2)	Canopies may be constructed of cloth or metal hood; provided, however, all frames and supports shall be of metal. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All awnings shall be constructed and erected so that the lowest portion thereof shall be not less than ten feet above the level of the sidewalk or public thoroughfare; 
(2)	All canopies shall be constructed and erected so that the lowest portion thereof shall be not less than ten feet above the level of the sidewalk or public thoroughfare; 
(3)	No awnings or canopy shall be permitted to extend beyond a point two feet inside the curb line; 
(4)	No limitation on width of awnings provided, however, full compliance with all city building and zoning regulations; and 
(5)	No auto awning or canopy shall be permitted to extend beyond the property line or interfere with the site triangle at an intersection which shall be for a distance of 25 feet along each intersecting property line. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Every awning shall be securely attached to and supported by the building. Posts or columns beyond the building line shall not be permitted for awnings. No awning shall be attached to the wood jambs, frames or other wood members of a building (frame buildings excepted) when such building is less than ten feet from public property; and 
(2)	The framework of all canopies shall be designed by a structural engineer and approved by the building inspector as in compliance with the building code of the city. All frames and supports shall be of metal and designed to withstand a wind pressure as provided in section 32-13. 
(e)	No advertising shall be placed on any awning or canopy except that the name of the owner and the business, industry or pursuit conducted within the premises may be painted or otherwise permanently placed in a space not exceeding eight inches in height on the front and side portions thereof. 
(f)	Permits for awnings and canopies shall be required as provided in section 32-4. 
(g)	Every awning shall be rolled or folded against the building wall except when service as a protection from sun, rain, snow or other inclement weather. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.30; Code 1983, § 5-1438)
 
Sec. 32-39. Street clocks.
(a)	A street clock as regulated by this chapter means any timepiece erected upon a standard upon the sidewalk, or on the exterior of any building or structure for the convenience of the public and placed and maintained by some person for the purpose of advertising their place of business. 
(b)	Construction requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All street clocks as herein defined shall be constructed of incombustible material, including the frames, braces and supports thereof; 
(2)	The dial of such clocks shall be not less than 30 inches in diameter; 
(3)	Any glass forming a part of a clock or the sign thereon shall be safety glass or plate glass at least one-fourth-inch thick and in case any single piece or pane of glass has an area exceeding three square feet, it shall be constructed of wired glass, securely held in place; and 
(4)	Any moveable part of a street clock, that is, cover or service opening shall be securely fastened by metal hinges. 
(c)	Location requirements are as follows: 
(1)	Clocks supported on the corner of any building or structure at the intersection of two streets shall not be less than 15 feet or more than 20 feet above the sidewalk and shall not project from the face or wall of the building or structure in any direction more than five feet; and 
(2)	Every clock erected on the sidewalk shall be supported upon a post of ornamental design, the total height of which shall be not less than 15 feet, shall be not more than 20 inches from the outer edge of the curb, and shall be at least 20 feet from the point of intersection of the lines of any street, measured parallel with the street. 
(d)	Erection requirements are as follows: 
(1)	All clocks erected on the exterior of any building or structure shall comply with the requirements set forth in section 32-33 of this Code regulating wall signs, or section 32-35 regulating projecting signs in all respects concerning erection, whichever applies; and 
(2)	All street clocks, whether erected on exterior walls or on the sidewalk, shall comply with the requirements of section 32-13. 
(e)	Any person erecting a street clock on any public sidewalk shall obtain the special written permission of the city council in addition to all other permits required hereunder. 
(f)	No person shall be permitted to erect more than one street clock as herein defined for any place of business at any one location. 
(g)	Only the name of the owner, proprietor or manager of the place of business erecting and maintaining such clock shall be permitted as advertising matter on the clock. 
(h)	Such clock shall keep accurate time, and if this condition is not complied with, the clock shall be promptly repaired or removed. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.31; Code 1983, § 5-1439)
 
Sec. 32-40. Non-conforming signs.
The use of any sign or other advertising structure in existence on adoption of this chapter which violates or does not conform to the provisions hereof may be continued so long as such sign or structure is safe and secure; provided that such sign or structure is not existing on street right-of-way or extending over street right-of-way, and they may not be enlarged, altered, or replaced except so as to conform with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.32; Code 1983, § 5-1440)
 
Sec. 32-41. Public property.
It is unlawful to erect or maintain any sign on, over or across any street, alley or public property in the city except as herein specifically authorized. 
(Prior Code, § 9-8.33; Code 1983, § 5-1441)
 
Sec. 32-42. Revocation of permit for projecting sign.
Any permit issued under the provisions of this chapter for the erection, installation or maintenance of a sign which projects over any public street, highway, alley, parkway or sidewalk constitutes a mere license and may be revoked by the building inspector or by the city council if it should be determined that such sign should be removed in the interest of public safety and welfare or if the improvement of the public way over which such sign projects should make such removal necessary. A written notice of such revocation shall be delivered to the owner or occupant of the premises upon which such sign is located and if such owner or occupant cannot be found, such notice shall be posted on the premises. Either the owner of the premises or the person, firm or corporation having control over such sign shall within ten days from the date of delivery or posting of such notice, as the case may be, remove such sign insofar as it may project over or across such public way.
